From jason at vancleve.com  Mon Dec  1 10:46:01 2003
From: jason at vancleve.com (Jason Van Cleve)
Date: Mon Dec  1 10:46:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] iptables And /proc Control
Message-ID: <20031201114450.18286f3d.jason@vancleve.com>

I'm curious:  why are packet filtering options needed in /proc, when netfilter offers so much power?  For instance some iptables tutorials suggest doing this

echo "1" > /proc/sys/net/ipv4/icmp_echo_ignore_all

to disable "response to ping".  There are several other similar commands.  I'm not sure exactly what they effect, but couldn't one achieve the same with iptables?

--Jason Van Cleve

From mark at linuxhardware.net  Mon Dec  1 11:29:02 2003
From: mark at linuxhardware.net (Mark Griskey)
Date: Mon Dec  1 11:29:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Leaving the List - Firewire and Linux
Message-ID: <200312011124.02930.mark@linuxhardware.net>

Greetings, 

I am leaving the Portland area (heading to Pittsburgh, PA), and therefore will 
be leaving the list.  Over the past few years I've mostly lurked, but my 
knowledge base has expanded by following many of the threads on this list.  
In that light, I thought I would take this as an opportunity to share my 
recent experience with digital video and linux and 802.11b usb wireless 
device under Linux.

I had to install a firewire PCI card to use my digital video camera with 
Linux.  I bought the cheapest one ENU inc has available, it was $26.  I don't 
know what brand it is, it just said "firewire" on the box.  I figured it was 
pretty generic, and I was right.  I has the ohci chip on it, which is well 
supported under linux.  After installing the card, I re-built my kernel with 
the IEEE1394 support enabled and the other fire-wire related options built as 
modules.

I then installed kino, (http://kino.schirmacher.de/) a digital video grabbing 
and editing program.  I plugged the camera into the computer, loaded the 
firewire module and the IEEE1394 video module, the camera was detected, fired 
up kino, and that was it, I was receiving digital video from the camera, it 
was really easy.  

This particular camera also takes still shots, I used gphoto2 to retrieve 
those with absolutely no problems, although I did have to upgrade to the 
latest version for the camera support.

Now on to the wireless.  Since I am moving, and will be temporarily staying 
with relatives, I want to be able to set my desktop up without having to fish 
wires.  So I headed to Worst Buy and bought a D-Link DW 122 usb wireless 
adapter. (It has the prism2 chip) After downloading and building the wlan-ng 
usb driver (http://www.linux-wlan.org/), I plugged the device in and loaded 
the module.  Within seconds I was on-line.  Speaking of wireless, don't buy 
the D-Link DWL520, although it doesn't say on the packaging, it needs a PCI 
2.2 slot.  However, there are reports that it works in a PCI 2.1 slot.  I 
have a 2.1 slot and it didn't work.  While researching which devices really 
do have the prism2 chip, I noticed that Linksys has been switching to the 
broadcom chip in some of their cards, if you are in the market for one of 
these, be mindful of this, as the broadcom chip is as of yet unsupported.

One this that I didn't get working, and partly because I ran out of time, was 
my Lacie 80gig firewire hard disk. IT needs the SBP-2 module, which was 
fussy.  I have reports that it does work, but I will have to wait to try it.

Mark

  What do I do to just get a root shell that will allow me to change root's

From drl at drloree.com  Mon Dec  1 12:43:02 2003
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Mon Dec  1 12:43:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Getting a root prompt upon booting
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0312011221370.6360@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0312011221370.6360@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1070311404.676.11.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Mon, 2003-12-01 at 12:25, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   I'm getting my old notebook ready for sale and tried changing the password
> to a give-away. Apparently, my fingers mistyped the new password the same
> way twice: I cannot log in under either the new or old root password.
> 
>   So, I tried booting into single user mode. This is one a Slackware-9.1
> system. At the boot prompt I type 'linux single' or 'linux 1' and it does
> boot into single-user mode, but asks for a login. Sigh.
> 
>   What do I do to just get a root shell that will allow me to change root's
> password? The boot loader on this box is LILO, not grub.

The only way that I know of is to boot the box with an alternative, like
knoppix, and then delete the root password hash from the /etc/shadow
file on the hard-drive.  Don't let the knoppix GUI mount the hard-drive,
it will mount it read-only.  (Of course, the command "mount / -o rw -o
remount" will take care of the problem.)

Good Luck,

Derek Loree





From lemming at quirkyqatz.com  Mon Dec  1 13:03:02 2003
From: lemming at quirkyqatz.com (Mark Morgan)
Date: Mon Dec  1 13:03:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Getting a root prompt upon booting
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0312011221370.6360@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0312011221370.6360@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <56285.134.134.136.3.1070312558.squirrel@webmail.pair.com>

Rich Shepard said:
>
>   What do I do to just get a root shell that will allow me to change
> root's password? The boot loader on this box is LILO, not grub.

"linux init=/bin/bash rw"
will probably work.  From there it's usually easier to just edit the
password file to null out the root password.  sync your HD before
rebooting to be safe.

From mikeraz at patch.com  Mon Dec  1 13:05:03 2003
From: mikeraz at patch.com (Michael Rasmussen)
Date: Mon Dec  1 13:05:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Getting a root prompt upon booting
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0312011221370.6360@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0312011221370.6360@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <20031201210343.GB10484@patch.com>

On Mon, Dec 01, 2003 at 12:25:03PM -0800, Rich Shepard wrote:
> 
>   What do I do to just get a root shell that will allow me to change root's
> password? The boot loader on this box is LILO, not grub.
> 

At the lilo prompt type:

	IMAGENAME init=/bin/bash

You'll be in as root with a bash shell.  

See:  http://www.hackinglinuxexposed.com/articles/20020702.html

for one of the many explanations.

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Mon Dec  1 13:08:01 2003
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: Mon Dec  1 13:08:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Getting a root prompt upon booting
In-Reply-To: <1070311404.676.11.camel@fastlinux.homenet>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0312011221370.6360@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	<1070311404.676.11.camel@fastlinux.homenet>
Message-ID: <867k1gnt5x.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Derek" == Derek Loree <drl at drloree.com> writes:

Rich> What do I do to just get a root shell that will allow me to
Rich> change root's password? The boot loader on this box is LILO, not
Rich> grub.

Derek> The only way that I know of is to boot the box with an
Derek> alternative, like knoppix, and then delete the root password
Derek> hash from the /etc/shadow file on the hard-drive.  Don't let
Derek> the knoppix GUI mount the hard-drive, it will mount it
Derek> read-only.  (Of course, the command "mount / -o rw -o remount"
Derek> will take care of the problem.)

That will work.  The other solution is to boot linux with the
init=/bin/sh boot option trick, and edit /etc/passwd or /etc/shadow as
appropriate (removing the password hash).  That will allow you to
reboot and login root without a password, which is sufficient to reset
the password to whatever you like (paying more attention this time).

From aaron at speakeasy.org  Mon Dec  1 14:14:02 2003
From: aaron at speakeasy.org (Aaron Burt)
Date: Mon Dec  1 14:14:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] iptables And /proc Control
In-Reply-To: <20031201114450.18286f3d.jason@vancleve.com>
References: <20031201114450.18286f3d.jason@vancleve.com>
Message-ID: <20031201221333.GB22543@bavariati.org>

On Mon, Dec 01, 2003 at 11:44:50AM -0700, Jason Van Cleve wrote:
> I'm curious:  why are packet filtering options needed in /proc, when
> netfilter offers so much power?  For instance some iptables tutorials
> suggest doing this
> 
> echo "1" > /proc/sys/net/ipv4/icmp_echo_ignore_all
> 
> to disable "response to ping".  There are several other similar
> commands.  I'm not sure exactly what they effect, but couldn't one
> achieve the same with iptables?

One could, but these directly control the behavior of the network stack
rather than filtering stuff before it gets there.  So same effect but
much different cause.

Also, it means you can do a few basic things without loading netfilter.

Why have an accelerator pedal if you can hit the brake to slow down,
  Aaron



From keithl at kl-ic.com  Mon Dec  1 15:25:03 2003
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Mon Dec  1 15:25:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] commercial VPN site hosting?
Message-ID: <20031201232335.GA20663@gate.kl-ic.com>

I had a bit of a scare today, when I found that Comcast has started
blocking ping.  I have heard tales of them blocking other ports in
other regions, and I should be prepared for future buttheadedness.

Are there any commercial services that offer "static IP at one end,
VPN at the other end?"  With such a service, I could VPN out through
my comcast line, and put up my ports and an IP address to hang my
present incoming services (ping, smtp, ssh, http redirect) on.

A service that also hosted webpages, and supported CGI for perl and
wiki, would be even better.

I don't need the service now (unless it is cheap) but it would be
nice to plan in advance of need.

Keith

From Steve.Daggett at fiserv.com  Mon Dec  1 15:39:02 2003
From: Steve.Daggett at fiserv.com (Daggett, Steve)
Date: Mon Dec  1 15:39:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Linux kernel do_brk() function vulnerability
Message-ID: <05AD3C7EEA42D311809300902785AC8A07FD434C@eft01ms01.eft.fiserv.net>

>From TrueSecure, TSRadar list:
Background:  On Friday, November 21, 2003, the Debian project
announced several of their systems had been compromised with no
further information regarding how.  Today Debian and Red Hat
(Enterprise) issued patches to their Kernels.

- - From the Debian Security Advisory:
>Recently multiple servers of the Debian project were compromised
>using a Debian developers account and an unknown root exploit.
>Forensics
>revealed a burneye encrypted exploit. Robert van der Meulen managed
>to decrypt the binary which revealed a kernel exploit. Study of the
>exploit by the RedHat and SuSE kernel and security teams quickly
>revealed that the exploit used an integer overflow in the brk system
>call. Using
>this bug it is possible for a userland program to trick the kernel
>into giving access to the full kernel address space. This problem
>was found in September by Andrew Morton, but unfortunately that was
>too late for the 2.4.22 kernel release.
>
>This bug has been fixed in kernel version 2.4.23 for the 2.4 tree
>and 2.6.0-test6 kernel tree. For Debian it has been fixed in version
>2.4.18-12 of the kernel source packages, version 2.4.18-14 of the
>i386 kernel images and version 2.4.18-11 of the alpha kernel images.
> 

CAN-2003-0961 (under review) 
http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CAN-2003-0961

Updated 2.4 kernel fixes privilege escalation
http://rhn.redhat.com/errata/RHSA-2003-389.html


Steve Daggett
Senior Network Design Engineer

From barryb at actionnet.net  Mon Dec  1 16:22:19 2003
From: barryb at actionnet.net (barryb at actionnet.net)
Date: Mon Dec  1 16:22:19 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Recording Internet radio
In-Reply-To: <1069549807.23716.34.camel@halo>
References: <1069549807.23716.34.camel@halo>
Message-ID: <20031123021741.GA10094@edge>

On Sat, Nov 22, 2003 at 05:10:06PM -0800, Holger Stephan wrote:
> I'd like to record an Internet radio broadcasting tomorrow night. Are
> there any good tools out there for that? I am a bit concerned about the
> file size, it is a 4 1/2 hour opera. It is not so much the hard disk
> space but will recording software handling such a big file?

A tool that I have found useful for generic broadcast recording is vsound
http://www.zorg.org/vsound/
The hard disk space taken will depend on what sample rate you record at.
4 1/2 hours of cd quality will be about 4 1/2 cd's worth of data so
roughly 2.5GB. Later you could compress it using your favorite codec
into a much smaller space or burn it on a cd. You could also record
at a lower sample rate, especially if the broadcast itself is not
being done at a high bit rate.

Bill Barry

From sbonds at agora.rdrop.com  Mon Dec  1 16:22:58 2003
From: sbonds at agora.rdrop.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Mon Dec  1 16:22:58 2003
Subject: [PLUG] RAID 1 suggestions
In-Reply-To: <4514.216.99.218.67.1069742039.squirrel@sautez.com>
References: <4437.216.99.218.67.1069737763.squirrel@sautez.com>   
 <Pine.LNX.4.52.0311242215350.22235@shaft.bitmine.net>
 <4514.216.99.218.67.1069742039.squirrel@sautez.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.BSF.4.58.0311250954510.57502@agora.rdrop.com>

On Mon, 24 Nov 2003, Josh Orchard josh-at-emediatedesigns.com |PDX Linux| wrote:

> I don't know what else I would want to take into account. Here is what
> I'm trying to resolve:
>
> 1. Backups
> 2. Little but preferred no maintenance
> 3. Easy recovery
>
> It just seemed that RAID 1 was a simple solution with little worries.
> The other option is to RSYN the drives minus the obvious /proc and some
> others.  But this doesn't give you hot swap ability.  You would have to
> turn off the drive do a lilo or other grub loader thingy and then it
> would work again.  Maybe.

For a really simple, low-effort way to achieve this, I would think about
the following:

Allocate 50% of each drive for the usual filesystems, software mirrored.
This protects you from hardware failure but not from accidental deletes,
programs going nuts, filesystem bugs, etc. etc.

For example, on a pair of hypothetical 40GB drives you could have half the
drive used like this:

200MB  /dev/md0 /boot
512MB  /dev/md1 <swap>
8192MB /dev/md2 /
8192MB /dev/md3 /home

The rest of the drives serves as a mirrored local to-disk backup area:

16384MB /dev/md4 /backups

I suggest setting up a script that uses "dump" to back up the mirrored
partitions to the backups area.  A sample script is attached.

The first level 0 dump should be copied to a couple tapes, a stack of
CD-Rs, or a hard drive that is removed from the system.  (Alternatively,
only allocate 25% of your disks, and make the backup area the other 75%,
but that wastes a lot of your online storage on static data.)

The level 0 backup would only be needed if a file that has not changed
since that level 0 backup was created needed to be restored.  I've never
had to do this, since I seem to only damage/delete recently created files.
However, you'll want that level 0 backup somewhere-- just in case.  (I
usually use stacks of CD-Rs for this.)

The attached backup script sample schedule never does a level 0 (full)
backup for this reason.

Easy recovery is the reason I like the dump utility.  Using "restore -i" I
can use the bash-like interface to mark the files I want restored, then
restore them.  (Because RAID provides basic protection, I'm seldom doing a
full restore.)

The "Tower of Hanoi" sequence mentioned in the script makes it a bit
harder to find the files you want restored but saves lots of disk space.
If you want a truly easy recovery, just make every backup a level 1 and
you'll never need to hunt through multiple backups to find the files you
want.

As always, do a test restore to familiarize yourself with the process so
you don't have to learn it under pressure.  Also, periodic test restores
help ensure that the backups are valid and that you've included all the
devices that should be included.

  -- Steve
-------------- next part --------------
#!/bin/sh

# Backs up system to a second local drive using "dump".  The only parameter
# is the "dump" incremental level.  This script has only been tested
# on Linux using ext2 dump.

# YOU MUST RUN A LEVEL 0 BACKUP MANUALLY BEFORE USING THIS SCRIPT.  It will
# still work without this, but your first "level 1" will be huge.

# Below is a sample schedule of system backups with level 1 on 
# Saturday.  Adjust schedule as makes the most sense for your 
# activity schedule.  The below "Tower of Hanoi" sequence
# is highly recommended since it allows for a maximum number of points
# in time available for recovery with a minimum amount of storage usage.
# (At the expense of some additional complexity during restores.)

# To restore a given day's data:
# DoW     Levels needed
# ------ --------------
# Sat(6): 1
# Sun(0): 1,3
# Mon(1): 1,2
# Tue(2): 1,3,5
# Wed(3): 1,2,4
# Thu(4): 1,3,5,7
# Fri(5): 1,2,4,6

# Sample crontab entries for the above schedule:

#00 06 * * 6 root /root/backup.sh 1 >> /var/tmp/backup.cron.out 2>&1
#00 06 * * 0 root /root/backup.sh 3 >> /var/tmp/backup.cron.out 2>&1
#00 06 * * 1 root /root/backup.sh 2 >> /var/tmp/backup.cron.out 2>&1
#00 06 * * 2 root /root/backup.sh 5 >> /var/tmp/backup.cron.out 2>&1
#00 06 * * 3 root /root/backup.sh 4 >> /var/tmp/backup.cron.out 2>&1
#00 06 * * 4 root /root/backup.sh 7 >> /var/tmp/backup.cron.out 2>&1
#00 06 * * 5 root /root/backup.sh 6 >> /var/tmp/backup.cron.out 2>&1

# The simplest way to restore a file is to use 
# "restore -t -A <archive file>" to list the contents of the dump and
# grep for the file(s) that need to be restored.  Then use "restore -i"
# to interactively restore them.

# Note that this script overwrites each level's previous backup with the
# new one.  It also aborts on the first error so any subsequent 
# filesystems will NOT BE BACKED UP.

# Steve Bonds
# Email: rn5o6kw02 at sneakemail.com
# Copyright 2003, All rights reserved
# Redistribution permitted under the terms of the GNU General Public License
# version 2.0.  http://www.gnu.org/copyleft/gpl.html

bail() {
	MAIL_NEEDED=yes
	echo `date` "[$$]: Error: $1"
	echo `date` "[$$]: Error: $1" >> $MAIL_BODY
	MAIL_SUBJECT="Fatal backup error on $HOSTNAME"
	send_mail
	exit 1
}	

send_mail() {
	if [ "${MAIL_NEEDED}x" != "x" -a "${MAIL_TO}x" != "x" ]; then
		cat $MAIL_BODY | $MAIL_CMD "$MAIL_SUBJECT" $MAIL_TO
		cat $MAIL_BODY
	elif [ "${MAIL_NEEDED}x" != "x" ]; then
		echo "Subject: $MAIL_SUBJECT"
		cat $MAIL_BODY
	fi
	rm -f $MAIL_BODY
}

############################################################
# Customize these as needed
MAIL_TO=root

# This script assumes that the following structure is in place:
# ${BACKUP_AREA}/level0
# ${BACKUP_AREA}/level1
# ...
# ${BACKUP_AREA}/level9
BACKUP_AREA=/backups

# List of devices to back up without the /dev in front.  Don't
# try to back up the area where $BACKUP_AREA is located or you
# will waste a LOT of space.
DEVICES="md0 md1 md2 md3"

############################################################
# These should be fine as-is

HOSTNAME=`hostname`
MAIL_CMD="mail -s"
MAIL_BODY=`mktemp backup.XXXXXX`

############################################################
# Actual commands

LEVEL=$1
: ${LEVEL:?"Please specify backup level (0-9), 0=full"}
shift

# Backups contain every file on the system, so it's real important to be sure
# that only root can read them.
umask 077

case $LEVEL in
	[0123456789]) # OK to proceed
	;;
	*) echo "Invalid level, must be 0 through 9"
	exit
esac

for device in $DEVICES; do
	# If you like, you can create cd-sized images via -M -B 665600
	# This is handy for burning them onto CD-R media

	# The filenames are used several places, so only figure them
	# out once.  Do not embed a datestamp so each level's backup
	# overwrites the previous one.
	DUMP_FILE=${BACKUP_AREA}/level${LEVEL}/${device}.dump
	ARCHIVE_FILE=${BACKUP_AREA}/level${LEVEL}/${device}.archive

	# Remove existing backup at the same level from last week
	rm -f $DUMP_FILE $ARCHIVE_FILE

	dump -${LEVEL} -f $DUMP_FILE -A $ARCHIVE_FILE -q -u -z1 /dev/${device} && echo `date` "$device backup succeeded" || bail "Problem backing up $device" 

done

From svanhoosen at yahoo.com  Mon Dec  1 16:33:02 2003
From: svanhoosen at yahoo.com (Scott Van Hoosen)
Date: Mon Dec  1 16:33:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Setting UP TCP/IP in Linux
In-Reply-To: <000001c3b3ea$ba81be10$7900a8c0@ALRice>
Message-ID: <20031202003202.21186.qmail@web40804.mail.yahoo.com>

What distribution are you using? I use Red Hat, and know of a few ways
to do these things.

To check your IP address settings, use the "ifconfig" command. To read
details about this command, use the "man" command like so: "man
ifconfig"

The "man" command is very useful and gives you details about just about
any command or program you can think of.

To set your IP address in Red Hat, one way is with "netconfig." You
could also manually edit your ethernet config file, which might be
something like /etc/sysconfig/network-scripts/ifcfg-eth0. You can also
set up your network with ifconfig. Again, check the man page.

I hope this helps,

-Scott

Most likely, you didn't have the /usr partition mounted as you did not 
go through the whole init cycle. However, wiping the disk and doing a 
fresh install is the more practical choice when selling a computer. I 
would probably take the additional step of doing a secure delete and 
overwriting the sectors to make sure that none of your personal data 
can be recovered. There are many utilities for doing this.  A quick 
google will find you many choices that fit on a floppy.

From ian at znark.com  Mon Dec  1 19:21:01 2003
From: ian at znark.com (Ian Burrell)
Date: Mon Dec  1 19:21:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] validation

From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Mon Dec  1 19:40:03 2003
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Mon Dec  1 19:40:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] no sound w/ devfs
In-Reply-To: <200312011823.24762.Finn@graveyard-freelance.org>
References: <200312011823.24762.Finn@graveyard-freelance.org>
Message-ID: <1070336352.11139.20.camel@dell.linux.box>

On Mon, 2003-12-01 at 10:23, Finn wrote:
> recently i have been having an issue with no sound under devfs.  The 
> documentation for devfs has been no help, as everything appears to be 
> configured correctly according to the examples.  KDE keeps saying /dev/dsp 
> does not exist (and i can't find it either) Checked the kernel logs and devfs 
> is starting properly and devfsd is running.  Also all the appropriate modules 
> are loaded.  Anyone have a clue bat for this one?

Check out /dev/snd/ if you're using alsa, and /dev/sound/ no matter what
you're using.

With devfs, /dev/dsp is almost always a symlink to /dev/sound/dsp...

FWIW, it seems devfs is on its way out.  I gave it a shot here on my
laptop and have been sorely disappointed in it.  I see no advantages and
plenty of disadvantages.

Rob

From: carla at bratgrrl.com (Carla Schroder)

Subject: [PLUG] Getting a root prompt upon booting
In-Reply-To: <3FCBF457.6040602@pacifier.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0312011221370.6360@salmo.appl-ecosys.com> <Pine.LNX.4.56.0312011725480.7128@salmo.appl-ecosys.com> <3FCBF457.6040602@pacifier.com>

On Monday 01 December 2003 6:09 pm, Kyle Accardi wrote:
> Rich Shepard wrote:
> 
> >   Frustratingly, when I was at the boot prompt I discovered that I 
had no
> > editor available to me. No vim, emacs or joe! Worse, when I tried 
'ls /usr',
> > the shell prompt immediately returned; no listing of files or 
directories in
> > /usr.
> 
> This sounds like a case for chroot.  Suspect that your normal 
filesystems 
> weren't mounted and you were working with the bare minimum.  One nice 
thing 
> RedHat does in this case is to spit out a reminder on how to do this 
when in 
> single-user/rescue mode.

I love Knoppix for this kind of thing, it makes it soooo easy. 

"Open a root shell on the host system
This lets you operate on the host system, as though you were logged into 
it directly. Identify the partition the host system is on, then open a 
Knoppix root shell and mount it:

root at ttyp0[knoppix]# mount /dev/hda1 /mnt/hda1
root at ttyp0[knoppix]# chroot /mnt/hda1
root at Knoppix:/ "

From http://www-106.ibm.com/developerworks/linux/library/l-knopx.html

$ cvs login
Logging in to :pserver:kyle at rufus:2401/home/cvsroot
CVS password:
/home/cvsroot: no such repository
$

/var/log/messages reports
Dec  1 20:04:40 rufus cvs: login refused for /home/cvsroot

Does it really think /home/cvsroot is a user? or it's not happy with the way 
the repository is set up?


The Facts:

Repository is /home/cvsroot

Added newgroup 'cvs', my user is in that group

$ ls -la /home/cvsroot
drwxrwxr-x    6 cvs      cvs          4096 Nov 28 18:57 .
drwxr-xr-x    8 root     root         4096 Nov 28 17:50 ..
drwxrwxr-x    3 cvs      cvs          4096 Nov 28 18:22 CVSROOT

                =========================

$ echo $CVSROOT
:pserver:kyle at rufus:/home/cvsroot

                =========================

Created /etc/xinetd.d/cvspserver/ like so,
service cvspserver
{
         socket_type         = stream
         protocol            = tcp
         wait                = no
         user                = root
         passenv             =
         server              = /usr/bin/cvs
         server_args         = -f --allow-root=/home/cvsroot/ pserver
	disable		    = no
}

Restarted xinetd

                =========================

$ grep cvspserver /etc/services
cvspserver	2401/tcp	# CVS client/server operations
cvspserver	2401/udp	# CVS client/server operations

Did you initialize a new new repository like so?

cvs -d /home/cvsroot init

It looks like it since I see a CVSROOT directory. Also make sure you 
have entered your password correctly for the userid you are using. I 
know for my userids that access CVS I have them assigned to the cvs 
group too.

Check your xinitd.d/cvspserver setup too:

On Mon, 2003-12-01 at 23:14, Marvin J. Kosmal wrote:

> Or just use dd
> 
> dd if=/dev/zero  of=/dev/hda  bs=512
> 
> Let that run till done..

The data on the drive is still very easily recoverable after that,
however.  Shoot, you could probably do it from Windows.  :-)

I feel safe after dd'ing it with zero once, then with /dev/urandom
twice.  The data on the drive is still recoverable at that point... but
it's not quite so easy to get at it and beyond the capabilities of most
folks.  If you only want to run over it once, I'd go with urandom over
zero... I would think that would help at least a little bit.

Rob

From heinlein at madboa.com  Tue Dec  2 07:49:01 2003
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Tue Dec  2 07:49:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] local cvs repository
In-Reply-To: <3FCC2885.4030303@pacifier.com>
References: <3FCC114F.5060401@pacifier.com> <200312012128.16438.aschlemm@comcast.net>
 <3FCC2885.4030303@pacifier.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0312020740200.10845@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Mon, 1 Dec 2003, Kyle Accardi wrote:

> I was also under the impression that xinetd (unlike its predecessor)
> didn't really need to be restarted because configs were read
> on-demand--obviously not the case.

Folks in Red Hat land can use /sbin/chkconfig to manage xinetd
services, assuming that a file for that service already exists in
/etc/xinetd.d:

[heinlein]$ chkconfig --list | grep ^[[:space:]]
        chargen-udp:    off
        rsync:  off
        chargen:        off
        daytime-udp:    off
        daytime:        off
        echo-udp:       off
        echo:   off
        services:       off
        servers:        off
        time-udp:       off
        time:   off
        cups-lpd:       off
        sgi_fam:        on
        ktalk:  off

To turn on, say, time, just issue

  chkconfig time on

chkconfig will send SIGHUP to xinetd for you; check /var/log/messages
for log spew.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>



From shahms at shahms.com  Tue Dec  2 09:02:01 2003
From: shahms at shahms.com (Shahms King)
Date: Tue Dec  2 09:02:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] local cvs repository
In-Reply-To: <3FCC114F.5060401@pacifier.com>
References: <3FCC114F.5060401@pacifier.com>
Message-ID: <1070384256.11265.52.camel@shahms.mesd.k12.or.us>

I know this isn't the question you asked, but I can't help recommending
arch or subversion.  Arch is dead simple to set up and much easier to
use than CVS (and much, um, more reliable in my experience).  I haven't
personally user subversion, but given that most of the developers are
also the maintainers of CVS, I'm guessing it's pretty similar but
"better."  I've never successfully set up a SVN server, however, so I
don't know.  It's also now a GNU project and at
http://www.gnu.org/software/gnu-arch/ I have spec files and RPMS if
you're using RedHat and decide to go that route.  I've replaced all of
my CVS repos with arch archives and haven't looked back.
-- 
Shahms King <shahms at shahms.com>

From srau at rauhaus.org  Tue Dec  2 10:39:02 2003
From: srau at rauhaus.org (Stafford A. Rau)
Date: Tue Dec  2 10:39:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] iptables And /proc Control
In-Reply-To: <20031201191415.05367734.jason@vancleve.com>
References: <20031201114450.18286f3d.jason@vancleve.com> <20031201221333.GB22543@bavariati.org> <20031201191415.05367734.jason@vancleve.com>
Message-ID: <20031202183830.GA21733@rauhaus.org>

* Jason Van Cleve <jason at vancleve.com> [031201 18:15]:
> 
> What I'm wondering is, if I'm going to use netfilter, why bother with
> the /proc options?  They show up in most iptables sample scripts, so
> there must be a reason.
 
For one, if you have multiple interfaces, you are not going to forward
packets unless /proc/sys/net/ipv4/ip_forward is "1", regardless of what
iptables says.

--Stafford

Subject: [PLUG] Emergency boot disk creation

Surely you've heard this one before. One has a Linux
installation that boots from a floppy, and loses the
ssme. What's worse, this distro does not make a boot
disk as part of the installation routine.

Is it possible to make a boot disk by copying
individual files onto a floppy, and if so which ones
should they be--other than the kernel, of course? If
this subject is treated extensively in a document,
perhaps somone could merely direct me to it.

I would recommend using CVS over ssh...

export CVSROOT=:ext:kyle at rufus:/home/cvsroot
export CVS_RSH=ssh

Then place your ssh public key in kyle at rufus:.ssh/authorized_keys and you're
set. 

-Rob Anderson

> installation that boots from a floppy, and loses the
> ssme. What's worse, this distro does not make a boot

> Is it possible to make a boot disk by copying
> individual files onto a floppy, and if so which ones

If one were to kindly provide information as to the name and version of
one's choice of distro, and some details on the boot medium used in this
particular instance, I suspect one might find help to be a bit more
forthcoming, as well as more accurately targeted to one's predicament.

> If this subject is treated extensively in a document,
> perhaps somone could merely direct me to it.

It likely is, in many lovingly-created documents that invariably are
only minimally applicible to one's particular situation.  And there's
one document buried in some mail archive with the exact fix.

All that said, I'm gonna guess you used a floppy with syslinux, the
kernel and a basic boot commandline (root=/dev/hdb1 or suchlike). AFAIK
syslinux can't just be copied, it has to be installed so the floppy
knows to boot from it.

Good luck,
  Aaron

From iconoklastic at yahoo.com  Tue Dec  2 11:56:01 2003
From: iconoklastic at yahoo.com (Robert Kopp)
Date: Tue Dec  2 11:56:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Emergency boot disk creation
In-Reply-To: <20031202192443.GA10616@bavariati.org>

--- Aaron Burt <aaron at speakeasy.org> wrote:

> > Is it possible to make a boot disk by copying
> > individual files onto a floppy, and if so which
> ones
> > should they be--other than the kernel, of course?
> 
> If one were to kindly provide information as to the
> name and version of
> one's choice of distro,  I suspect one might find
help
> to be a bit more
> forthcoming,

This is a toughie. It's Mandrake 9.1. It does not make
a boot disk during the installation, and if you try to
make one after booting into it, using a blank,
formatted floppy, it won't do it. The floppy already
has a filesystem, or something. Who ever heard of such
a thing? Why doesn't it just erase the disk?

That means that Mandrake put the boot loader into the
MBR, without asking anyone. Unfortunately, if you
dual-boot with Win XP, this is unacceptable. All you
have to do is to boot into XP with its CD and restore
the MBR, but Mandrake is not accessible. If I'm going
to use Mandrake 9.1, I probably need to make a boot
disk for it somehow.

Remember, I'm the dude with the Promise drive
controller. Neither Red Hat 8 nor 9 appears to work
with it properly, assigning drive device designations
such as hde and hdf. Not Mandrake: it's hda and hdb,
as it should be. Since Mandrake solves that problem,
I'm inclined to use it, if I don't have to install it
every time I want to use it.

Robert "Tim" Kopp
http://analytic.tripod.com/

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Tue Dec  2 12:41:01 2003
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: Tue Dec  2 12:41:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Emergency boot disk creation
In-Reply-To: <20031202185713.42054.qmail@web9606.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20031202185713.42054.qmail@web9606.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <863cc36jio.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Robert" == Robert Kopp <iconoklastic at yahoo.com> writes:

Robert> Surely you've heard this one before. One has a Linux
Robert> installation that boots from a floppy, and loses the
Robert> ssme. What's worse, this distro does not make a boot disk as
Robert> part of the installation routine.

Robert> Is it possible to make a boot disk by copying individual files
Robert> onto a floppy, and if so which ones should they be--other than
Robert> the kernel, of course? If this subject is treated extensively
Robert> in a document, perhaps somone could merely direct me to it.

If there is a working kernel on the HD, you should be able to boot
from a grub floppy and then boot that kernel from the interactive grub
command-line, with something like:

   root (hd0,0) 
   kernel /boot/vmlinuz-foo root=/dev/hda1
   boot

substituting the right devices and kernel filename.  Grub has device
and filename completion, so if you aren't sure what to type, hit tab
and you'll see your choices.  There are instruction for making grub
floppies online, so google is your friend there.  Basically, it is two
dd commands if you've got another working linux box.  I believe there
is a rawrite alternative if you are stuck with windows.  Ah, I found
this with a google on: grub floppy dd

  <http://www.uruk.org/orig-grub/install.html>

From ehem at m5p.com  Tue Dec  2 14:50:02 2003
From: ehem at m5p.com (Elliott Mitchell)
Date: Tue Dec  2 14:50:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Emergency boot disk creation
In-Reply-To: <20031202193402.26084.32881.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <200312022249.hB2MnFvR019137@m5p.com>

> From: Robert Kopp <iconoklastic at yahoo.com>
> Is it possible to make a boot disk by copying
> individual files onto a floppy, and if so which ones
> should they be--other than the kernel, of course? If
> this subject is treated extensively in a document,
> perhaps somone could merely direct me to it.

Doesn't like anyone has answered the first question correctly yet, so
naturally, "Yes".  :-)

Depends upon how functional you want the floppy to be. Absolute minimal
functionality, mainly the system loads the kernel and boots, can be
obtained with only the kernel.

fdformat /dev/fd0
cat /boot/vmlinuz > /dev/fd0

If this is a vanilla distribution kernel you may need to run `rdev` on it
first so it knows where to find the root filesystem. This doesn't load
any initial ramdisk, so it does have to have the basic drivers for your
hardware built in, but if you need it fast it does the job.

For a little more functionality, both syslinux and LILO can be placed on
floppies. For LILO:

mkfs /dev/fd0
mount /dev/fd0 /mnt/floppy
mkdir /mnt/floppy/boot /mnt/floppy/etc /mnt/floppy/dev
cp /boot/*.b /mnt/floppy/boot
cp /boot/vmlinuz /mnt/floppy/boot
cp /etc/lilo.conf /mnt/floppy/etc
mknod /mnt/floppy/dev/fd0 b 2 0
lilo -r /mnt/floppy -b /dev/fd0
umount /mnt/floppy

You might want/need to do further customization of lilo.conf, but for a
minimal installation this will work. If you're using an initial ram disk
you'll need to copy that on as well. This requires a Unix filesystem on
the floppy so LILO can talk to the device, though with some adjustment
you could work around that (hmm, might even be as easy as `mount /dev
/mnt/floppy/dev -o bind`, and then skip the `mknod`). Also note that you
can nuke floppy/dev and floppy/etc after running lilo.

On Tue, Dec 02, 2003 at 04:14:06PM -0800, Mark wrote:
> Colin Kuskie wrote:
> >I updated from RH9 to Fedora Core 1 last night, and everything went
> >great (except that they still haven't integrated the ethernet drivers
> >for the Dell Inspiron 1100 yet.)  The upgrade took about 1.5 hours.
> >
> >However, I quickly noticed that in vim (from the vim-enhanced package)
> >the built-in perl interpreter does not seem to work anymore.  Trying
> >a simple command like this:
> >
> >:1,$perldo 'tr/a-z/A-Z/;'
> 
> Try ":%perldo $_ = tr/a-z/A-Z/;"

% is the same as 1,$

tr/// uses $_ as the variable to operate on when no other variable is
specified.

To make tr/// use the $_ variable explicitly, you'd use the binding
operator '=~', not '='.  Using '=' makes tr/// return the number of
characters changed, not the changed variable.

Colin

  I think not...  I suspect mkisofs will want a directory structure to base
it's ISO image.  It would be possible to use tmpfs to create a scratch
directory to work from.  You can create a tmpfs filesystem with a simple
mount command.

mount tmpfs /mnt/tmpfs -t tmpfs

See:
http://www-106.ibm.com/developerworks/library/l-fs3.html

From pem at nellump.net  Tue Dec  2 18:40:02 2003
From: pem at nellump.net (Paul Mullen)
Date: Tue Dec  2 18:40:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Leaving the List - Firewire and Linux
In-Reply-To: <200312011124.02930.mark@linuxhardware.net>
References: <200312011124.02930.mark@linuxhardware.net>
Message-ID: <20031203023649.GA2133@nellump.net>

On Mon, Dec 01, 2003 at 11:24:02AM -0800, Mark Griskey wrote:
> 
> One this that I didn't get working, and partly because I ran out of time, was 
> my Lacie 80gig firewire hard disk. IT needs the SBP-2 module, which was 
> fussy.  I have reports that it does work, but I will have to wait to try it.

I have a WD 120 GB drive in an external FireWire enclosure, and don't
recall having had any real difficulties setting it up. Besides the 'sbp2'
module, you'll need (or at least I needed) 'raw1394' and 'ohci1394'
modules. Other than that, it pretty much just works. Since the drive is
accessed via SCSI emulation, it shows up as '/dev/sda'. One thing I've
noticed: the drive has to be powered up before 'sbp2' loads, or else it
won't get noticed (and consequently its partitions can't be mounted).


Paul

From aaron at speakeasy.org  Tue Dec  2 19:04:01 2003
From: aaron at speakeasy.org (Aaron Burt)
Date: Tue Dec  2 19:04:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Backing up to DVD?
In-Reply-To: <05AD3C7EEA42D311809300902785AC8A07FD4356@eft01ms01.eft.fiserv.net>
References: <05AD3C7EEA42D311809300902785AC8A07FD4356@eft01ms01.eft.fiserv.net>
Message-ID: <20031203030317.GA23449@bavariati.org>

On Tue, Dec 02, 2003 at 05:34:50PM -0800, Daggett, Steve wrote:
> Aaron Burt:
> > Hrm, there's gotta be a way to pipe output from tar through mkisofs to
> > cdrecord such that you get a tar.gz file on the CD.  Methinks 
> > I'll have to give it a try...
> 
>   I think not...  I suspect mkisofs will want a directory structure to base
> it's ISO image. 

Well, I tried -graft-points first.  It works with a real file, but not
with '-' as the source filename.  But -stream-media-size looks to be an
actual (if hackish) way to do this.  Problem is, it always names the
file STREAM.IMG, won't do multisession, needs to know the size in
advance and pads the CD/DVD out to that size.  So unless the maximum
size is known in advance, a 10MB backup will take the same space and
write-time as a 700MB one.

I guess it needs to know the size of the file when it writes the ISO9660
directory info.  Who'da thunk?

And with multi-volume backups, ya dang well better label the CDs.

Yup, looks like the resulting CD would be about as cryptic as one
created by piping tar directly to cdrecord.  Difference being that you
would have to mount it before reading the tarball.

I guess you better just have a compressed backup's worth of free space
somewhere if you want useful things like informative filenames or multi-
session backup CDs.  The tmpfs idea looks good if you have enough VM.

Sorry, my thinking process involves much blathering,
  Aaron <insert smiley>

>>Try ":%perldo $_ = tr/a-z/A-Z/;"
> 
> 
> % is the same as 1,$
> 
> tr/// uses $_ as the variable to operate on when no other variable is
> specified.
> 
> To make tr/// use the $_ variable explicitly, you'd use the binding
> operator '=~', not '='.  Using '=' makes tr/// return the number of
> characters changed, not the changed variable.

Yeah, I typoed out the '~', but otherwise did you try it?  It might get 
you around the "bug" at least for now.
I note the same behaviour with gvim 6.2.29 with my Gentoo system.
Doing ":%perldo $_ =~ tr/a-z/A-Z/" gets the correct behaviour
Though I'm seeing now that it's not the "$_ =~" that's the problem, it's 
your use of single quotes.
":%perldo tr/a-z/A-Z/" works as well.

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Tue Dec  2 20:50:02 2003
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Tue Dec  2 20:50:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Backing up to DVD?
In-Reply-To: <20031203020322.GB10874@maybe.net>
References: <2615.68.108.203.223.1070411524.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>
 <11250-98290@sneakemail.com> <20031203020322.GB10874@maybe.net>
Message-ID: <19431-01191@sneakemail.com>

On Tue, 2 Dec 2003, Chris Jantzen chris-plug-at-maybe.net |PDX Linux| wrote:

> On Tue, Dec 02, 2003 at 05:51:24PM -0800, Steve Bonds wrote:

> Why does everyone keep recommending dump?

"everyone" is probably mostly me.  ;-)

> It's very fs-specific and I seem to recall even ext2 maintainers
> deprecating it although I could be wrong.

It's not deprecated:

http://dump.sourceforge.net/isdumpdeprecated.html

> It seems a very fragile format to back up to.

I don't find dump fragile at all, particularly on Linux where the dump
source is readily available should I need to restore some antique CD-R 20
years from now.  Once you throw in compression, I feel that all backup
methods are pretty fragile.  This can be mitigated by using reliable media
and periodically checking the backups to see if they can be restored.

I use dump since I like the bashlike shell available in "restore -i".  It
also handles incrementals, compression, and multi-part archives easier (in
my opinion) than "tar".

W. Curtis Preston, author of the O'Reilly "UNIX Backup and Recovery" book
also recommends "dump" since it's easy to get backups done correctly with
it.  From his chapter on Native Backup and Recovery Utilities:

-----
This chapter describes the benefits and pitfalls of several utilities.
dump and restore are usually the best option if they are available. After
dump and restore, cpio has the best functionality, but it is slightly less
user friendly than its cousin tar. tar is incredibly easy to use and is
much more portable than either dump or cpio. If you have to back up raw
devices or perform remote backups with tar or cpio, dd will be your new
best friend.
-----

I never would have started using "dump" if it weren't for this book.  One
tour of a partial recovery with "restore -i" was enough for me to become a
dump believer, particularly after all the failed or partial "tar" restores
I'd done because of a misspelled or forgotten file.  Guess what?  You get
to read that whole tape all over again.  Grrr.

With "restore -i", I would just "cd" into the directory I wanted to
restore, pick the files I wanted, and go.  (Though I admit that I often
had problems restoring multi-part dumps until I started using the sleazy
"-a" flag on the restore.)

Other things I like about dump:
  + it's almost impossible to forget to include some of the
    files/directories on a filesystem
  + built-in gzip/bzip compression, and you can choose the multi-part file
    size after compression (-M -B)
  + strange files/devices/fifos/etc "just work"
  + really easy incrementals

Things I don't like about dump:
  + it's almost impossible to selectively exclude files/directories
  + on heavily written filesystems it's easier to get skipped or
    partially-backed up files than with tar/cpio. ("restore -C" will find
    this out for you)
  + it's really only useful for backups, whereas tar/cpio are useful for
    copying files, making archives, sending a file collection to someone,
    etc.

The most important thing is to DO the backups.  The method you use to get
there is far, far less important.  ;-)

  -- Steve

From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Tue Dec  2 21:56:02 2003
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Tue Dec  2 21:56:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] chat softwares
In-Reply-To: <FCEBIHDEIPOEEPHFOCFFAELHCKAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
References: <FCEBIHDEIPOEEPHFOCFFAELHCKAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
Message-ID: <1070430956.7027.26.camel@dell.linux.box>

On Tue, 2003-12-02 at 21:21, Billy Dimaculangan wrote:

> anyone who could help me on how to block through iptables the chat software
> and yahoo/msn messenger. sample configs or refence link would be greatly
> appreciated.

Figure out what ports they're using (there are many ways to do this, the
easiest probably being firing up GAIM and seeing what it connects to)
then block 'em on the PREROUTE table-

iptables -t nat -A PREROUTE -p tcp --dport 1863 -j DROP

... for example, should kill MSN messenger on its default port.  I'm
pretty sure it uses TCP, but you might block UDP, too, in case.  It
looks like YIM uses port 5050 by default.  You could block on the
destination IP address, too.. but in my experience, those kinds of
things change with time.

That is, of course, assuming you mean how to stop systems using a linux
box as the default gateway.

Rob

> cdrecord such that you get a tar.gz file on the CD.  Methinks I'll
> have to give it a try...

Using a another tool:

http://fy.chalmers.se/~appro/linux/DVD+RW/

If you wish to burn down output generated by an arbitrary program, you
can use:

dumpsomething | growisofs -Z /dev/scd0=/dev/fd/0 

Thank you
Russell

> On Tue, 2003-12-02 at 21:21, Billy Dimaculangan wrote:
>
> > anyone who could help me on how to block through iptables the
> chat software
> > and yahoo/msn messenger. sample configs or refence link would be greatly
> > appreciated.
>
> Figure out what ports they're using (there are many ways to do this, the
> easiest probably being firing up GAIM and seeing what it connects to)
> then block 'em on the PREROUTE table-
>
> iptables -t nat -A PREROUTE -p tcp --dport 1863 -j DROP
>
> ... for example, should kill MSN messenger on its default port.  I'm
> pretty sure it uses TCP, but you might block UDP, too, in case.  It
> looks like YIM uses port 5050 by default.  You could block on the
> destination IP address, too.. but in my experience, those kinds of
> things change with time.
>
> That is, of course, assuming you mean how to stop systems using a linux
> box as the default gateway.
>
> Rob
>

> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org

I agree, and I have many reasons for this opinion - most of which were

Thus, I want to see the mailing list(s) remain as they are for the time
being.  However, I have been thinking about ways to make the list(s)
work better and had some point I would like to make a few changes.
Hopefully these changes wouldn't change the nature of the lists - only
make them easier to use.

For example, I would like to set the lists up, so once you are registered
for one of them, you can post to any of the lists.  I also think we should
post a digest or at least a listing of topics for each list to the main
plug list on a daily basis.  My thinking is that these changes would
encourage people to use our topical lists instead of the main list for
more things.

> From: "Steve Bonds" <1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com>
> On Tue, 2 Dec 2003, Chris Jantzen chris-plug-at-maybe.net |PDX Linux| wrote:
> 
> > On Tue, Dec 02, 2003 at 05:51:24PM -0800, Steve Bonds wrote:
> 
> > Why does everyone keep recommending dump?
> 
> "everyone" is probably mostly me.  ;-)

You're not the only one.

> > It's very fs-specific and I seem to recall even ext2 maintainers
> > deprecating it although I could be wrong.
> 
> It's not deprecated:
> 
> http://dump.sourceforge.net/isdumpdeprecated.html

Ah, just the link I need to beat people over the head with when they
bring up the Linus message, thanks!  :-)

>   + strange files/devices/fifos/etc "just work"

This is the truely crucial thing. Things like extra filesystem
permissions and flags (extended ACLs, ext2's immutable and other flags,
etc), also incredibly long filenames. Notably dump will handle links and
holes in files absolutely perfectly, while even GNU tar you don't have a
guarentee.


> From: Chris Jantzen <chris-plug at maybe.net>
> On Tue, Dec 02, 2003 at 08:49:07PM -0800, Steve Bonds wrote:
> > Things I don't like about dump:
> >   + it's almost impossible to selectively exclude files/directories
> >   + on heavily written filesystems it's easier to get skipped or
> >     partially-backed up files than with tar/cpio. ("restore -C" will find
> >     this out for you)
> >   + it's really only useful for backups, whereas tar/cpio are useful for
> >     copying files, making archives, sending a file collection to someone,
> >     etc.
> 
>     * Isn't available for reiserfs. (My showstopper. ;-) Or JFS.=20
>       And XFS's dump is specific to XFS. This has always been my gripe.
>       What if I don't *want* to restore to the same filesystem format?

I and others have beaten on the ReiserFS folks telling them need dump,
they've kept to the excuse they need it to be explicitly sponsored, or
have one of their existing sponsors demand it before it will happen. For
the moment, this means I avoid ReiserFS.  :-(

Dump is filesystem specific, restore is dump *file* specific not
filesystem specific. You'll need a version of restore which handles the
dump file, but there is no need to restore to the same type of filesystem
the dump originated on.


> From: Chris Jantzen <chris-plug at maybe.net>
> On Tue, Dec 02, 2003 at 11:04:59PM -0800, Chris Jantzen wrote:
> > BTW-One way to get around the mentioned 'live fs' issue very, very
> > nicely is to use LVM and snapshot volumes. (Though be careful with md
> > devices as this can slow your system down a *lot*.)
> 
> =2E..which as I read further is mentioned...
> 
> But it bears mentioning: If you're running a "Linux server" you have
> almost no excuse not to be running LVM right now.

Disk space is not free, particularly if you're running on no budget (not
too much load, it is reliable, no need to upgrade). Also adds more
complexity, and more potencial for bugs...


Another real option for the journalling filesystems which can perform
data-journaling would be a "journal-only" option. Instead of doing
copy-on-write below the filesystem, simply tell the filesystem to only
write to memory and the journal. If the journal overflows the filesystem
has to start revert back to writing to the filesystem, but that condition
is easy to detect and with a very large journal not /all/ that likely.

>>>>> "Aaron" == Aaron Burt <aaron at speakeasy.org> writes:

Matt> Does anyone have recommendations on software for data backups to
Matt> DVD under Linux?

Aaron> mkisofs and cdrecord?  You can pipe one into the other.

Aaron> Hrm, there's gotta be a way to pipe output from tar through
Aaron> mkisofs to cdrecord such that you get a tar.gz file on the CD.

Why bother with mkisofs?  Why not just write the tar bitstream
instead?  Of course, you won't be able to mount it like an iso9660
image, but you ought to be able to read the tarball from the device.
GNU tar (which I assume you are using) even has a capacity limit
option that might let you do multiple volume backups.  Not that I've
tried it, but what does blank media cost these days?  Worth a try.

On Tue, 2 Dec 2003, Grish wrote:
> David Mandel wrote:
>  > For example, I would like to set the lists up, so once you are
>  > registered for one of them, you can post to any of the lists.  I also
>  > think we should post a digest or at least a listing of topics for
>  > each list to the main plug list on a daily basis.  My thinking is
>  > that these changes would encourage people to use our topical lists
>  > instead of the main list for more things.

These are good ideas, Dave.  I think it would easiest to just hack
together a little python to do this because you can inherit the existing
python functions from mailman to alter the list databases.  Is my thinking
correct here?  I'm not a python feller.

> If it's made an option that's off by default.

Huh?!?  He's talking about making it an option that's ON by default.

> There is a reason I subscribe to PLUG main and not any of the other
> PLUG-.*'s, and that's because I don't want to hear the crap they talk
> about on them.

You totally misunderstand, I think.  Dave is talking about making you able
to POST to those lists without subscribing to them separately... that way,
you can join those discussions whenever you like and redirect there when
necessary without going through the process of subscribing.  And in
addition to this, subject headers would be sent to PLUG in a daily summary
so that you can see if the discussions there are worth your time to
follow-up or not.

He's not suggesting that you get sent the mail from these lists without
explicitly asking for it.

Also:  Russell Senior and I had a discussion with Cooper Stevenson tonight
in Corvallis about his (Cooper's) ideas of what's wrong with PLUG and how
he would make it better.  He was eventually convinced that it would be
best to leave PLUG as it is and create a separate list that exists as a
moderated gateway to the general plug list.  He said he'd moderate it
himself and if it went unmoderated, so be it.  But basically, all posts to
and from the plug list would go to this moderated list and the moderator
would approve or deny them.  You could subscribe to this moderated list,
but your messages to the moderated list would also have to be approved or
denied by the moderator before forwarded on to the general plug list.

I personally think nobody in their right mind would take on that
moderator's job for free (mostly because of the time requirement), but I
think it answers his concerns nicely without impinging on our liberties at
all.

J.

David> seem to feel the list(s) should remain as they are -
David> UNMODERATED.

I went to the MWVLUG meeting in Corvallis this evening and afterwards
had a discussion of the list issues with several of those assembled.
Cooper Stevenson expressed an uneasiness about how the PLUG traffic
looks to newbies, that it might drive people away, which he didn't
want to happen.

Here's a wacky idea I had.

I made a suggestion to him for optional moderation.  That is, he
create his own mailing list that filters PLUG traffic.  Subscribers
send to (e.g.) plug-moderated and those messages get (either manually
or automatically) reposted to the main plug list, then the moderater
chooses which responses are helpful and not too scary or offensive
from plug back on to plug-moderated.

The nice thing about this arrangement is that plug remains
cooperatively anarchic as is without interruption, the folks who
thinks moderation is a good and useful idea get to offer a moderated
version and do the moderation work themselves.

In principle, subscribers could choose their own moderator:
plug-cooper-filtered, plug-michael-c-robinson-filtered, etc.

I am not sure that the software exists to do this directly, but it
doesn't look like a hard problem in principle.  One issue with mailman
would probably be the plug subscription limitation.  That is, mailman
wants list admin approval for posts from non-subscribers.  So
plug-moderated subscribers would need to be added to the approved
poster list somehow for it to work without manual intervention by the
plug list admin.

FWIW.

-- 
Russell Senior         ``I have nine fingers; you have ten.''
seniorr at aracnet.com

From chris-plug at maybe.net  Wed Dec  3 01:28:02 2003
From: chris-plug at maybe.net (Chris Jantzen)
Date: Wed Dec  3 01:28:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Backing up to DVD?
In-Reply-To: <200312030804.hB384R0Q024656@m5p.com>
References: <20031203070802.29517.69580.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org> <200312030804.hB384R0Q024656@m5p.com>
Message-ID: <20031203092656.GG10874@maybe.net>

On Wed, Dec 03, 2003 at 12:04:27AM -0800, Elliott Mitchell wrote:
> > On Tue, Dec 02, 2003 at 11:04:59PM -0800, Chris Jantzen wrote:
> > > BTW-One way to get around the mentioned 'live fs' issue very, very
> > > nicely is to use LVM and snapshot volumes. (Though be careful with md
> > > devices as this can slow your system down a *lot*.)
> > 
> > =2E..which as I read further is mentioned...
> > 
> > But it bears mentioning: If you're running a "Linux server" you have
> > almost no excuse not to be running LVM right now.
> 
> Disk space is not free, particularly if you're running on no budget (not
> too much load, it is reliable, no need to upgrade). Also adds more
> complexity, and more potencial for bugs...

Huh? Snapshots are copy-on-write. Perfect snapshot of filesystem state
at the given time without any additional disk usage. (Disk usage only
occurs as the filesystem is used.) No need to worry about "too much
load" *at all* on a live system. 

Plus LVM lets you expand and rearrange volumes live (of course, your
*filesystem*, not volume, will need to support expansion as well for it
to be actually useful--another reason I like reiserfs, it does this
instantly and without preperation, in a logged filesystem) and at will--
no reboot after fdisk. No need to tar-pipe or dump/restore your files
around new drive layouts: I just move the PE's for volumes I want on
new arrays or drives from the old drive to the new drive--it's live
and transparent.

Also, if your bootloader can load the initrd, then you never, ever need
to worry about what physical disk contains your system. LVM will
autodetect the devices that form the volume groups and let the system
boot from there. I've gone back and forth between md, ide, scsi, and
scsi raid without ever *touching* my /etc/fstab or kernel root
parameter.

Like I said, there is almost no reason "you" (i.e., in the general sense)
shouldn't be running LVM right now. Like backups are insurance against
failure, LVM is "insurance" against future configuration changes
("failure to think"? :).

-- 
chris kb7rnl =->

From jeme at brelin.net  Wed Dec  3 01:58:01 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Wed Dec  3 01:58:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] bash decimal interpretation
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0312030149340.32649@shaft.bitmine.net>

I have to write little bash loops all the time.  Usually, this is just to
handle bulk renames and things.  Fairly frequently, I have to deal with
this booger:

jbrelin at person:~/$ for a in `seq -w 1 10`;do b=$[$a+5];echo $a $b;done
01 6
02 7
03 8
04 9
05 10
06 11
07 12
bash: 08: value too great for base (error token is "08")

What's the deal with that crap?

OK, it makes perfect sense.  Bash is interpreting numbers that begin with
0 as octal... says so right in the man page.  But why in all of heaven
would it go ahead and do that when the number CAN'T be octal?!?

And I can't find a simple way to treat the number correctly.

Also, how am I supposed to pad that with 0s to get the right length again?
I mean, I could go ahead and do some garbage where I check the length and
add leading 0s until it gets up there, but that seems absurd and doesn't
help in the general case when you don't know what the greatest length is
going to be until you're at the end of the loop.

Grrr.

J.
-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------

 http://www.openlaw.org



From chris-plug at maybe.net  Wed Dec  3 02:08:02 2003
From: chris-plug at maybe.net (Chris Jantzen)

In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0312030149340.32649@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Wed, Dec 03, 2003 at 01:59:28AM -0800, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> 
> I have to write little bash loops all the time.  Usually, this is just to
> handle bulk renames and things.  Fairly frequently, I have to deal with

> 03 8
> 04 9
> 05 10
> 06 11

Try:

for a in `seq 1 10`;do b=$[$a+5];printf "%02d %02d\n" $a $b;done

(Std Disclaimer: printf is a bashism)

Kills two birds in one stone, perhaps. Note lack of "-w" argument,
particularly.

Well, you're issuing "seq 1 bar", so why not do:

export WIDTH=`echo -n $bar | wc -c`
for a in `seq 1 $bar`; do printf "%0${WIDTH}d\n" $a; done

Getting uglier by the minute, but it works.

From chris-plug at maybe.net  Wed Dec  3 04:10:02 2003
From: chris-plug at maybe.net (Chris Jantzen)
Date: Wed Dec  3 04:10:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] bash decimal interpretation
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0312030338550.32649@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0312030149340.32649@shaft.bitmine.net> <20031203100716.GL10874@maybe.net> <Pine.LNX.4.52.0312030237310.32649@shaft.bitmine.net> <20031203104726.GM10874@maybe.net> <Pine.LNX.4.52.0312030253280.32649@shaft.bitmine.net> <20031203112810.GN10874@maybe.net> <Pine.LNX.4.52.0312030338550.32649@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <20031203120930.GO10874@maybe.net>

On Wed, Dec 03, 2003 at 03:40:47AM -0800, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> 
> On Wed, 3 Dec 2003, Chris Jantzen wrote:
> > Well, you're issuing "seq 1 bar", so why not do:
> >
> > export WIDTH=`echo -n $bar | wc -c`
> > for a in `seq 1 $bar`; do printf "%0${WIDTH}d\n" $a; done
> >
> > Getting uglier by the minute, but it works.
> 
> Um, I'm really not trying to get you to do my work here... but I have one
> more problem to which I don't see the (surely) obvious answer.
> 
> Do I just backtick that to get it into a variable I can actually use?
> 
> b=`printf "%0${WIDTH}d" $a`
> 
> That's the best way?

AFAIK, sure.

I would point out that parenthesis command-substitution is faster and
more easily nestable and looks nicer. I haven't used it because I feared
you might confuse braced variable substitution. Additionally bracket
expressions are deprecated and will be removed soon. Double-paren
expressions replace them. So, from the top it might look like:

export WIDTH=$(echo -n $END|wc -c)
for a in $(seq 1 $END); do 
  b=$(printf "%0${WIDTH}d" $((a+5)))
  echo $b
done

Though I'm a bit pressed to see why you need to pretty print into a
variable other than to save on typing, maybe. Certainly it may start
getting treat as octal again. ;-)

Another nice approach:

WIDTH=$(echo -n $END|wc -c)
FORMAT="%0${WIDTH}d %0${WIDTH}d\n"
export FORMAT     # may not be necessary, depending

for a in $(seq 1 $END); do
  printf "$FORMAT" $a $((a+5))
done

-- 
chris kb7rnl =->

> Another nice approach:
> 
> WIDTH=$(echo -n $END|wc -c)
> FORMAT="%0${WIDTH}d %0${WIDTH}d\n"
> export FORMAT     # may not be necessary, depending
> 
> for a in $(seq 1 $END); do

I.e., remember you *can* do something like:

FORMAT="You want to change file %0${WIDTH}d to file %0${WIDTH}d\n"

and the result will be along the lines of

You want to change file 01 to file 06
You want to change file 02 to file 07
You want to change file 03 to file 08
You want to change file 04 to file 09
...

XFS+Samba is the only current method (of which I'm aware, anyway) to
have a Linux box serve up a network filesystem with full NT-ish ACLs,
then it's all you've got.

From Steve.Daggett at fiserv.com  Wed Dec  3 10:06:01 2003
From: Steve.Daggett at fiserv.com (Daggett, Steve)
Date: Wed Dec  3 10:06:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] OT:Intenet connection speed
Message-ID: <05AD3C7EEA42D311809300902785AC8A07FD4359@eft01ms01.eft.fiserv.net>

AthlonRob:
> 
> I thought a T1 line, by definition, was 1.54Mbps.

  Actually, to be pedantic about it, 1.544Mbps is the total line speed. The
actual usable bandwidth is commonly 1.536Mbps.  It's composed of 24 64Kbs
channels.  The extra 8Kb is an overhead bit used for framing and CRC.

  You can lose another 192Kb if the T1 channel is not 8 bit clean.  You get
24x56Kb channels instead of 24x64Kb.  The network steals one bit per 64Kb
channel to maintain 1's density on the T1.  It leaves you with 1.344Mbps T1
line.  

Steve D...

The way I have mine configured, I can hit ",L" (comma, capital 'L') to
reply to list. At the same time, I can hit ,r to go to the author only,
and ,g to go to both the author and the list. 

Check if this is in your ~/.muttrc:

   bind pager ,L   list-reply

and then, I have this:

lists plug plug-talk

I have other lists as well, but those are the two relevant ones. 

Also, I see this:

## This is new - and you should know about it:
  set ignore_list_reply_to  # ignore the "Reply-To" lines
                            # which point back to the mailing list -
                            # YES!

HTH

Okay, I *have* found how to configure the "list-reply" feature. But
you have to tell it in advance which addresses are mailing lists. And it
still honors Reply-To:  unless I set ignore_list_reply_to. There
is a patch for RFC 2369 support, but it's not there by default. I should
go look at it and see why it isn't in Debian.

Ultimately, all I want is a consistent, automatic way, no matter which
mailbox I'm in and no matter how badly mangled the mail is, for me to
be able to hit one key for "reply to everybody" and one key to "reply
only to the sender". From any mail client without having to futz with
options to no end. Is this too much to ask?

On Wed, Dec 03, 2003 at 10:14:27AM -0800, Russ Johnson wrote:
> The way I have mine configured, I can hit ",L" (comma, capital 'L') to
> reply to list. At the same time, I can hit ,r to go to the author only,
> and ,g to go to both the author and the list. 

Yeah, thanks to me reading the manual I discovered much of this. :-)

Reply-To: still subverts my desired effect for non-list traffic from
people that *do* use Reply-To: for it's originally intended purpose of
directing recipients to the senders real address (rather than trusting
From:)

Now that I have my client suitably configured to ignore fields the way I
prefer, I'll invariably spark the "Why Did You Cc: Me? I'm Subscribed To
the List" wars. Which will bring up the the "Mail-Followup-To: Isn't a
Real Standard" wars. Which still leads me to believe that Reply-To: is
the root of evil here. I don't see why such an option in your
subscription options can be *harmful*.

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Wed Dec  3 10:43:02 2003
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Wed Dec  3 10:43:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] DVD backups
Message-ID: <20031203184050.GB3056@gate.kl-ic.com>

As a devoted recent convert to rsync/dirvish backup, I could hijack
this thread (disk to disk backup is *SO* much faster, cheaper, easier).
But that would be rude ...

I am curious whether there are DVD-R changers out there.  Most systems
are much bigger than 4.7GB, and I've always found it painful to partition
data to match the backup medium (lots of wasted space, lots of fumbling
with tape M of N, etc.).  DVD-R drives run about $150-$250 without
changers;  the high cost of media and the labor-intensive changing of
disks would tempt one to forgo frequent backups. 

I back up 80GB every night (onto hard disks);  at 10MB/sec (8x DVD-R)
that would take 2+ hrs per day and 17+ media for a full dump, though
incrementals would be a lot cheaper.  Still, that sounds like $2K/yr
and an awful lot of time, along with the annoyingly cumbersome 
restore process incremental backups lead to.  

I understand Russell Senior will be telling us about using rsync for
backups at the December advanced topics (Russell, email me about this!)
and it might be worthwhile to learn about rsync and disk-to-disk before
committing to the expense and bother of alternatives.

Keith

Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

On Wed, 3 Dec 2003, Keith Lofstrom keithl-at-kl-ic.com |PDX Linux| wrote:

> As a devoted recent convert to rsync/dirvish backup, I could hijack this
> thread (disk to disk backup is *SO* much faster, cheaper, easier). But
> that would be rude ...

I don't think anyone would argue about the benefits of disk-to-disk
backups.  However, offline media has its place too.  If there were one
perfect solution for all applications the whole storage consulting
industry would collapse.  Not that this would be an entirely bad thing...
;-)

> I am curious whether there are DVD-R changers out there.  Most systems
> are much bigger than 4.7GB, and I've always found it painful to
> partition data to match the backup medium (lots of wasted space, lots of
> fumbling with tape M of N, etc.).  DVD-R drives run about $150-$250
> without changers;  the high cost of media and the labor-intensive
> changing of disks would tempt one to forgo frequent backups.

Try:

http://www.google.com/search?q=DVD-R+jukebox

Generally these are geared for the business archiving market and priced
accordingly.  ($8,000.00 or more)  If you're fretting the cost of media,
then these probably aren't a good choice.  ;-)

You'll also have the issue of compatibility with your backup server OS
and software since each jukebox uses its own proprietary command set for
moving media around.

> I understand Russell Senior will be telling us about using rsync for
> backups at the December advanced topics (Russell, email me about this!)
> and it might be worthwhile to learn about rsync and disk-to-disk before
> committing to the expense and bother of alternatives.

This might be a good warmup for the rsync talk:

http://www.mikerubel.org/computers/rsync_snapshots/

In this, Mike discusses how to use rsync and hard links to create some
really space-efficient incremental backups on disk.  Perfect for archiving
to DVD-R and putting away into that safe deposit box.  ;-)

  -- Steve

I just did a test.  If there's other traffic on the line, it subtracts
from the bandwidth the site shows.  So when I ran it with no other
network traffic, I got 2,414 kbps, but with a Mandrake ISO downloading
at ~1,500 kbps from limestone.uoregon.edu, I only got 889 kbps. (neener)

So it's all those other users denying you your preciousss bandwidth.

And, yes, there are such things as fractional T1s.  Use part for 'net,
part for interoffice, part for phone lines (with T1 you get ANI.)

I hope the title of this message isn't too confusing.

The use of an offboard drive controller (Promise
Ultra100 TX2) has raised difficulties with Linux that
have still not been resolved.

Giving Red Hat (8 & 9) the kernel parameter "linux
ide=reverse" does not seem to help. Perhaps the stock
kernel does not recognize it. In any case, I haven't
been able to install either of these releases at all.
Red Hat's technical support strikes me as quite
incompetent, so I'd rather not invoke it (as by the
purchase of a retail package for this purpose).

Mandrake comes pretty close: the drives turn up as hda
and hdb. Trouble is, the optical drives "disappear"
and I can't find out what happened to them. Perhaps
turning off recognition of the onboard controller, if
that's what Mandrake does, results in not dealing with
ATAPI devices on that controller properly, either.
(That's probably the kind of optical drives that most
people have.) I an not a heavy CD user. Could this
problem be circumvented by using a USB optical drive,
or by connecting the ATAPI drives to the add-on
controller? Mandrake's support is somewhat helpful. Of
course, they really want you to join the club. 

I ordered SuSE (OEM) from Ebay, and think I'll try
that, too. You can get it there for $10, and SuSE does
not offer downloadable iso's. Maybe they've got
everything under...control? If not, I may use a
procedure such as the one that seems to be necessary
with Mandrake.

From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Wed Dec  3 11:35:02 2003
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Wed Dec  3 11:35:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] chat softwares
In-Reply-To: <20031203120929.402a8b8a.jason@vancleve.com>
References: <FCEBIHDEIPOEEPHFOCFFAELHCKAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
	 <20031203120929.402a8b8a.jason@vancleve.com>
Message-ID: <1070480283.7024.124.camel@dell.linux.box>

On Wed, 2003-12-03 at 11:09, Jason Van Cleve wrote:

> Most iptables tutorials suggest you close all ports and open them as needed.  It's a better approach, and it should save you from chasing down unwanted traffic.

Your line wrapping is broken...

Most iptables tutorials suggest closing down all ports and opening them
as needed, yes... but they're usually talking about the INPUT
chain/table/whatever... so there is no chance you're listening on a port
you don't want to be listening on.

That is *not* the same thing as what Billy was looking for.  The
limitation mentioned above limits who can access you, not what you can
access.  Billy was looking (assuming he was talking about rules on a
gateway box) to limit what users of his network are able to access. 
Defaulting to DROP, IMHO, would cause a bit of a pain in the neck. 
You'd have to set rules for each individual port you wished users of
your network to have access to... and that list would get quite long
pretty quick.  

I think it would be just as easy to just set up a SOCKS proxy in that
case, and deal with that, disabling all forwarding altogether.  That
would give you more control, I think.

I don't think that's worth it for most networks, though, as it's a royal
pain in the ass for everybody involved.

Rob

On Wed, 2003-12-03 at 09:16, Michael Montagne wrote:
> A question about acceptable performance for a T1 line.  We just
> switched providers and I'm seeing less than pleasing performance on my
> connection speed.  Our line is 512kbps and I know that some drop is
> expected during peak hours but yesterday I measured from 60kbps to
> 227kbps during the work day then up to 453kbps at about 6:00 pm.  Are
> these numbers to be expected from a T1 line?
> 
You might want to consider setting up SNMP to give you real time stats
of your pipe, this will give you a much better indication of real
bandwidth usage.  Then to test through put, download a couple of ISO
images and watch the SNMP monitor.

HTH,

Derek Loree

On Wed, 2003-12-03 at 11:17, Aaron Burt wrote:
[snip]
> 
> And, yes, there are such things as fractional T1s.  Use part for 'net,
> part for interoffice, part for phone lines (with T1 you get ANI.)

It is also possible to order a partial T1 from your service provider.  I
used to work at a place that had a 384k partial T1.  It used the
frame-relay scheme that seemed to suck up bandwidth when you needed it
most (lots of lost packets, re-sends and time-outs).  Upgrading to a
full T1 with a Point-to-Point scheme made a huge difference.

Good Luck,

Derek Loree

On Wed, Dec 03, 2003 at 10:40:50AM -0800, Keith Lofstrom wrote:
> 
> As a devoted recent convert to rsync/dirvish backup, I could hijack
> this thread (disk to disk backup is *SO* much faster, cheaper, easier).
> But that would be rude ...
>

There's the PowerFile R200 series.  200 discs and 1-2 drives for
$2,500-$7,000 depending on configuration.  Yes, that's not quite a
terabyte of near-line storage for several times the cost of the
equivalent capacity in online IDE RAID. 

Heck, the radiotelescope guys just move data around by FedExing a Linux
box that's stuffed with big IDE discs.  Just plug it into power and GigE
and you're ready to go.

Note that there *are* reasons (mostly legal and administrative) to have
optical changers, and the R200 is a bargain compared to other solutions.  

> DVD-R drives run about $150-$250 without changers;  the high cost of
> media and the labor-intensive changing of disks would tempt one to
> forgo frequent backups. 

Ayup, that's the case if you want to backup data on media that's too
small for the job.  Removable discs must always trail fixed ones
(because of mechanical factors and a rougher environment), and tape
seems to be approaching its limits (because of the limits of flexible
media, or maybe just insufficient R&D).

Note that IOMega's latest high-capacity medium (Rev) is essentially a
stripped-down 35GB laptop hard-drive.  

> I back up 80GB every night (onto hard disks);  at 10MB/sec (8x DVD-R)
> that would take 2+ hrs per day and 17+ media for a full dump, though
> incrementals would be a lot cheaper.  Still, that sounds like $2K/yr
> and an awful lot of time, along with the annoyingly cumbersome 
> restore process incremental backups lead to.  

Incrementals aren't so bad if you make them relative to the last full
backup.  It's stacked incrementals that *really* suck.

> I understand Russell Senior will be telling us about using rsync for
> backups at the December advanced topics (Russell, email me about this!)
> and it might be worthwhile to learn about rsync and disk-to-disk before
> committing to the expense and bother of alternatives.

Indeed.  It's all about choices and flexibility, innit?

-- 
If hard data were the filtering criterion you could fit the entire
contents of the Internet on a floppy disk. 
  -- Cecil Adams

reading message you decide you want to reply, press 'r'
mutt prompts "Reply to plug at lists.pdxlinux.org? ([yes]/no): ", press 'n'

and go about your messaging.

From ehem at m5p.com  Wed Dec  3 14:16:07 2003
From: ehem at m5p.com (Elliott Mitchell)
Date: Wed Dec  3 14:16:07 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Backing up to DVD?
In-Reply-To: <20031203183004.18436.49385.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <200312032215.hB3MFKfu032075@m5p.com>

> From: Chris Jantzen <chris-plug at maybe.net>
> On Wed, Dec 03, 2003 at 05:35:16AM -0800, Paul Heinlein wrote:
> > On Tue, 2 Dec 2003, Chris Jantzen wrote:
> > >     * Isn't available for reiserfs. (My showstopper. ;-) Or JFS.
> > >       And XFS's dump is specific to XFS.
> >=20
> > The thing about XFS's dump is that it lets you archive the ACLs. Since
> > XFS+Samba is the only current method (of which I'm aware, anyway) to
> > have a Linux box serve up a network filesystem with full NT-ish ACLs,
> > then it's all you've got.
> 
> The only "modern" FS. ext2 does this, too, but it has none of the
> features we all seem to be looking for. :-) Plus I don't *think* you can
> back up ACL's easily. But I haven't tried, so don't take my word for it.

Many flavors of dump allow you to exclude files. None that I know of have
the ability to exclude ACLs or permissions from dumps. You don't need to
tell dump to backup ACLs, you get them and any other filesystem-specific
extras archived no matter what.

On Wed, 2003-12-03 at 13:40, Jason Van Cleve wrote:
> Quoth AthlonRob, on Wed, 03 Dec 2003 11:38:03 -0800:
> 
> > Your line wrapping is broken...
> 
> Or unbroken, as it were.  Doesn't your client autowrap long lines?

Indeed it does most of the time.  However, it has to guess if I want the
line to be broken up or not.  For example, I don't want commandlines,
URLs, Message IDs, or things of a technical nature broken up.  Regular
paragraphs that are just broken on a single line - no, I'm ok with those
being broken up.

When quoting a message, Evolution assumes we'll break the lines
ourselves if the one we're responding to didn't want to break any lines,
so we we don't end up with funky quotes of quotes or break quoted URLs
and the like.

It just makes things easier for all involved if we email line-wrapped
posts, doesn't it?

Rob
