On Wed, Dec 03, 2003 at 09:59:52AM -0800, Chris Jantzen wrote:
> I would honestly appreciate it if you could point me to how I can
> configure Mutt to handle the presence of Reply-To: or not in one unified
> manner of my choosing. (And why doesn't it out of the box, being the
> "hacker's choice MUA".)

Don't worry about Reply and Reply All behavior, look up how to use
reply-to-list.  Long story short, if you add lines like this one to
your ~/.muttrc, all you have to do after that is hit L to reply to
list.

subscribe plug at lists.pdxlinux.org

You can specify as many mailing list addresses as you like per
subscribe line, and as many subscribe lines as you want.

Other MUA's that aren't still in the stone age in this regard are
kmail and sylpheed-claws off the top of my head, but I know there's
many more.

From creswick at cs.orst.edu  Wed Dec  3 18:12:01 2003
From: creswick at cs.orst.edu (Rogan Creswick)
Date: Wed Dec  3 18:12:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] 2-way exchanges with ssh and scp
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0312031726050.14220@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0312031726050.14220@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <20031204021132.GB3979@sapphire.CS.ORST.EDU>

On Wed, Dec 03, 2003 at 05:29:11PM -0800, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   I can use scp to copy files from my main workstation/server to the
> laptops, but not the other direction.
> 
>   From the laptop, when I try 'scp salmo:<filename> .' I see:
> ssh_exchange_identification: Connection closed by remote host.
> 

It looks like this is most often caused by an overly strict
/etc/hosts.deny

I am a bit confuse, you can copy from your workstation to your laptop,
or you can copy from the laptop to the server?

"scp salmo:<filename> ."

will copy <filename> from salmo to the local box (even if salmo is the
local box), so I'm assuming the server is salmo---although that might
be part of your problem, a confounded command line.  I'll call the
laptop "laptop".

Also note that you can use scp to copy to a remote host, or from a
remote host, which is different from invoking scp from one host, or
invoking it from another host.

>   So, do I need to make changes to /etc/ssh/ssh_config or
> /etc/ssh/sshd_config? And, on which machine? I've managed to get myself
> quite confused here at what needs to be set where for 2-way communications.


You probably need to change /etc/ssh/sshd_config on salmo.

This trick to reverse-ssh should also work (posted on here a while back):


# on salmo do this:
ssh -f -N laptop -R22000:localhost:22

#now, on laptop you can do this:

scp -p 22000 localhost:<filename> .

which will copy the file from _salmo_ to the laptop (despite the
localhost in the command line---the first command sets up a tunnel
from laptop:22000 to salmo:22).


-Rogan

From chris-plug at maybe.net  Wed Dec  3 18:46:01 2003
From: chris-plug at maybe.net (Chris Jantzen)
Date: Wed Dec  3 18:46:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] OT: standards and design
Message-ID: <20031204024510.GA30462@maybe.net>

Re: the "if we followed your suggestion technology would never advance"

Yes it would. I'm arguing that orthogonal standards design is critical.
Should KDC's really be required to learn about Win2K ACL's in order to
continue doing their job of "managing passwords" (to put it simply)? Was
it a good idea to add <FONT> tags and sundry to let what was meant to be
a document structure language be abused as a document presentation
standard? Should "ls" know how to mount nfs volumes (hypothetically)?

We can design *standards* to be orthogonal (no strong cross-dependencies,
no whole sort of general mish-mash, no strong overlap of purposes) and let
*solutions* cross-integrate them. The operating system can talk to an
authorization and an authentication server seperately, but the servers
in question don't need to do each others' jobs. Maybe this argues that
I'm wrong -- many MUA's deal with mixed HTML/HTTP and RFC822 with flair.
I just think it's wrong for an RFC to an existing standard to draw on a 
"foreign" data format. I suppose at some point it comes down to taste,
after all that's the great thing about standards -- there's so many to
choose from!

This is waaayyy off-topic for the technical list, and I recommend
further commentary be taken to plug-talk, which I don't subscribe to --
feel free to Cc: me, if you want. (Normally, anything approaching what
I'd think would be plug-talk otherwise, I ignore the whole thread. So, I
doubt I'd *want* to subscribe to plug-talk. 8-D) I won't say any more,
cross my heart.

-- 
chris kb7rnl =->

From ehem at m5p.com  Wed Dec  3 19:34:02 2003
From: ehem at m5p.com (Elliott Mitchell)
Date: Wed Dec  3 19:34:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Backing up to DVD?
In-Reply-To: <20031204015934.GG32680@maybe.net>
Message-ID: <200312040333.hB43XHNA035261@m5p.com>

> From: Chris Jantzen <chris-plug at maybe.net>
> On Wed, Dec 03, 2003 at 02:15:20PM -0800, Elliott Mitchell wrote:
> > > The only "modern" FS. ext2 does this, too, but it has none of the
> > > features we all seem to be looking for. :-) Plus I don't *think* you can
> > > back up ACL's easily. But I haven't tried, so don't take my word for it.
> > 
> > Many flavors of dump allow you to exclude files. None that I know of have
> > the ability to exclude ACLs or permissions from dumps. You don't need to
> > tell dump to backup ACLs, you get them and any other filesystem-specific
> > extras archived no matter what.
> 
> How can you say this *and* say that restore isn't fs-specific (prior
> msg)? What if I archive an ext2 system with ACL and restore to XFS with
> totally different ACL structures? Or what if I restore sensitive data,
> unwittingly, to a filesystem that doesn't support ACL's at all and the
> file is readable by the wrong people?

The power of having a consistant ACL changing interface, unfortunatly of
course we don't have one.  :-(  So you'll only restore the FS specific
stuff if the API and features match. I haven't played with ACLs much, but
the recommended action is to use ACLs to add access, not remove it,
specifically for cases like this (the other one being fsck saving the
file, but not the ACL).

I agree with Jantzen.  Email clients should be text browsers, not HTML
browsers.  Web browsers should not be email clients and IRC clients and
News clients and WYSIWYG HTML editors.  And operating systems should not
be Web servers and media players and messaging services that are active
by default.  Modularity means the best of breed--rather than the
biggest--can prevail.

Just my opinion.

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Wed Dec  3 22:15:03 2003
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Wed Dec  3 22:15:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Backing up to DVD?
In-Reply-To: <20031204015934.GG32680@maybe.net>
References: <20031203183004.18436.49385.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
 <200312032215.hB3MFKfu032075@m5p.com> <20031204015934.GG32680@maybe.net>
Message-ID: <24007-04094@sneakemail.com>

On Wed, 3 Dec 2003, Chris Jantzen chris-plug-at-maybe.net |PDX Linux| wrote:

> > Many flavors of dump allow you to exclude files. None that I know of
> > have the ability to exclude ACLs or permissions from dumps. You don't
> > need to tell dump to backup ACLs, you get them and any other
> > filesystem-specific extras archived no matter what.
>
> How can you say this *and* say that restore isn't fs-specific (prior
> msg)? What if I archive an ext2 system with ACL and restore to XFS with
> totally different ACL structures? Or what if I restore sensitive data,
> unwittingly, to a filesystem that doesn't support ACL's at all and the
> file is readable by the wrong people?

This is why ACLs will continue to suck until we get a unified and
consistent standard.  ;-)  Since UNIX treats everything as a stream of
bytes and ACLs lie outside that stream, unless each and every program
supports the particular ACL implementation for the filesystem in use
something as simple as making a copy or compressing a file will destroy
the ACLs.

If using ACLs it's important to be fail-safe so that if the ACLs are
removed, less access is given rather than more.

The dump/restore in use on Linux doesn't support ACLs, though it *is* kind
enough to warn you if it detects that you have them on a particular inode.

  -- Steve

From russell-evans at qwest.net  Thu Dec  4 08:16:01 2003
From: russell-evans at qwest.net (Russell Evans)
Date: Thu Dec  4 08:16:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] OT:Intenet connection speed
In-Reply-To: <20031203174240.GA3550@themontagnes.com>
References: <20031203171601.GA3013@themontagnes.com>
	<1070473025.7030.93.camel@dell.linux.box>
	<20031203174240.GA3550@themontagnes.com>
Message-ID: <20031204081748.60571bca.russell-evans@qwest.net>

On Wed, 3 Dec 2003 09:42:40 -0800
"Michael Montagne" <michael at themontagnes.com> wrote:

> I'm using this site:
> http://webservices.cnet.com/bandwidth
> 
> >On 12/03/03, AthlonRob busted out the keyboard and typed:

> > 
> > How are you measuring that speed?


Try bing http://www.cnam.fr/reseau/bing.html

Bing will allow you to measure bandwidth by hop. Pick a host, do a
traceroute to it , and then use bing on the hops along the way. I like
to use large and small packets.

bing -s 64 -S 1024 localhost gateway
bing -s 64 -S 1024 localhost nexthop
...

This will help you understand where bandwidth issues really are. No
point beating up your ISP if the issue is upstream from them or in your
own network.

Thank you
Russell.



From srau at rauhaus.org  Thu Dec  4 09:10:02 2003

Message-ID: <20031204170859.GA7006@rauhaus.org>

* Russell Evans <russell-evans at qwest.net> [031204 08:16]:
> 
> Try bing http://www.cnam.fr/reseau/bing.html
> 
> Bing will allow you to measure bandwidth by hop. Pick a host, do a
> traceroute to it , and then use bing on the hops along the way. I like
> to use large and small packets.
> 
> bing -s 64 -S 1024 localhost gateway
> bing -s 64 -S 1024 localhost nexthop

I'm not familiar with what bing does, but remember when using a tool
like bing or mtr or even traceroute, that responding back with the icmp
ttl expired messages for traceroute or icmp echo replies for pings is
about last on the list of priorities for a router. You may get what look
like slow hops in the middle when your end to end latency is still fine.

--Stafford

From chris at maybe.net  Thu Dec  4 13:07:01 2003
From: chris at maybe.net (Chris Jantzen)
Date: Thu Dec  4 13:07:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Backing up to DVD?
In-Reply-To: <200312032334.hB3NYDl7032852@m5p.com>
References: <20031203121002.31104.25658.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org> <200312032334.hB3NYDl7032852@m5p.com>
Message-ID: <20031204011908.GF32680@maybe.net>

First off, sorry about the tight space/hardware thing. I know how it feels.

On Wed, Dec 03, 2003 at 03:34:13PM -0800, Elliott Mitchell wrote:
> > Plus LVM lets you expand and rearrange volumes live (of course, your
> > *filesystem*, not volume, will need to support expansion as well for it
> > to be actually useful--another reason I like reiserfs, it does this
> > instantly and without preperation, in a logged filesystem) and at will--
> > no reboot after fdisk. No need to tar-pipe or dump/restore your files
> > around new drive layouts: I just move the PE's for volumes I want on
> > new arrays or drives from the old drive to the new drive--it's live
> > and transparent.
> 
> Two issues, first is that reliability one. More complexity, more chances
> for data-corrupting bugs. Also the need for more hardware because more
> complexity generally means slower.

I've never had any issue with Linux LVM except earlier versions stalling
the system excessively during a volume move on a heavily loaded live
server. Additionally, EVMS is ported from use in AIX on zSeries mainframes,
et. al. I, personally, first ran into LVM on an HP-UX mini I assisted in
running ... hmmm ... thinks ... 11 years ago? The concept is well-tested
and a core part of "enterprise".

Implementation bugs are just as bad as any other bug, really. Early 2.5
had IDE data corruption bugs. Versions of ext3 have had corruption bugs
(I lost the journal on my laptop, for example). Potential LVM bugs aren't
any more "special".  You always want to play it safe when upgrading your
kernel or doing any kind of major build. And see if new techniques or
methods you're looking into adopting are robust in design and concept.

> Second, perhaps I should do more research on the issue, but my last read
> of LVM had indicated you didn't get control over where volumes physically
> resided. You gave it instructions, but you only had logical control, not
> physical.

You can pvmove extents to any device you want. You can even initially
create volumes specifically on any physical device of your choosing.

> > Also, if your bootloader can load the initrd, then you never, ever need
> > to worry about what physical disk contains your system. LVM will
> > autodetect the devices that form the volume groups and let the system
> > boot from there. I've gone back and forth between md, ide, scsi, and
> > scsi raid without ever *touching* my /etc/fstab or kernel root
> > parameter.
> 
> I build custom kernels, so I don't worry about initial ramdisks (on the
> one machine I don't worry about modules either, deliberatly static
> kernel).

No, you need userspace tools to detect and activate the volumes because
the kernel doesn't have the bloat to walk the disk structures to autodetect
the major/minors for the volume block devices. This scenario will become
the norm, more than the exception for many subsystems with 2.6. (Although
2.6 makes initrd's even more transparent.)

> Which leaves the sole concern being loading the kernel. Even
> LILO can load from beyond the olde limit, so I guess that is no longer a
> concern. 

Well, yes, I do have a fixed, tiny /boot partition. :-)

> You don't need LVM though to remove the need to modify fstab,
> you could mount filesystems by label for a long time (long time in this
> case meaning even Debian stable can do it).

/me investigates.

Ah. Didn't know that had gone beyond "just ext2". (I think the last time
I looked at that must've been around RH6.2) Still, mounting /dev/vg0/root
instead of the Linux-specific label syntax "feels" more portable to me
across UNIXen. To me.

> > Like I said, there is almost no reason "you" (i.e., in the general sense)
> > shouldn't be running LVM right now. Like backups are insurance against
> > failure, LVM is "insurance" against future configuration changes
> > ("failure to think"? :).
> 
> Then again so is good planning, and experience. I know what I'm doing so
> I don't yet need LVM (or EVMS). Still you're likely correct, good for
> people who don't know.

I'm just pointing to the "yet". Better to start now and have it at your
fingertips when "yet" comes, than try to revamp everything. Kind of like
backups: you aren't *planning* to have a system failure, but it's a
possibility, so it's good to have your options open. Although one could
say, I'm just encouraging better planning in this regard, now that I
look at it. :-)

Maybe my sense of perspective is warped: building large storage servers,
using NetApps, etc where having an LVM is like air and water to me. :-)
I still maintain that you should start with one as your initial install
as long as you're doing anything more complex than "firewall", "web
appliance", or "email pop toaster". Although I admit your language of
"reduce complexity" does sound like you tend towards this field.

-- 
chris kb7rnl =->

> run Mozilla xhosted so that it displays on my work machine.  Is there
> any way to get the existing Mozilla to display at work, or do I need to
> start a new one?

Disclaimer: the info below isn't going to be very useful, since I
can't recall the app. name at the moment.

There exists a program that emulates an X server, and will pipe the
I/O from applications attached to that X server to some other X server
that can be changed dynamically.  Basically it acts like "screen" for
graphical apps, allowing you to do what you describe.

Unfortunately, I can't remember what it's called.  Perhaps knowing it
does exist will trigger someone's memory, or I may find it again (I'm
trying to dig it up again).

From zot at whiteknighthackers.com  Thu Dec  4 14:52:01 2003
From: zot at whiteknighthackers.com (Zot O'Connor)
Date: Thu Dec  4 14:52:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] trying to determine corrupted .files
Message-ID: <1070578226.6399.64.camel@kat.zotnet.com>

I have a partially recovered system where many of the .files are
corrupted.

I am trying to determine a way to determine which of the . files are
corrupted, but this appears to not be trivial.  The criteria I would
love is:

1)  Known text file only.
2)  Has binary information in it.

An example:
.gnupg/options
         To enable full OpenPGP compliance you ^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@
        ...
        @ou should make sure that you have read t
        # Options for GnuPG
        # Copyright 1998, 1999, 2000, 2001 Free Software Foundation, Inc.

Some of the files can be cleaned, like the above file, some need to be
re-recovered.  The re-recovery process is not trivial so I want to
minimize the effort.

so the technique I am heading towards is something along these lines:

        find USER/\.[a-zA-Z]* -type f -exec ...

The the exec part is getting tricky but I did determine that a
moderately useful test is:

         file -k .gnupg/options
        .gnupg/options: data
        
        strings -n 40 .gnupg/options | wc -l
             28

This looks for strings greater than 40 chars long, and tells me how many
I will find.  I am then thinking of comparing file's output to wc's
output and seeing if wc > X and file says binary, then attempting a
recovery.

But before I mess too much.....  Any see an easier way to do this?

Thanks!

Zot O'Connor

http://www.WhiteKnightHackers.com

  Without going into details I hosed my new laptop this morning in a period

address 216.99.206.23 to salmo rather than the non-routable address. Where

From heinlein at madboa.com  Thu Dec  4 15:52:01 2003
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Thu Dec  4 15:52:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] ssh picking up the incorrect IP address
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0312041527280.23903@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0312041527280.23903@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0312041549300.2982@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Thu, 4 Dec 2003, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   However, whenever I try to use ssh or scp (to move necessary
> applications from another box on the network), the tool tries to
> connect to my external IP address, not the internal network address.
> Of course, it keeps failing.

Didn't you used to push an /etc/hosts file around your network that
contained all your local hostnames and addresses?

Also, make sure that your system looks to files before DNS for name
resolution. You'll want to see a line like this in /etc/nsswitch.conf:

hosts:  files dns

(There may be other stuff after 'dns'; that's ok.)

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

216.99.206.23 is the address returned by DNS for the name
salmo.appl-ecosys.com. If you want this to be different
locally, you can add an entry to your /etc/hosts file.
Perhaps this is how you had it configured in the past.

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Thu Dec  4 15:56:08 2003
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Thu Dec  4 15:56:08 2003
Subject: [PLUG] running two copies of mozilla
Message-ID: <20031204235443.GB15310@gate.kl-ic.com>

I diddled my .../mozilla/run-mozilla.sh file using the instructions at
http://sxs.sourceforge.net/sxs/index2.html .  Select "Internet Browsing"
and the essay "Running Multiple Instances of Mozilla".  Note that the
provided patch is too old to apply to the modern  run-mozilla.sh  file,
you will have to do some hand mods.  The reference in the essay to
"-remote openURL(%u,new-window)"   bears investigation.

In any case, the mod allows me to run multiple mozilla instances with
the same profile.  I can't attest to it's reliability;  I have seen
mozilla lock up under various circumstances, but then I have seen that
before and after the mod, so it is hard to say how much trouble the
mod causes.  

In general, the sxs site has some handy tricks, and is worth perusing.

Keith

From kgmorse at mpcu.com  Thu Dec  4 16:23:02 2003
From: kgmorse at mpcu.com (Keith Morse)

Subject: [PLUG] Re: Backing up to DVD?
In-Reply-To: <20031203092656.GG10874@maybe.net>

 <200312030804.hB384R0Q024656@m5p.com> <20031203092656.GG10874@maybe.net>

I gotta start reading the whole thread before I post.

On Wed, 3 Dec 2003, Chris Jantzen wrote:

> On Wed, Dec 03, 2003 at 12:04:27AM -0800, Elliott Mitchell wrote:
> > > On Tue, Dec 02, 2003 at 11:04:59PM -0800, Chris Jantzen wrote:
> > > > BTW-One way to get around the mentioned 'live fs' issue very, very
> > > > nicely is to use LVM and snapshot volumes. (Though be careful with md
> > > > devices as this can slow your system down a *lot*.)
> > > 
> > > =2E..which as I read further is mentioned...
> > > 
> > > But it bears mentioning: If you're running a "Linux server" you have
> > > almost no excuse not to be running LVM right now.
> > 
> > Disk space is not free, particularly if you're running on no budget (not
> > too much load, it is reliable, no need to upgrade). Also adds more
> > complexity, and more potencial for bugs...
> 
> Huh? Snapshots are copy-on-write. Perfect snapshot of filesystem state
> at the given time without any additional disk usage. (Disk usage only
> occurs as the filesystem is used.) No need to worry about "too much
> load" *at all* on a live system. 
> 
> Plus LVM lets you expand and rearrange volumes live (of course, your
> *filesystem*, not volume, will need to support expansion as well for it
> to be actually useful--another reason I like reiserfs, it does this
> instantly and without preperation, in a logged filesystem) and at will--
> no reboot after fdisk. No need to tar-pipe or dump/restore your files
> around new drive layouts: I just move the PE's for volumes I want on
> new arrays or drives from the old drive to the new drive--it's live
> and transparent.
> 
> Also, if your bootloader can load the initrd, then you never, ever need
> to worry about what physical disk contains your system. LVM will
> autodetect the devices that form the volume groups and let the system
> boot from there. I've gone back and forth between md, ide, scsi, and
> scsi raid without ever *touching* my /etc/fstab or kernel root
> parameter.
> 
> Like I said, there is almost no reason "you" (i.e., in the general sense)
> shouldn't be running LVM right now. Like backups are insurance against
> failure, LVM is "insurance" against future configuration changes
> ("failure to think"? :).
> 
>

> > How can you say this *and* say that restore isn't fs-specific (prior
> > msg)? What if I archive an ext2 system with ACL and restore to XFS with
> > totally different ACL structures? Or what if I restore sensitive data,
> > unwittingly, to a filesystem that doesn't support ACL's at all and the
> > file is readable by the wrong people?
> 
> This is why ACLs will continue to suck until we get a unified and
> consistent standard.  ;-)  Since UNIX treats everything as a stream of
> bytes and ACLs lie outside that stream, unless each and every program
> supports the particular ACL implementation for the filesystem in use
> something as simple as making a copy or compressing a file will destroy
> the ACLs.
> 
> If using ACLs it's important to be fail-safe so that if the ACLs are
> removed, less access is given rather than more.
> 
> The dump/restore in use on Linux doesn't support ACLs, though it *is* kind
> enough to warn you if it detects that you have them on a particular inode.

Another issue in backing up to DVDs is that most DVD file systems do not
deal well with file names with weird characters (such as umlauts) or
long filenames.  (Some have problems at 32 characters, some go to 64.)

The only way to get around it is to tar the file system first, and that
has other issues.

        ? The owner of Landmark Theatres is not concerned about piracy
        in movie theaters.

I've used Imation CD-R media for years with excellent results.  I
especially liked the thick plastic coating on the back protecting the
fragile foil.

Lately, though, I've been disappointed.  The thick plastic coating now
only covers "most" of the back, with huge sections spelling "Imation" left
uncoated.  I've also noticed an unacceptably high level of "grown defects"
that only appear after a few weeks of abuse.

I've recently seen Imation's "Business Select" media.  It costs more, but
I'm hopeful that it might be more durable.  Has anyone used this?

unexpected host 66.190.251.135 it because that host is pinging you. you

sniffer tool. netstat -s | grep "ICMP messages received" might give you
some idea also.

From root at loraksus.org  Thu Dec  4 21:44:02 2003
From: root at loraksus.org (Karol Kulaga)
Date: Thu Dec  4 21:44:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Who makes good media?
In-Reply-To: <3FCFDFB4.9070706@pacifier.com>
Message-ID: <E1AS8kD-00027L-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

You know, for CDs, it is so hard to tell these days, the manufacturers
are making the blanks for a very low amount of profit and nobody cares
about quality control. Name brand isn't a guarantee of quality, far
from it, but the 100 packs of "no name free after 1 rebate packaged
without a spindle and wrapped in crappy plastic" cds are pretty much
going to be made by some child worker in a roach infested factory in
Calcutta.
It's also hard to say brand X is good quality, because companies tend
to get break into the market with cheap, good cdrs, and then 6 or so
months down the line, once they have a "good name", jack up their
prices another 20% and switch to a manufacturer that makes crappy cds.


TDK used to be reliable, then I bought 4 spindles and they were all a
bad batch (i.e. error in the exact same position on all of the cds),
and TDK refused to take them back. Needless to say, I don't buy them
any more after my experience with their support staff. They used to be
_really_good_ but that was when 16x cdrs were the top of the line.

Maxell is utter crap 99% of the time; I've gotten sealed spindles with
"stuff" between the cds and peeling top coats. I was less than
impressed.

Memorex is umm, iffy, but their black cdrs aren't bad.
Actually I haven't had many black cdrs go bad. Coincidence?

Imation isn't bad, I really haven't had many trouble with that brand,
probably the best in the last 3-4 months.

Fujifilm made some surprisingly good ones, (really colorful ones)
although I don't see them for sale anymore. Burned nicely and very low
incidence of errors too.

The best ideas are to burn at half the rated speed and verify after
burning that there are no crc errors or other happy errors. Or just
buy a hard drive, the prices for quality media are about the same as a
hard drive on special. 120 gb drives are ~75 now if you get a deal. .

Customer support for all the manufacturers is terrible, and downright
arrogant in some places. I don't think anybody follows their
"warranty" of replacing defective media, but a spindle of cdrs being
shot by a .22 does make a very nice and colorful, albeit short lived
fountain of CD shards (you so want to stay a bit back, however -
shards are thrown a good 20 feet if you get the angle just right. ).
Probably more satisfying than having _____ mail you some blanks. AOL
cd showers are also fun. But enough about senseless gun violence.

Crap cdrs are always good for burning vcds. Also rather good
projectile weapons (i.e. hold 1 hand in front of eyes, bend cd in half
with other hand so that it bends inside your hand).
I digress. (yet again. . .)

As for dvd-r's, I'd hate to say it, but the compusa ones aren't that
bad, which is pretty remarkable considering the top coat of their name
brand CD's dissolved in water (well, a couple years ago they did).
I've burned about 50 and haven't had any fail on me yet, although it
has only been about 4 months. I'm paranoid and burn everything at 1x
though. I also have ~20 memorex and maxell ones, no failures on those
either. I could be really lucky though, I am quite nervous about the
data stored on those DVDs lasting.  Apple DVD-R's are apparently
really good, although they are something like $5 a pop, so I don't
think the cost/benefit thing works too well there.

From sasha_romanosky at yahoo.com  Thu Dec  4 22:21:01 2003
From: sasha_romanosky at yahoo.com (Sasha Romanosky)
Date: Thu Dec  4 22:21:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] shipping camera images home from New Zealand
In-Reply-To: <86ekvkgbon.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <00ba01c3baf7$b2b59940$6401a8c0@laptop>


Instead of the usb cable and proprietary drivers, another option is to
buy a usb digital media reader/writer. There are types to support
smartmedia ($20 or so), compact flash, and a couple of others. They are
not much bigger than the media itself, allow for reading and writing,
require no additional drivers (for xp, anyhow). 

They can operate as a regular removable media drive if you're using it
to move largs files from pc to pc, for example. Or, full of images from
the camera, the card is removed, slipped into this thing and presto,
instant images.  

sasha

Not possible.  If you want usable security footage, stick to an analog

From Anderson.Robert at menlolog.com  Fri Dec  5 09:19:02 2003
From: Anderson.Robert at menlolog.com (Anderson, Robert H - MWT)
Date: Fri Dec  5 09:19:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] 2-way exchanges with ssh and scp
Message-ID: <25E622D843625C40BE0EEC150B437C1B2CCEB3@cnfqe029.cnf.prod.cnf.com>

Send the verbose output...

ssh -v ...

You can also run the sshd on the server with the -d option and in the
foreground to diagnose server issues...

sshd -d -f /etc/ssh/sshd_config -p 2222

Then from the laptop connect to port 2222...

ssh -v -p 2222 ...

Hope this helps,

-Rob Anderson

From josh at emediatedesigns.com  Fri Dec  5 13:43:01 2003

Subject: [PLUG] Backup User
Message-ID: <1335.134.244.174.87.1070660509.squirrel@sautez.com>

Hello,

I'm setting up some backup scripts and have run into a little challenge.

I doing the following:

rsync -av /drive1 /drive2

now I want to do this:

rsync -e ssh -avP backupUser at server1:/drive2 /mybackup

The problem is that the backupUser does not have the correct
permissions to read all the files that were backuped.  The first local
rsync is done with root and root is not allowed to ssh into the remote
server.

I have tried to put backupUser in the root group but that didn't seem
to help.

What settings/permissions do I need to give backupUser so that
he/she/it can read all the files regardless of permissions.  Some of
the files that are backup are 600.  Also, I don't want to tgz the file
as it is 8GB or more and after I do the first big ugly transfer the
rest would be pretty small with rsync.

From aaron at speakeasy.org  Fri Dec  5 13:51:02 2003
From: aaron at speakeasy.org (Aaron Burt)
Date: Fri Dec  5 13:51:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Linux Server setup
In-Reply-To: <20031205194627.GA6925@themontagnes.com>
References: <20031205194627.GA6925@themontagnes.com>
Message-ID: <20031205215058.GC32355@bavariati.org>

On Fri, Dec 05, 2003 at 11:46:27AM -0800, Michael Montagne wrote:
> So my wife was complaining about spam in the office.  I threw out my
> usual, you should set up a linux server to collect your mail from your
> ISP (right now they all just use pop3) and you could use spamassassin.

It's that, or install a spam filter like Popfile on each PC, giving
users control over their own spam-filtering.

> You could also make that your file server and then you could back up
> easier and not cut off from someone's files when they decide to turn
> their computer off.  Currently they use a peer-to-peer network with
> all win98 machines. 

I did small-business networks for quite a few years, and I want to make
sure you know what you're getting yourself into here.

Servers require sysadmins.  The Boss is (rightfully) gonna ask, "How
much is your time gonna cost?  Can we trust you to be available RIGHT
NOW when the thing breaks and shuts down the whole office?  What do we
do if the both of you up and move to Connecticut?  What business reason
compels us to commit to something that'll cost us money now and for the
indefinite future?"

For most folks, changes mean anger and confusion.  The one who hits the
mail-check button every 20 seconds when she's expecting something won't
like being told to wait for Fetchmail on the Linux box to do its every-
10-minute check; she'll sit and stew and drum her fingers as loudly as
possible.  The one who shares a few form letters won't like having to
access them from another drive letter, because he's *always* accessed
them from c:\Documents\pucky\bull\ and dammit, anything else is just
plain *different*.

The technical work is easy, the social work is not.  Mimimize the pace
of (perceived) change and technology commitment, cultivate and use the
office's amateur technicians, sling boatloads of charm and humor and
only the tiniest pinches of BS, and act like everything's perfectly
reasonable. 

> I think I can handle all of this except for one nagging question.  I
> want this to look relatively easy so I thought I'd ask here first.
> She likes to check her mail from home. Their ISP is Qwest and I'm sure
> they connect using DHCP.  I also sort of told her that she could
> access the linux box from home when she needed to.  Are these things
> (the access parts) possible with your standard Qwest DHCP setup?  

When I had QWorst DSL, I accessed my Linux box remotely all'a time.
It's one of the nicest things about having DSL or cable.  I used a free
dyndns.org hostname and set up my box to update it every time it did a
DHCP.

Be sure and test that everything works and recovers automagically before
making any promises, let alone bringing the box into the office.  
And think about backup and virus-scanning for the file-server.
Central reliable storage with regular backup can be its own reward.

Sorry this is so long, but all of it is heartfelt and IMO important.

From plug201 at jblack.org  Fri Dec  5 15:12:02 2003
From: plug201 at jblack.org (J Black)
Date: Fri Dec  5 15:12:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Linux Server setup
In-Reply-To: <1070664653.2504.277.camel@localhost>
References: <20031205194627.GA6925@themontagnes.com>
	 <1070664653.2504.277.camel@localhost>
Message-ID: <1070665773.10020.293.camel@localhost>

Michael,

You probably promised only file server access, but are you aware of
RealVNC and TightVNC, two compatible PC-Anywhere type applications for
Windows and Linux?  If not, Google both those words &/or check out
http://www.linuxworld.com/story/32625.htm and then
http://www.gregmartyn.com/computerhelp/tightvnc.html
The problem you may encounter with any server (VNC or FTP or ...) on
DHCP is finding out the IP address from "outside", since Qwest may
assign a new one at times. To work around that, read
http://www.gregmartyn.com/computerhelp/dyndns.html & follow the links to
dyndns.org to set up a way to access your server by name (dyndns.org)

Surely they are on some kind of router/firewall, so read at
www.dyndns.org about how to set up the firewall to let outside
connections in to the server for specific ports (like the FTP port or
the VNC port).

I am just in the middle of setting this up myself, so can't guide you
any further at this time.  Perhaps others on this list can?

- Jesse

On Fri, 2003-12-05 at 13:18, Jason Van Cleve wrote:
> So I'm on dial-up and want to block banner ads, but I don't want to do
> anything too fancy, like using squid.  I know there is a solution using
> bind, which I have on my system but am not actually running.  But it
> appears I can also do it just by adding entries in /etc/hosts.

I didn't realize squid was all that fancy.  :-)

To block ads and porn on my local network, I have squid set up with
squidGuard and transparent proxying via iptables.

You could modify a blacklist and use /etc/hosts and point to localhost,
then have an http server running on localhost serving up any request a
pretty blocked.jpg or whatnot.

http://axpr.net/blocked.jpg is what I use, if I remembered the URL
correctly.

Squid/SquidGuard was really not all that difficult to set up, IMHO.

> Which is preferable?  It would be nice to redirect ad' domains to my
> local httpd and serve myself a gif image instead of the broken image
> icon.

I should turn my red-on-white jpg into a red-on-transparent gif, now
that I think about it.....

I don't know how you'd configure a local HTTP server to answer every
request with a certain graphic, though.

> And by the way, can anyone post a list of undesirable domains, as a
> starting point?

My list is currently about 18MB in size.  I'd rather not post it to the
list (hell, Postfix would reject it locally, before it got there).  I
have a few blacklists added together which are fairly static, and then
also update nightly the http://squidguard.mesd.k12.or.us/blacklists.tgz
list.

Rob

From kyle at silverbeach.net  Fri Dec  5 17:45:02 2003

On Friday 05 December 2003 16:37, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   My fiancee wants to work on her laptop either connected to the network or
> off-line. There's no problem setting up her /home directory and getting
> three of the four main apps she uses running as stand-alone installations:
> mozilla, openoffice.org and jpilot. My question is how to configure her
> mail service (she likes sylpheed).
>
>   On the workstation, all /home directories are nfs-mounted from the
> server. So her mail is on the server and she is able to send and receive
> with no problems.
>
>   On the laptop, connected to the network, what do I need to do so she can
> collect mail from the server when she wants it? This is new territory for
> me so expect some questions. :-)

I set my wife up with a lap top in a similar manner, but I think the 
restrictions might be different.

I set up a small WAP on my local LAN (it's going behind it's own firewall 
soon) and NFS exported the home directory for her.  I set up POP on the 
server so she could get her email.  Because her home directory is staying on 
the server, I can just use POP and not IMAP.

It seems to work out fine though I think I'll go to 802.11g as soon as I can 
afford it (and the Linux drivers work).  The latency is noticably higher than 
my wired network and the bandwidth is not great.  But it was _cheap_!

The big difference here is that my wife _only_ uses the laptop from home, i.e. 
she is effectively always on the LAN.  I use the laptop offline and remotely 
all the time, but I don't have a problem with SSH etc.

My biggest goals was to make sure that she never ended up with two copies of 
her mail or her other data.

When would your fiancee collect email?  When she's not at home, is she 
completely offline?  If she needs to get and handle mail while she's remote, 
then something like IMAP or APOP might be the best bet (POP is not encrypted 
or particularly secure, hmm, not sure if IMAP is either).

You could get the email to the laptop a number of ways.  If you want to make 
sure that everything works (while email might not flow, nothing errors out), 
this might work (untested, use with caution, do not drive heavy machinery, I 
am not a system admin, nor do I play one on TV, etc. etc.):

Set up a simple POP server on the server.

Write a little wrapper script for fetchmail on the laptop.  Have it run every 
ten minutes or so.  _Iff_ the network is up, have it contact the server and 
get the mail.  If the network is not up, it just quietly goes back to sleep.  
Actually I think that fetchmail might be able to do this on its own, I cannot 
remember.

Set up Postfix/<MTA of choice> on the laptop.  Aim Sylpheed at it for 
_sending_ mail.  I'm not sure of all the nuances, but I'm pretty sure that 
Postfix comes out of the box with a sample config that would handle a 
intermittently connected machine.  Where do you route outgoing mail?  Postfix 
should queue mail until it is triggered to sent it away.

Setup Sylpheed to real new email from /var/spool/mail or the local equivalent. 
I.e. wherever fetchmail is going to put it.

This way she could always check for mail and send mail, even while offline.  
She won't get mail quite as quickly, but it should be able to queue just fine 
on the server.  She'll be able to send mail at any point, but it won't make 
it off the laptop and into the wide world until she's online.

What are her interactivity requirements?  If she is online, but not on your 
internal LAN sometimes, then maybe a carefully protected IMAP server would be 
best?

I'm probably going to be setting up a VPN tunnel from my laptop through my 
firewall into my DMZ so that I can access my internal services without having 
to expose them directly through the firewall.  I've done chroot servers and 
the like and it wasn't fun.  Most everyone I work with has wireless or a LAN 
at home or in the office.  Thus, I can be on the Internet nearly anywhere.

Best,
Kyle

On Fri, Dec 05, 2003 at 03:08:10PM -0800, J Black wrote:
> I googled for "list of ad servers" and got a bunch of useful-looking
> matches.  The first one, http://pgl.yoyo.org/adservers/, looks quite
> informative, tho written for Windows users.  In Linux, the hosts file is
> /etc/hosts.

Abusing the hosts file in this manner may have serious implications on
any OS (namely, network weirdness, and if you run a webserver on your
system, a *lot* of 404's coming from localhost).

Solve it the right way by using something with some intelligence and
save yourself some headaches down the line.

From bsr at spek.org  Fri Dec  5 23:08:02 2003
From: bsr at spek.org (Brent Rieck)
Date: Fri Dec  5 23:08:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Moving a user from workstation to portable
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0312051632570.1628@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0312051632570.1628@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <3FD17FE2.6040405@spek.org>

Rich Shepard wrote:
>   On the laptop, connected to the network, what do I need to do so she can
> collect mail from the server when she wants it? This is new territory for me
> so expect some questions. :-)

I setup an IMAP server on my workstation to do exactly that for me.  Now 
both my laptop and my desktop can read the same mail; my laptop uses a 
world-reachable ip address to read the email from (over IMAPS) so it 
even works when outside of my own network.  I filter "server side" with 
procmail rather than with the filtering capability of my email clients; 
I didn't know if two connected clients would "fight" over filtering, or 
if I'd have to always leave the filtering one running.

At first I used the UW IMAP server - which I quickly realized sucks; my 
flow of spam kept the IMAP server busy enough to keep my system load at 
2+ 24/7 all while being VERY unresponsive.  I recently switched to the 
Courier IMAP server and maildirs now my system load is back down to a 
reasonable 0.1.

--Brent

In the FWIW column, the only time I've seen ssh_exchange_identification 
has been if the target host has tcp_wrappers enabled and ssh is not 
permitted, or connecting to a Cisco PIX that has not had the certificate 
authority generated and save to flash.  Assuredly it is not the latter.

tcp_wrappers, netfilter rules, or file permissions related to ssh are the 
three issues I deal with anymore.

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Sat Dec  6 18:22:02 2003
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: Sat Dec  6 18:22:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] 2-way exchanges with ssh and scp
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0312061724220.23947@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0312031726050.14220@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	<20031204021132.GB3979@sapphire.CS.ORST.EDU>
	<Pine.LNX.4.56.0312061252070.23947@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	<86brql1vk2.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
	<Pine.LNX.4.56.0312061724220.23947@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <86k759xt9s.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Rich" == Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> writes:

Russell> Does the remote system have "PasswordAuthentication yes" in
Russell> its /etc/ssh/sshd_config?

Rich>   Yes, it does.

Rich>   I just tried connecting with that commented out with no
Rich> difference.

Well, it should have been "yes" given my understanding of what you
were trying to do.  However, I think now that understanding was
faulty.

You probably should make new keys on lemna, rather than copying them
over from salmo.  On lemna, run:

  ssh-keygen -t dsa 

If dsa keys are what you want.  You should _add_ (as in "append") the
resulting .ssh/id_dsa.pub to the appropriate users
.ssh/authorized_keys on salmo.  Likewise, you should _add_ salmo's
.ssh/id_dsa.pub to lemna's .ssh/authorized_keys.

Permissions and ownership are also important.  The .ssh directory
should be 0700, and .ssh/id_dsa should be 0600.  I seem to recall
something about write permission on the home directory being important
too, but I couldn't find the specifics.  Something about a group
member or another user should not being able to modify the .ssh
permissions.

-- 
Russell Senior         ``I have nine fingers; you have ten.''
seniorr at aracnet.com

From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Sat Dec  6 19:54:02 2003
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Sat Dec  6 19:54:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Re: PGP
In-Reply-To: <20031207025626.GH11158@brian.brianandkellyderr.com>
References: <1070665690.2542.290.camel@localhost>
	 <20031206034209.GP27730@ursine.ca>
	 <20031207025626.GH11158@brian.brianandkellyderr.com>
Message-ID: <1070770340.5827.129.camel@dell.linux.box>

On Sat, 2003-12-06 at 18:56, Brian Derr wrote:

> I'm curious as to how you have your signature and email in one file
> rather than the way I'm sending my emails now with the text in one file
> and the gpg signature in another.  Is it a setting with GnuPG or mutt?
> Thanks!

If you google about for PGP/MIME vs cleartext (or inline) signing, you
should find a lot of explenations on it, maybe even with workarounds for
mutt.

I think a few friends who use mutt and sign inline have things set up to
pipe the text of the message through gpg before sending, as if from the
editor rather than from mutt itself, but I don't have specifics, as I've
never been a big mutt user.

FWIW, a lot of folks use a broken mail client that will not properly
display your PGP/MIME post - the text of the email shows up as an
attachmnt.

Rob

From the Mutt user manual:

  6.3.143.  pgp_create_traditional

  Type: quadoption
  Default: no

  This option controls whether Mutt generates old-style inline PGP
  encrypted or signed messages.

  Note that PGP/MIME will be used automatically for messages which have
  a character set different from us-ascii, or which consist of more than
  a single MIME part.

  Also note that using the old-style PGP message format is strongly
  deprecated.

From daniel at digitree.org  Sun Dec  7 04:43:02 2003
From: daniel at digitree.org (Daniel Hedlund)
Date: Sun Dec  7 04:43:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] how are uid/gid mapped between NFS server and client?
In-Reply-To: <867k18ud3s.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <86zne5t2z0.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
	 <20031207100219.GA3460@maybe.net> <20031207102158.GB3460@maybe.net>
	 <867k18ud3s.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <1070800894.3387.131.camel@bluegum.digitree.org>

> Ah, right (sorry for the ambiguity).  So to paraphrase, there isn't
> any uid/gid translation over the NFS layer.  The server sees a uid
> (not a username) wanting to write, the server serves files by uid,
> etc.

Yes, that's pretty much correct.  This is also a very serious problem as
well, so you need to make sure you restrict which IP addresses have
access to the NFS shares, and it's still only okay to use NFS in trusted
environments.  If a rogue computer connects to your network and is able
to mount the NFS share, they will have full access to read and write to
every account/directory on the server (even worse if the NFS shares have
symlinks enabled).  Well, this isn't quite true as, be default, I
believe the root account over NFS has the same privileges as the user
'nobody'.

I also believe there are very easy attacks against NFS servers with IP
address spoofing, and man in the middle attacks.  I also found out about
a week ago that there is an SSL/TLS wrapper that can go around NFS to
make it a little bit more secure...but each computer with access needs
to be trusted.

Cheers,

Daniel

-- 
Daniel Hedlund
daniel at digitree.org
CEO & Chief Consultant
DigiTree Studios Pty Ltd.

From heinlein at madboa.com  Sun Dec  7 08:07:02 2003
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Sun Dec  7 08:07:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] how are uid/gid mapped between NFS server and client?
In-Reply-To: <86zne5t2z0.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <86zne5t2z0.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0312070704280.9801@pecos.madboa.com>

On Sun, 7 Dec 2003, Russell Senior wrote:

> Please pardon the clueless NFS-ignorant question:
>
> If the uid's aren't synchronized between the NFS server and client,
> what happens?  Suppose user jdoe is uid 1001 on the NFS client and
> uid 1005 on the NFS server, what uid will own jdoe's files on the
> NFS server?

As others have noted, uid -> username resolution gets done on the
client.

Any filesystem, network or local, needs three compoents: file server,
file client, *and* a common authentication system.

Since filesystems store file metadata (ownership, permissions, ACLs,
...) as numeric tokens, it needs an authentication database to do
number -> name lookups. Sometimes the authentication system is local,
like /etc/passwd, and sometimes it's remote: NIS, LDAP, AFS, Kerberos.

Regardless of whether the authentication is local or remote, however,
it needs to be there. Remove a user from /etc/passwd on your local
system, and all you'll see are files owned by some uid. Same thing if
you lose contact with your NIS or LDAP server.

The trick, I think, will be to devise a network filesystem in which

* within the network universe, any given "realm" (for lack of a better
  term) is unique; a realm would be the moral equivalent to a DNS
  domain or subdomain name or to the root DN in LDAP land.

* within each realm, each username must be unique

* a group can contain users of many realms

* all files are stored with rich ACLs, not Unix u-g-o symbols

* all communication between clients, filestores, and authentication
  servers is protected by strong crypto

* all authentication servers are visible to the networks of any remote
  realms with which there are collaborative efforts

* authenication servers must be available via a fall-back mechanism
  for redundancy, much like NIS has

* client access to file servers should be available in both
  host-to-host formats, like NFS is currently implemented, and a
  user-to-host format, with the remote mount available only to the
  mounting user.

* file locking can be done on a byte-range basis

* all communications are based on open standards

There are a few "mostly there" protocols for all this -- AFS and NFSv4
the leading contenders -- but AFS is hard and NFSv4 doesn't (imo) do
enough to define a shared authentication mechanism.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Sun Dec  7 09:11:02 2003
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Sun Dec  7 09:11:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] how are uid/gid mapped between NFS server and client?
In-Reply-To: <86zne5t2z0.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <86zne5t2z0.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <23958-57992@sneakemail.com>

On Sun, 7 Dec 2003, Russell Senior seniorr-at-aracnet.com |PDX Linux| wrote:

> Please pardon the clueless NFS-ignorant question:
>
> If the uid's aren't synchronized between the NFS server and client, what
> happens?  Suppose user jdoe is uid 1001 on the NFS client and uid 1005
> on the NFS server, what uid will own jdoe's files on the NFS server?

On the NFS server the files will be owned by userid "1001", since that is
the uid the files were created will (reported by the client).

Other clients will also see the files owned by userid "1001" since they
are now stored that way.

If jdoe logs in to the NFS server, he/she will now not be the owner of the
files since the uid is different.  User "1001", whoever it may be, will be
the owner of those files.

  -- Steve



From carla at bratgrrl.com  Sun Dec  7 10:43:02 2003
From: carla at bratgrrl.com (Carla Schroder)
Date: Sun Dec  7 10:43:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] what is the point of PGP-signed emails?
Message-ID: <200312071042.33484.carla@bratgrrl.com>

So what's the point, realio and trulio, of using PGP in email? I think 
it's a geek affectation. Anyone can generate a key. Anyone can paste a 
bunch of stuff in a message that looks like a key. If someone like 
David Mandel posted a message here that said "No more PLUG. I'm sick of 
it. We're pulling the PLUG hahahahaaa", it wouldn't matter if it were 
PGP-signed or not- no one would take such a message at face value. We 
would pick up and the phone and go "Yo, David, WTF?" 

So, aside from generating endless flame wars over how mail clients 
display a PGP sig, I just don't see the point.

From daniel at digitree.org  Sun Dec  7 10:55:02 2003
From: daniel at digitree.org (Daniel Hedlund)
Date: Sun Dec  7 10:55:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] what is the point of PGP-signed emails?
In-Reply-To: <200312071042.33484.carla@bratgrrl.com>
References: <200312071042.33484.carla@bratgrrl.com>
Message-ID: <1070823225.3387.184.camel@bluegum.digitree.org>

     For normal day to day emails, there's probably not too much of a
benefit using PGP signatures (ie. general banter or from a grandmother
to her daughter).  I guess it could be important to use if decisions
were being made to prove identity (ie. voting over something through
email), or if people often send code to be committed to CVS.  PGP
encryption, on the other hand, is very useful.  Cheers,

Daniel

Daniel Hedlund

| Anyone can paste a bunch of stuff in a message that looks like a
| key.

From dan_young at parkrose.k12.or.us  Sun Dec  7 11:54:02 2003
From: dan_young at parkrose.k12.or.us (Dan Young)
Date: Sun Dec  7 11:54:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] what is the point of PGP-signed emails?
In-Reply-To: <200312071128.43425.carla@bratgrrl.com>
References: <200312071042.33484.carla@bratgrrl.com>
        <3FD37B4D.9050104@egosurf.net>

Message-ID: <65059.12.225.208.192.1070826852.squirrel@webmail.parkrose.k12.or.us>

Carla Schroder said:
> On Sunday 07 December 2003 11:11 am, Grish wrote:
>> | Anyone can generate a key.
>>
>> Indeed. But it will be a different key.
>
> Different from what? Someone generates their own key, and appears on
>  this list claiming to be Joe Smith. What good is the PGP key? We
> have  only his word that he is who he says he is.

Hence key-signing parties and web-of-trust. If David shows me two
pieces of ID and his pub key, I have a more reasonable expectation
that his signed messages come from him, if he takes reasonable
precautions with his private key, i.e. encrypting it w/ a strong
passphrase. If you and Eric and Russell and Jeme tell me a given pub
key belongs to David, and I trust you all and have your signed keys,
then maybe I somewhat trust that the key really is his.

> The point is verifying the authenticity of a message, by whatever
> means  are available, and it sounds you're saying PGP is completely
> trustworthy. I'm saying it' s not. Even if it is verifiably David's
> key, that only proves someone had access to his PC.

Private keys protected by strong passphrases are the order of the day.

> Some Pluggers had fake ID as teenagers 'proving' they were 21. I
> don't  see how this is any different. If you already have a web of
> relationships established, then youalready have ways of knowing if a
>  message came from a particular person or not. If it's a total
> stranger,  then I don't see where it's any better than any other
> form of ID, that  can be faked.

PGP strengthens those already established webs-of-trust and extends
them. Your example with David disbanding PLUG works because that
statement would be wildly out of character. What happens when a
forgery is more subtle?

I agree that PGP less useful for complete strangers. On some level you
have to depend on the stranger to protect their private key, or the
whole thing breaks down.

-Dan Young
-Parkrose School District

From grishnav at egosurf.net  Sun Dec  7 12:12:01 2003
From: grishnav at egosurf.net (Grish)
Date: Sun Dec  7 12:12:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] what is the point of PGP-signed emails?
In-Reply-To: <200312071128.43425.carla@bratgrrl.com>
References: <200312071042.33484.carla@bratgrrl.com> <3FD37B4D.9050104@egosurf.net> <200312071128.43425.carla@bratgrrl.com>
Message-ID: <3FD38946.40501@egosurf.net>

-----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----
Hash: SHA1
 
Carla Schroder wrote:

|
| Different from what? Someone generates their own key, and appears
| on this list claiming to be Joe Smith. What good is the PGP key?


None. See the GnuPG Handbook section on key signing and trust
relationships. That's what makes the PGP keys useful for identification.

| We have only his word that he is who he says he is.


Or your own eyes and ears.

And even if the key does you no good for identity verification, it is
still good for integrity verification.

|
| The point is verifying the authenticity of a message, by whatever
| means are available, and it sounds you're saying PGP is completely
|  trustworthy.


Completely trustworthy? Nothing is.

But remember, OpenPGP is a standard, GnuPG is the implementation (that
I'm using, anyway). You are welcome to verify the GnuPG source for
yourself if you don't trust the implementation. You're welcome to code
your own as well.

As far as the standard, and the algorithims it employs: they are some
of the best we've got right now. Completely trustworthy? Nah...
Cryptographically secure (by reasonable definition)? So far as we
know, yes.

| I'm saying it' s not. Even if it is verifiably David's key, that
| only proves someone had access to his PC.


Yes. And tortured him for his passphrase (which *should* be long
enough that people aren't going to guess it or brute-force it any time
soon).

And if someone else did have access to his key (and assuming that he
knows about it), he should be busy generating a revoker right now.

|
| Some Pluggers had fake ID as teenagers 'proving' they were 21.


Poor analogy. A signed key is *much* harder to forge than a signature
or a card (some would say impossible, but I won't argue that).

| I don't see how this is any different. If you already have a web of
|  relationships established, then youalready have ways of knowing if
| a message came from a particular person or not. If it's a total
| stranger, then I don't see where it's any better than any other
| form of ID, that can be faked.
|
Because you're thinking purely in terms of identification
verification. In that circumstance, you're right. A key is basically
useless for indentification without being signed (weather by you or
through a web of trust).

However, consider this:

We've likely never met in real life. There is no face assocaited with
this name. Yet, these messages consistantly come from the same public key.

Lets say I've been forging somebody's identity all along. Does it
really matter? So you can no longer trust the name that's assocaited
with a given key. Big deal! You couldn't trust it before.

You can still trust the key's fingerprint, and the signature. You
still know that, whoever the hell I am claiming to be on a given day,
I'm still the same person typing the email.

Assuming, of course, that I've kept my private key secure. ;)

Weather or not you actually know this message came from me, or someone
claiming to be me, you still know it was sent by key id 0E7428ED with
fingerprint 6ACE BFFA 6584 C3FE C95A DAF4 568F FF44 0E74 28ED. Even if
you can't necessarily verify who a person is, you can verify that it's
still the same person.

Finally, even an untrusted unknown key can be used to ensure that a
message arrives fully intact, and has not been altered in transit.

From grishnav at egosurf.net  Sun Dec  7 12:20:03 2003
From: grishnav at egosurf.net (Grish)
Date: Sun Dec  7 12:20:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] ssh and X forwarding
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0312071156500.20423@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0312071156500.20423@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <3FD38B1D.9030600@egosurf.net>

-----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----
Hash: SHA1
 
Rich Shepard wrote:

| Am I correct in assuming that if X forwarding is set to "yes" in
| /etc/ssh_config and /etc/sshd_config, then it's done automatically?
|
No. You also need to specify -X on the command line:

ssh -X remote_host.

| That is, an X app running on the server is displayed in X on the
| client?


Let's use the terms "remote host" and "local host" - client and server
is too confusing when talking X, because remember, the server runs on
the "client," and the clients are the programs running on the "server" ;)

The application runs on the remote host (what you called the server),
and connects to the X server (what you called the client) on the local
host which draws the client's (in this case, by "client" I mean an X
client - the piece of software running, be it Mozilla or GAIM)
information to the display.

SSH should set up the DISPLAY environment variable on the remote host
for you, so that the client (again, software) knows where to connect.
That port will, of course, be forwarded to X running on the local
host. SSH will also take the liberty of setting up your .xauth file so
that the client (software) is allowed to access the server (X server
on local host).

|
| I'm wondering if this would be the most parsimonious way for my
| fiancee to read and compose mail from her laptop. Easier than me
| trying to learn how to properly set up an IMAP server for her use.


IMAP isn't hard to set up. If even I can figure it out, it should be
cake for anyone else.

Besides, X isn't too great if you end up in a situation where you're
stuck on a modem or something... (sorry, I can't remember if that was
one of the criteria on your original email regarding this question.)

as* sshd_config, than yes, it's done automatically.

files on the local host won't get you anywhere, and changing both on
the remote host will still require -X on the local host...

From chris at maybe.net  Sun Dec  7 13:32:01 2003

Subject: [PLUG] Re: PGP and S/MIME

References: <1070665690.2542.290.camel@localhost> <20031206034209.GP27730@ursine.ca> <20031207025626.GH11158@brian.brianandkellyderr.com> <1070770340.5827.129.camel@dell.linux.box> <20031207044521.GF9810@maybe.net> <20031207132907.GB18362@brian.brianandkellyderr.com> <20031207203704.GA21999@maybe.net> <20031207204606.GB19944@ursine.ca>
Message-ID: <20031207213149.GA17408@maybe.net>

On Sun, Dec 07, 2003 at 12:46:06PM -0800, Paul Johnson wrote:
> On Sun, Dec 07, 2003 at 12:37:04PM -0800, Chris Jantzen wrote:
> > If I know the other end is likely to be using Outlook, I just switch to
> > my S/MIME signature, which does work fine.
> 
> Do you have a howto on how to sign using S/MIME?

If you Google, there are results on it. It's not an .... easy ...
process. :-( Most of the difficulty lies in extracting the certificates
and chain of trust from the files given to you by your CA. Presumably if
you could find one that's more OpenSSL friendly, sailing would be
smoother. The second difficult part is understand which directories the
S/MIME patch wants the files in, as the documentation is a bit hazy
there.

When I find time, I shall have to sit down and explain it, if you want.

(BTW, Thawte will give you a personal email cert for free, and you can
go and get it signed by people to create a web of trust like GPG.)

Oh, and I remember (and just went and looked) that there is an example
rc block in Debian in /usr/share/doc/mutt/examples

>  Maybe even automate
> it in mutt to do it automatically when it see's Outlook Express's
> User-Agent header?

I tried just now, and apparently in the current incarnation of Mutt,
it's not possible to do general header matching on reply. (It's possible
elsewhere, though.) It is, however, relatively easy to switch on a
per-address basis.

At the top of your -hook blocks, add the following:

send-hook . "unset smime_is_default"

then later, add something like:

send-hook "~C billg at microsoft.com" "set smime_is_default"

-- 
chris kb7rnl =->

Dan> Hence key-signing parties and web-of-trust. If David shows me two
Dan> pieces of ID and his pub key, I have a more reasonable
Dan> expectation that his signed messages come from him, [...]

I thought Jeme made an interesting point a few weeks ago, about the
pieces of ID being more or less superfluous in this situation.  If you
recognize the person standing in front of you as the person you think
it is, then it really doesn't matter who the State thinks they are.
The mapping between flesh and electronic communication what is
interesting.

That said, and just to blurt out something that has been bouncing
around in my head for a while, I don't see how signing my messages
does much for me, at least not directly.  I might _want_ to maintain
some ambiguity about what I did or didn't say (particularly when my
jokes aren't funny).  Signing messages is primarily a service to the
recipient, and only through that service, indirectly a service to the
sender.

From chris at maybe.net  Sun Dec  7 14:26:01 2003
From: chris at maybe.net (Chris Jantzen)
Date: Sun Dec  7 14:26:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] how are uid/gid mapped between NFS server and client?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0312070704280.9801@pecos.madboa.com>
References: <86zne5t2z0.fsf@coulee.tdb.com> <Pine.LNX.4.58.0312070704280.9801@pecos.madboa.com>
Message-ID: <20031207222532.GA19565@maybe.net>

On Sun, Dec 07, 2003 at 08:06:24AM -0800, Paul Heinlein wrote:
> Any filesystem, network or local, needs three compoents: file server,
> file client, *and* a common authentication system.
> 
> Since filesystems store file metadata (ownership, permissions, ACLs,
> ...) as numeric tokens, it needs an authentication database to do
> number -> name lookups. Sometimes the authentication system is local,
> like /etc/passwd, and sometimes it's remote: NIS, LDAP, AFS, Kerberos.
> 
> Regardless of whether the authentication is local or remote, however,
> it needs to be there. Remove a user from /etc/passwd on your local
> system, and all you'll see are files owned by some uid. Same thing if
> you lose contact with your NIS or LDAP server.

To quibble on fine (but important) points:

Authentication is simply the process of verifying identity, e.g., the
user has the password right or has the right SecurID card.

Authorization is the process of mapping a user identity to their rights
to access files. Presumably it makes sure the identity is authenticated
first, but it is not required to (such as in our case of NFS < v4).

Sometimes it is also worth seperating the concept of a Directory as
the database that maps textual user identities to machine readable user
identities (such as username to uid).

Understanding the difference between authorization and authentication
helps to understand why Microsoft's abuse of Kerberos 5 packets for
the purposes of Active Directory is a bad thing.

Again, just quibbling. The important thing from the entire thread is:
Yes, you have to synchronize. :-)

-- 
chris kb7rnl =->

From daniel at digitree.org  Sun Dec  7 15:16:02 2003
From: daniel at digitree.org (Daniel Hedlund)
Date: Sun Dec  7 15:16:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] ssh and X forwarding
In-Reply-To: <1070837977.2226.6.camel@atlas.cadtocam.com>

	 <1070837977.2226.6.camel@atlas.cadtocam.com>
Message-ID: <1070838893.3387.261.camel@bluegum.digitree.org>

On Mon, 2003-12-08 at 09:59, Kenneth G. Stephens wrote:

> We use VNC to run programs on our compute servers. X-forwarding in ssh
> sometimes works, sometimes doesn't.  VNC also has the advantage of being
> able to disconnect without loosing the session. She comes home and runs
> vncviewer and she is right back where she left off.

Warning:  VNC is also inherently very bandwidth intensive (it sends full
images over, or parts that have changed depending on how configured, as
images, not descriptions of images).  You can get around this with
TightVNC, but it uses lossy compression (colours different than
original, poorer quality, etc.  VNC also starts an instance of X for
each session running.  This can be very memory intensive for the system
serving.  I'm not exactly sure, but (as an example) I believe that if
you have a regular X session running Gnome and you start a VNC session
running Gnome, it doesn't share the Gnome libraries in memory?  Anyone
have more insight?  Cheers,

Daniel

-- 
Daniel Hedlund
daniel at digitree.org
CEO & Chief Consultant
DigiTree Studios Pty Ltd.

Brent,

  I worked out a solution that's equivalent, but was quick and painless.

  Taking your message as a starting point, I found the RH 7.3 imap package
on rpmfind.net. Downloaded it and discovered that it was already installed.
All services turned off.

  Read the imap README and got that running on `salmo'. Tried to connect
from `pachy' (her laptop) and sylpheed would do only POP3. Shrug. Shut off
imap and fired up POP3 on `salmo'. Sylpheed now reads mail from
salmo:/var/spool/mail/<username> while running on `pachy', too. Whew!

  Now she has her four applications (mail, Web browsing, OpenOffice.org and
jpilot) all set up on the desktop of her laptop and can work in the den at
the rear of the house. We just need to remember to not trip on the 100' cat5
cable snaked across the floor. :-)

  Thanks to all of your. I learned a lot -- and was massively lucky -- this
weekend. Now to ensure that /dev/modem links to the proper device on my
laptop and I'm all set there, too. Now, back to the new workstation/server
....

Rich

On Sun, Dec 07, 2003 at 10:42:33AM -0800, Carla Schroder wrote:
> So what's the point, realio and trulio, of using PGP in email? I think 
> it's a geek affectation. Anyone can generate a key.

But not anybody can get their key signed.  You have to have a web of
trust to sign your keys with.

> Anyone can paste a bunch of stuff in a message that looks like a
> key.

Not that anybody would be able to do anything with it.

> If someone like David Mandel posted a message here that said "No
> more PLUG. I'm sick of it. We're pulling the PLUG hahahahaaa", it
> wouldn't matter if it were PGP-signed or not- no one would take such
> a message at face value. We would pick up and the phone and go "Yo,
> David, WTF?"

But if David Mandel had usually signed with a key that people who met
him have signed his key (legal ID and face-to-face interaction is
expected when you sign keys) could go, "OK, I can totally ignore this
non-issue, it's not actually David."

For private messages, it's also nice in the fact you can encrypt your
message to ensure only the intended recipient is able to view it
thanks to the wonders of public key encryption.

GnuPG is extensively documented.
http://www.gnupg.org/(en)/documentation/index.html

Hash: SHA1

On Sun, Dec 07, 2003 at 11:28:43AM -0800, Carla Schroder wrote:
> Different from what? Someone generates their own key, and appears on 
> this list claiming to be Joe Smith. What good is the PGP key? We have 
> only his word that he is who he says he is.

Until someone has met him, checked ID and signed his key.  Then, once
the newly signed keys are uploaded to keyservers, from finger, or
encoded in an email (what you see on this message is just a signature,
not a key), anybody who trusts the people that keysigning know by
proxy that Joe Smith really is who he claims he is.  Needless to say,
this only works as well as the people in your web of trust: It's
absolutely imperative that you understand how to properly use GPG or
PGP before using it.

> The point is verifying the authenticity of a message, by whatever means 
> are available, and it sounds you're saying PGP is completely 
> trustworthy. I'm saying it' s not. Even if it is verifiably David's 
> key, that only proves someone had access to his PC. 

Not specifically, no.  We know that someone has gained access to both
his private key and his private key password.  This isn't usually
where public key encryption breaks down, though.  Most people using
such systems protect their private key well, and don't go writing down
their PGP passwords for the same reasons they don't go leaving their
ATM cards around with their PIN numbers written on them.

> If you already have a web of relationships established, then
> youalready have ways of knowing if a message came from a particular
> person or not.

GPG cuts way back on the whole social engineering aspect.

> That said, and just to blurt out something that has been bouncing
> around in my head for a while, I don't see how signing my messages
> does much for me, at least not directly.  I might _want_ to maintain
> some ambiguity about what I did or didn't say (particularly when my
> jokes aren't funny).  Signing messages is primarily a service to the
> recipient, and only through that service, indirectly a service to the
> sender.

You know, I have two problems with this whole discussion, and they're
both in implementation. Maybe I just haven't looked through the
documentation fully enough, but I cannot find (for evolution, and mutt,
though I haven't looked as much for mutt) a way to do either of these
two things:

1) semi-automagically store public keys on users who send me signed
emails, and truly automagically verify emails from users who have
already sent me emails, and

2) have a way, as I'm sending an email, to decide not to sign the email.
The only way I can find in Evolution is to change the actual settings,
which takes a while.

Plus, with lists, the emails _do_ get changed in transit, and so the
verification probably cannot be done automagically easily, as the
verification software needs to know how the emails should be changed to
get them back to verifiable state.

Jeff

On Sun, Dec 07, 2003 at 05:11:07PM -0800, Jeff Schwaber wrote:
> You know, I have two problems with this whole discussion, and they're
> both in implementation. Maybe I just haven't looked through the
> documentation fully enough, but I cannot find (for evolution, and mutt,
> though I haven't looked as much for mutt) a way to do either of these
> two things:

Regarding mutt:

> 1) semi-automagically store public keys on users who send me signed
> emails, and truly automagically verify emails from users who have
> already sent me emails, and

This can be handled by gnupg with ~/.gnupg/options:

keyserver-options auto-key-retrieve

It will download the key from the keyserver and use it to verify the
message. You need to be a member of the web of trust or have signed the
key directly, though.

> 2) have a way, as I'm sending an email, to decide not to sign the email.
> The only way I can find in Evolution is to change the actual settings,
> which takes a while.

"p" (pgp menu)
"f" (forget doing anything)

On Sun, Dec 07, 2003 at 08:25:32PM -0500, Brian Derr wrote:
> > Plus, with lists, the emails _do_ get changed in transit, and so the
> > verification probably cannot be done automagically easily, as the
> > verification software needs to know how the emails should be changed to
> > get them back to verifiable state.
> 
> I haven't noticed a problem with this.  When reading my own emails sent
> to this list the GPG verifies correctly.  Now, I'm not sure if that is
> because of the priv or pub key though.  Perhaps a GPG/PGP guru could
> answer that more better.  :-)

Yeah, oops. I meant to address this in the other reply.

Simple: You only sign the body of the message. Then an MLM can change
the headers to its heart's content; or add additional MIME segments with
"Unsubscribe here" URL's, or whatever. You do need to be careful not to
always trust the From: line. I *believe* mutt crosschecks these, however.
I know it does for S/MIME.

-----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----
Hash: SHA1

On Sun, Dec 07, 2003 at 05:11:07PM -0800, Jeff Schwaber wrote:
> 1) semi-automagically store public keys on users who send me signed
> emails,

This one's a function of GPG.  Edit ~/.gnupg/gpg.conf to include...

keyserver x-hkp://pgp.mit.edu
keyserver-options auto-key-retrieve

...and after that, GPG will try to retrieve public keys when it
doesn't already have them.

> and truly automagically verify emails from users who have
> already sent me emails, and

This is done in mutt automatically on messages using PGP/MIME style
signatures.  Inline signatures can be verified in mutt with Esc-P

> 2) have a way, as I'm sending an email, to decide not to sign the email.

In mutt, on the confirmation screen, you have this option.  Hit P f
(for (P)GP and (f)orget it).

> Plus, with lists, the emails _do_ get changed in transit, and so the
> verification probably cannot be done automagically easily, as the
> verification software needs to know how the emails should be changed to
> get them back to verifiable state.

Yes, but if you notice, you can tell by what PGP adds what part of the
message PGP will be verifying.  The only changes you can really make
in transit is adding things after the signature.  The part that's
signed is still good, just there's some extra unsigned stuff after.

On Sun, Dec 07, 2003 at 08:25:32PM -0500, Brian Derr wrote:
> I haven't figured out how to have mutt automatically get a GPG pub key
> either.  Especially since most people don't have anything, either in
> headers or signature, stating where to find their pub key.

Well, you can always ask other PGP users to send you a copy of their
key.  You can do so in mutt with Esc-k.  You can import a key from
email with C-k

> I haven't noticed a problem with this.  When reading my own emails sent
> to this list the GPG verifies correctly.

This is because PGP only verifies what's within it's boundaries.
Headers and anything appended to the end after signing aren't signed
and don't bother PGP any.

On Thu, 04 Dec 2003 17:30:28 -0800, Kyle Accardi
<sandbox at pacifier.com> wrote:

>Alan wrote: in another thread
>> BTW, Maxell media is not recommended.  I have had a lot of problems with
>> it.  (The only thing they make that works reliably is their black
