The online CD-R Faq used to have a lot of good information. They
reviewed a freeware windows CD ID program from Germany that would scan
the CD-R and report if it used the long or short term longevity dyes.
I downloaded the program and it worked as advertised.

The long longevity CD-R's were usually limited to HP, Sony, Fugi, and
Maxwell Pro. I haven't seen a HP disk to test for years and Sony went
to the cheap dyes when the speed went up (If I remember right, when
they went to 40?x something) earlier this year.

I haven't tested CD-R's much with it for a while because it only
worked in Windows 98, not 2000 or XP that I normally use at work, so I
would buy a lot of disks when they passed and not have to go to a
Windows 98 machine much. 

When we were running low on disks a few months ago I tried to install
it again in XP and surprisingly it worked! Must be some XP update that
made it work. The bad part is first I went to look for an updated
version of the program. The online CD-R Faq no longer listed anything
about it! I went to the site in Germany and it was not mentioned there
either, just his other programs. It got me thinking that maybe the
CD-R manufacturers wanted that program gone before it was general
knowledge (I just checked the site again and it looks like the
programmer has dumped the domain).

If anybody wants the CDR ID program  just send me an email saying so.
It's 109KB in the zip file. Maybe someone here can figure out how it
works and write a version for Linux.

Robert
RxLxPDX at corralcreek.com
 

Here is a description from the program:

Background information:

This small tool was developed to read the ATIP from a CDR media
using a CD recorder - right now there?s no CDROM reader that can
do this (At least I don?t know of!).
The ATIP tells who has manufactured the disc and what dye type
they used. (The ATIP doesn?t tell the exact dye type - it just
tells if the recording strategy to be used for this media is
a "long strategy type" (e.g. Cyanine) or "short strategy type"
(e.g. Phthalocyanine).

From postmaster at jblack.org  Sun Dec  7 23:09:31 2003
From: postmaster at jblack.org (Postmaster)
Date: Sun Dec  7 23:09:31 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Linux Server setup
In-Reply-To: <20031205194627.GA6925@themontagnes.com>
References: <20031205194627.GA6925@themontagnes.com>
Message-ID: <1070664653.2504.277.camel@localhost>

Michael,

You probably promised only file server access, but are you aware of
RealVNC and TightVNC, two compatible PC-Anywhere type applications for
Windows and Linux?  If not, Google both those words &/or check out
http://www.linuxworld.com/story/32625.htm and then
http://www.gregmartyn.com/computerhelp/tightvnc.html
The problem you may encounter with any server (VNC or FTP or ...) on
DHCP is finding out the IP address from "outside", since Qwest may
assign a new one at times. To work around that, read
http://www.gregmartyn.com/computerhelp/dyndns.html & follow the links to
dyndns.org to set up a way to access your server by name (dyndns.org)

Surely they are on some kind of router/firewall, so read at
www.dyndns.org about how to set up the firewall to let outside
connections in to the server for specific ports (like the FTP port or
the VNC port).

I am just in the middle of setting this up myself, so can't guide you
any further at this time.  Perhaps others on this list can?

- Jesse

	 <Pine.LNX.4.56.0312061824010.24709@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	 <Pine.LNX.4.56.0312061837070.24986@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1070870469.24781.5.camel@kat.zotnet.com>

A good debugging technique is to run sshd in debug mode *ON ANOTHER
PORT*

sshd when run as debug does not create a fork, but dumps to the
terminal.

so something like 
        sshd -p 2222 -d

Then connect with
        ssh -v -p 2222

One nifty thing you can run this as a user, and only log in as that
user.  It traces perms issues down. Warning, some system make /etc/ssh*
not world readable.

In-Reply-To: <200312071042.33484.carla@bratgrrl.com>

On Sun, 2003-12-07 at 10:42, Carla Schroder wrote:
> So what's the point, realio and trulio, of using PGP in email? I think 
> it's a geek affectation. 

To some extent this is true, but for a long time it could have been said
about email in general....

> Anyone can generate a key.

Yes, but the difference is the key will verify *that* email as being
generated by *that* keyholder.  That is a huge difference.  Faked email
with a faked key will be able to *be proved* to be fake.  Currently
faked email can be demonstrated to *likely be* faked.

As signed email becomes the norm, it can be used to fight spam, allow
access to lists, and demonstrate reliable transmissions.



>  Anyone can paste a 
> bunch of stuff in a message that looks like a key.

But anyone can test if its a real signature.  Those who do check, will
know immediately.  Those who don't will not care.  This would be a
stupid thing to do.  It only tips off more people.

>  If someone like 
> David Mandel posted a message here that said "No more PLUG. I'm sick of 
> it. We're pulling the PLUG hahahahaaa", it wouldn't matter if it were 
> PGP-signed or not- no one would take such a message at face value. We 
> would pick up and the phone and go "Yo, David, WTF?" 

You are pointing out how real trust works, it is built over time through
a Bayesian-like system of event storage.  You have an expectation of
mail from "David Mandel" and this would not fit.

On the other hand if someone claimed that people were posting under
false creds, say as Wil, then he can point out he always posts with with
a signature.

> 
> So, aside from generating endless flame wars over how mail clients 
> display a PGP sig, I just don't see the point.

If all email clients settled this, and they can, then the de facto
standard could be signed email.  A PGP/GPG signature adds very little
overhead to the transmission (unlike S/MIME), and adds lots to
reliability, verification, and forensics.  These are issues that become
important, when their qualities become commonplace and expected.

But until the email clients settle the standards issues, it is an early
adopter/high needs thing.  Arguing over the client issues is an
important part of the standards process.

-- 
Zot O'Connor

http://www.ZotConsulting.com
http://www.WhiteKnightHackers.com

On Mon, 2003-12-08 at 04:06, Brian Derr wrote:
> On Sun, Dec 07, 2003 at 08:18:35PM -0800, Paul Johnson wrote:
> > Oh.  I'm not attaching my key to every file.
> 
> Alright, I get it.  So the sender has to actually attach the public key
> to the email for mutt to be able to get it.  I thought that mutt would
> be able to tell GPG to fetch the public key with ID foo from
> pgp.mit.edu.  That answers my questions, thanks guys for all the help!
> Now I just need to meet some of you so I can sign some keys.  (That
> might be hard though, living in CT and all.)  ;-)

Mutt *can* use GPG to fetch it... 

With that auto-key-retrieve setting in your GPG Config file, when you
ask it to verify something signed with a key that is *not* in your
keyring, GPG goes out and finds the key if it's on the keyserver, and
automagically imports it, then it verifies the message.

So don't tell Mutt to import a key, tell it to verify the message as if
you already had the key.

Rob

From mikel at quantecllc.com  Mon Dec  8 09:28:02 2003
From: mikel at quantecllc.com (Michael Luevane)
Date: Mon Dec  8 09:28:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] what is the point of PGP-signed emails?
In-Reply-To: <200312071042.33484.carla@bratgrrl.com>
Message-ID: <008c01c3bdb0$96b1e300$bf00000a@quantecllc.com>

plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org wrote:
> So what's the point, realio and trulio, of using PGP in
> email? I think
> it's a geek affectation. Anyone can generate a key. Anyone
> can paste a
> bunch of stuff in a message that looks like a key. If someone like
> David Mandel posted a message here that said "No more PLUG.
> I'm sick of
> it. We're pulling the PLUG hahahahaaa", it wouldn't matter if it were
> PGP-signed or not- no one would take such a message at face value. We
> would pick up and the phone and go "Yo, David, WTF?"
>
> So, aside from generating endless flame wars over how mail clients
> display a PGP sig, I just don't see the point.

Lots of other good talk, but here's a real-life example of a good reason to
sign your keys:

We had a key signing party down near U of O a few years ago, and this guy
(I'll call him "Bill") was telling us a story about the divorce he was going
through. Seem like the lawyer for his wife was trying to "help" her by
changing the text of the emails that the lawyer got from Bill.

Bill was a fastidious PGP user, signed all his emails. When the lawyer
brought up the changed emails as evidence during divorce procedings, Bill
had him verify the signatures. They didn't verify and Bill told the judge
about the sigs and what it meant.

This is one reason for signatures. For encryption, it's not too different in
concept from an envelope.

From chris at maybe.net  Mon Dec  8 13:22:01 2003
From: chris at maybe.net (Chris Jantzen)
Date: Mon Dec  8 13:22:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] what do you use Emacs for?
In-Reply-To: <200312081233.59622.carla@bratgrrl.com>
References: <200312081233.59622.carla@bratgrrl.com>
Message-ID: <20031208212155.GK19565@maybe.net>

On Mon, Dec 08, 2003 at 12:33:59PM -0800, Carla Schroder wrote:
> I'm curious, given how extensible it is, what do Emacs users do with it, 
> beyond reading email/newsgroups, and editing files?

You mean *strictly* other than editing/coding files? :-)

Like, web, irc, terminal shell, tetris, eliza... :-)

As far as what I *use* it for? I wouldn't code any other way. I have
context-sensitive manpages at my fingertips, doxygen lookups, etc;
function prototype hints, single click file load for #include's, project
file/object/function browsing. I love using it for LaTeX --
auto-complete environment blocks, reftex automatic label management,
x-symbol gui visualization of mathematics, even a microsoft-like
autospell highlight mode.

And, of course, personal customization using a very capable lisp
environment.

I do recognize that probably vim does a lot of the same. I just like
emacs better. I do use vi for tweaking config files (and apparently
writing email, though I'd rather find a better solution with mutt).

-- 
chris kb7rnl =->

From creswick at cs.orst.edu  Mon Dec  8 13:24:02 2003

Subject: [PLUG] what do you use Emacs for?

On Mon, Dec 08, 2003 at 12:33:59PM -0800, Carla Schroder wrote:
> I'm curious, given how extensible it is, what do Emacs users do with it, 
> beyond reading email/newsgroups, and editing files?

I use it for viewing images (auto-image-file-mode), word processing
(latex-mode), writing email (through mutt), file management (dired),
lisp programming -- and running/debugging (lisp-interaction-mode), it
serves as my shell on occasion (M-x shell is handy in this case), the
calendar (M-x calendar)--although not the schedule features--and the
occasional game of tetris (M-x tetris).

I would like to use it as a window manager, but it needs to support
embeded X apps in emacs windows first.

I don't use it to edit config files very often though.. I prefer vi[m]
for that.


-Rogan

The SuSE installation disks on Ebay are illegal if they are copies and
the person providing them charge for the disks. 

It doesn't matter which install method you use. Manual is a bit harder
if you don't know your hardware. All the installs allow you to setup the
disks how you want.

You'll find the manuals can be installed off of the CDs. The are rpms so
you'll need something to install them on. I think most people will find
the install is pretty easy and won't need the manuals until after the
install.

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Mon Dec  8 16:44:02 2003
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Mon Dec  8 16:44:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Anti Virus Software for Linux?
In-Reply-To: <1070929325.2302.44.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <1070929325.2302.44.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <3182-39018@sneakemail.com>

On Mon, 8 Dec 2003, Richard Lidzbarski eikonoklastic-at-comcast.net |PDX Linux| wrote:

> I run Red Hat 9 (will move over to Gentoo soon) and I'm looking for some
> good anti virus software appropriate for the lowly individual PC user.
> Suggestions?

I use the no-cost F-Prot for linux scanner.  Fridrik Skulason, the founder
of Frisk Software, has consistently supported a low or no-cost virus
scanner, kept as up-to-date and complete as anyone else's.

Virus signature updates are available via their FTP site.

If you want a Windows version with real-time resident scanning, it's $29
per year.

http://www.f-prot.com/products/home_use/linux/

  -- Steve

-----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----
Hash: SHA1

On Mon, Dec 08, 2003 at 07:06:19AM -0500, Brian Derr wrote:
> Alright, I get it.  So the sender has to actually attach the public key
> to the email for mutt to be able to get it.

No, you can also set GPG up to automatically fetch keys from
keyservers as I described upthread.

> I thought that mutt would be able to tell GPG to fetch the public
> key with ID foo from pgp.mit.edu.

Mutt passes it off to GPG, and if you have GPG set up as I suggested
upthread, it will get you keys if you don't have them and if they're
on the keyserver.

> Now I just need to meet some of you so I can sign some keys.  (That
> might be hard though, living in CT and all.)  ;-)

Sign keys with people you know locally, and as you and people you have
signed keys for (and so on and so on) sign keys, your web of trust
will grow.  Needless to say, a firm understanding of how it all works
should be considered mandatory before you start signing other people's
keys.

In-Reply-To: <1070871791.24781.19.camel@kat.zotnet.com>
References: <200312071042.33484.carla@bratgrrl.com> <1070871791.24781.19.camel@kat.zotnet.com>

-----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----
Hash: SHA1

On Mon, Dec 08, 2003 at 12:23:11AM -0800, Zot O'Connor wrote:
> As signed email becomes the norm, it can be used to fight spam, allow
> access to lists, and demonstrate reliable transmissions.

I can already see that among OpenPGP users except for fight spam.  You're
asking more than OpenPGP can deliver, there.  OpenPGP will only give you
the same assurance it already does for unknown keys:  It wasn't
altered in transit.  And it won't even do that if they haven't sent
their key to a key server.

> But anyone can test if its a real signature.  Those who do check, will
> know immediately.  Those who don't will not care.  This would be a
> stupid thing to do.  It only tips off more people.

And yet, that very thing was attempted over the summer on some of the
newsgroups I read regularly.  Funny watching all the OpenPGP users
turning around and laughing in the face of that one.

> > So, aside from generating endless flame wars over how mail clients 
> > display a PGP sig, I just don't see the point.
> 
> If all email clients settled this, and they can, then the de facto
> standard could be signed email.

It's already settled, it's just waiting for older and borken clients
to get with the times and implement the standard defined in the RFCs
for this (PGP/MIME).

Bickering over which format is pointless at this point, it's a done
deal.  Those who are developing this stuff have long since had this
flamewar and formalized it.

From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Mon Dec  8 17:42:02 2003

Subject: [PLUG] Damned ISPs! [OT?]
Message-ID: <1070936159.11639.46.camel@dell.linux.box>

I am continually astounded at the sheer lack of intelligence so many
ISPs exhibit.

This morning about about 10AM, Web-ster, my ISP (and only choice for an
ISP), began blocking outbound connections to port 25.  As a result, none
of my emails were getting out.  I didn't realize what was happening
until about 16:30.  I added their SMTP server as a relayhost to my
main.cf at about 16:45 as soon as I had the problem diagnosed.

But... what the *hell* are they thinking?  Are they just trying to screw
with me or what?  I sent a rant to their technical support department,
hopefully I will receive an answer tomorrow.

This ISP just plain sucks.  The speeds suck.  The reliability sucks. 
The only advantages are they're too stupid to set up dhcpd so I get a
static IP and the AUP (which I never actually agreed to) doesn't mention
anything about running servers.  But, still... blocking outbound port
25?!?

Is this common practice?  I have a friend down in Mississippi with
Comcast who has the same problem... he was able to help me quickly
figure out what's up.

*Sigh* ... I'm so disgusted with Web-ster......

Rob

From dmandel at pdxLinux.org  Mon Dec  8 19:01:02 2003
From: dmandel at pdxLinux.org (David Mandel)
Date: Mon Dec  8 19:01:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] what do you use Emacs for?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0312081628590.4872-100000@cohiba.fork.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0312081834510.9616-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com>

Yes, back in the old days I did many things with emacs.

    As well as the programs Dan mentioned, I wrote large complex key
binding system which contained quite a few custom functions that were
lacking in standard emacs.  This key binding system worked well in it's
day and age; but is no longer of value because of major improvements in emacs.

    I also wrote a number of screen oriented data entry programs using
emacs.  These also worked well.  They were designed to edit complex
ASCII files, where it was important to know what field was where and
if a given input value was reasonable.  In addition, the data entry
program computed certain fields based on other fields as the user
entered them.  This was sort a cool application.  At least, my client
like it.  In particular, the client liked the fact that it was much
much faster to use than the traditional data base forms based screens.
It also gave the client more flexibility to do cutting and pasting
and to ditto fields from one record to the next.  In fact, as I recall
I even had fields that could be dittoed with an increment added to it.

    I recall yet another of my emacs applications.  I used emacs
shell and/or telnet mode to run command line programs - especially
MOSS and ArcInfo.  By doing this I could use emacs lisp to write
macros for MOSS and ArcInfo.  ArcInfo comes with it's own scripting
language, called CPL.  However, emacs lisp is faster and much more
powerful than CPL.  This system worked great; but for some reason
I never convinced many users to adopt it.

    In any case,


           NOW JUST DO THESE THINGS WITH VI MY FRIENDS!!


-  EMACS RULES  -  EMACS RULES  -  EMACS RULES  -  EMACS RULES  -


                                                 Dave Mandel

From dmandel at pdxLinux.org  Mon Dec  8 19:16:01 2003
From: dmandel at pdxLinux.org (David Mandel)
Date: Mon Dec  8 19:16:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] what do you use Emacs for?
In-Reply-To: <200312081233.59622.carla@bratgrrl.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0312081909070.9616-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com>

Before I get into too much trouble for bashing vi, I will admit that
I do use and like vi as well as emacs.  vi is compact and fast relative
to emacs.  I prefer vi to emacs for small simple editing tasks where
one isn't going to be in the editor all day.  However, for heavy duty
jobs I prefer emacs.

On Mon, Dec 08, 2003 at 10:31:15AM -0800, Daggett, Steve wrote:
>   I disagree.  It sounds like someone was using crap cameras or too much
> video compression.

No.  It doesn't matter.  Once you hit the limits of the resolution,
that's it.  That's all the better you get.  If you're trying to
identify, say, a tattoo on someone's arm at a weird angle from the
footage, or try to read a license number off a plate someone has
(illegally) put a plastic cover or sprayed some glaring substance
over, an area of 120 pixels is going to be the same 120 pixels no
matter how big you blow it up.

It's not like with analog picture where you can go digitize the video
when you need to, at whatever resolution you need to, and then go nuts
tweaking it until you can make out what you need to.  And if you need
more resolution, just go re-encode from the original.

> Digital cameras have gotten a lot better and come down in price.
> Storage is cheep.  There's no reason that a digital surveillance
> system shouldn't be at least as good as an old analog system.

And yet, you're still limited by the resolution of the camera.  Which
means anybody standing across the room from the camera, when you go to
magnify the image, is going to look like they're on COPS: A blurry,
pixelated picture.

>   It's not just for video.  Some of the V4L projects do motion detection
> with still cameras.  

That's probably your most practical use for digital cameras.
Especially if where you're putting these up is a shop that has them
already for video telephony, just keep enough of the machines always
on to get motion sensor coverage where you want it.

- --

From zot at whiteknighthackers.com  Tue Dec  9 00:36:02 2003
From: zot at whiteknighthackers.com (Zot O'Connor)
Date: Tue Dec  9 00:36:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] what is the point of PGP-signed emails?
In-Reply-To: <20031209012620.GC9506@ursine.ca>
References: <200312071042.33484.carla@bratgrrl.com>
	 <1070871791.24781.19.camel@kat.zotnet.com>
	 <20031209012620.GC9506@ursine.ca>
Message-ID: <1070958699.26545.12.camel@kat.zotnet.com>

On Mon, 2003-12-08 at 17:26, Paul Johnson wrote:
> -----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----
> Hash: SHA1
> 
> On Mon, Dec 08, 2003 at 12:23:11AM -0800, Zot O'Connor wrote:
> > As signed email becomes the norm, it can be used to fight spam, allow
> > access to lists, and demonstrate reliable transmissions.
> 
> I can already see that among OpenPGP users except for fight spam.  You're
> asking more than OpenPGP can deliver, there.  OpenPGP will only give you
> the same assurance it already does for unknown keys:  It wasn't
> altered in transit.  And it won't even do that if they haven't sent
> their key to a key server.

Anytime all mail is authenticated by a user, assumptions can be built
into servers and clients.  The arguments about challenge/response spam
filters go away when you can tell who the user is via a keyserver tied
to something like razor.  Do not underestimate this one.  If you can
test all incoming mail against known friends, unknown but verified by
the keyserver you like/trust, unknown but valid signatures, and known
signatures of spammers, you have a strong case for SPAM ratings. 
Remember this assume signatures are the norm.  Spammer could keep
changing keys, but they would need to do that for each mailing, or until
their key is known.

This happened before when email addresses were harder to fake.  You
could block based on incoming email name with really good accuracy.  

Mail servers can allow relaying based on keys (I assume some do
already).  As this becomes the norm, then the reasons for open relays
start to drop.



> Bickering over which format is pointless at this point, it's a done
> deal.  Those who are developing this stuff have long since had this
> flamewar and formalized it.

Well spend a while on any mail client list and see the complaints. 
Kmail users on evolution's list is prime example.

While there is agreement PGP/MIME is better in general, until the other
clients are fixes, the whining is not such a bad thing.

-- 
Zot O'Connor

http://www.ZotConsulting.com
http://www.WhiteKnightHackers.com

Now that vim is so much more improved than vi, and the linux default
setup makes more sense than freebsd, I find my self stymied by lack of
command history, slightly different regex rules, and some other things. 
But on the whole vim is almost always there.

Oddly gvim and other graphical vi's never seem to work for me.  I want
to cut and paste in a terminal, like a X based terminal, not notepad.

Yes, but you might want to get the source from debian, most of the
patching is probably done.  Any particular reason for wanting to use the
.config from the older kernel?  Custom compiled kernels shouldn't need
an initrd image, you can compile in all the parts that are required for
the kernel to boot successfully. Not that it can't be done, it just
seems that making the kernel with all the parts for your hardware
built-in would be better.

Derek Loree





From heinlein at madboa.com  Tue Dec  9 08:11:02 2003
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Tue Dec  9 08:11:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Damned ISPs! [OT?]
In-Reply-To: <1070936159.11639.46.camel@dell.linux.box>
References: <1070936159.11639.46.camel@dell.linux.box>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0312090759490.7074@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Mon, 8 Dec 2003, AthlonRob wrote:

> This morning about about 10AM, Web-ster, my ISP (and only choice for
> an ISP), began blocking outbound connections to port 25.

As someone else mentioned, EarthLink began doing that a while ago.

Other ISPs have also jumped on the bandwagon, in worse ways. The
outfit that provided Internet connectivity for the OGI faculty retreat
last year *silently* redirected all port-25 traffic to its own mail
server.

At least with a flat-out block you'll eventually get an SMTP error
message. With a silent redirect, there's no recourse. If we hadn't
been testing some SMTP/AUTH stuff, we'd have never realized the
problem -- and had the ISP's server gone down, we wouldn't have
received any notice that the mail hadn't been delivered.

The other thing is that some large ISPs (e.g., AOL) will no longer
accept mail from IP blocks known to contain dynamically assigned
addresses. AOL isn't alone; there are plenty of mail admins on the
mimedefang mailing list who will only accept inbound SMTP connections
from official mail servers on, say, the rr.com or comcast.net IP
blocks.

I really don't care what sort of pseudo-self-justifications virus and
spam writers uses to feel good about themselves. Their activities just
suck. Period.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

From m at pdxlug.org  Tue Dec  9 09:46:01 2003
From: m at pdxlug.org (Matt Alexander)
Date: Tue Dec  9 09:46:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Perl Pipes
Message-ID: <33682.68.110.171.77.1070991937.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>

I'm playing around with pipes in Perl and I want to send something to a FH
then I want the output of that FH to go to a different FH.  Is this
possible?


open UPPER, "|tr '[a-z]' '[A-Z]'";
open LOWER, "|tr '[A-Z]' '[a-z]'";
pipe UPPER, LOWER;
open OUTPUT, ">output.txt";
pipe LOWER, OUTPUT;

print UPPER "up and down, up and down...";

> which appears as a SCSI device.  Is that not right?  

I think that using the old .config may leave you short, there were some
changes to the kernel options from one version to the next.  If the
drivers for the RAID array (and all other essential devices) are
compiled into the kernel (not as modules), then you will not need the
initrd image.  Don't forget to change lilo.conf to reflect the lack of
initrd for the new kernel.  You might want to set up lilo to give you a
selection of kernels to boot from, in case your custom one doesn't work.

Good Luck,

Derek Loree

From zot at whiteknighthackers.com  Tue Dec  9 11:41:02 2003
From: zot at whiteknighthackers.com (Zot O'Connor)
Date: Tue Dec  9 11:41:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] what is the point of PGP-signed emails?
In-Reply-To: <20031209121846.3831bfc9.jason@vancleve.com>
References: <200312071042.33484.carla@bratgrrl.com>
	 <1070871791.24781.19.camel@kat.zotnet.com>
	 <20031209012620.GC9506@ursine.ca> <20031209021551.GE17763@maybe.net>
	 <20031209025128.GB25747@ursine.ca>
	 <20031209121846.3831bfc9.jason@vancleve.com>
Message-ID: <1070998375.26545.45.camel@kat.zotnet.com>

On Tue, 2003-12-09 at 11:18, Jason Van Cleve wrote:
> Quoth Paul Johnson, on Mon, 8 Dec 2003 18:51:28 -0800:
> 
> > > violates the trust given to them by sending spam, their signatures
> > > are revoked. It's a thought, anyways.
> > 
> > Well, their signatures wouldn't be revoked, but everybody could just
> > set their trust level with that person to be untrustable.
> 
> So every client has to maintain a separate list of known spammers?  I
> don't know, the web of trust is a fine idea, but I don't think it is
> strong enough to tackle spam.

No, you subscribe to a list of known spammers (ala razor).  Remember
this is "in the future" where everyone normally signs their email.  Thus
spammers to avoid being easily filtered will have to sign their emails. 

They then have a few choices, 
        Fake the signatures
                This will fail a automated system.
        Sign as a unknown user
                This will raise their spam score.
                Once this is a known spammer it will clinch it
                (razor-PGP)
        Sign as a different user each mail
                This always makes them an unknown and makes it harder to
                send bulk mail.
        Not sign the mail
                The most likely tactic, this will raise their score
                
Currently Spam Assassin can white list people as they send non spam
mails to you.  This slowly builds a negative spam score.  With
signature, this could be 100% on the first time a non-spam mail is
sent.  Thus you will always be sure that the email is from a legit
person.  Once that person starts spamming, then you tag the key, send it
razor-PGP and the account is bad.

Now the razor-PGP idea is a blacklist and has all the issues that all
blacklists have, but it is far more effective than the current
score/weight scheme.

> --Jason Van Cleve

From chris at maybe.net  Tue Dec  9 11:45:03 2003
From: chris at maybe.net (Chris Jantzen)
Date: Tue Dec  9 11:45:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Perl Pipes
In-Reply-To: <33682.68.110.171.77.1070991937.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>
References: <33682.68.110.171.77.1070991937.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>
Message-ID: <20031209194422.GB24287@maybe.net>

On Tue, Dec 09, 2003 at 09:45:37AM -0800, Matt Alexander wrote:
> I'm playing around with pipes in Perl and I want to send something to a FH
> then I want the output of that FH to go to a different FH.  Is this
> possible?
> 
> 
> open UPPER, "|tr '[a-z]' '[A-Z]'";
> open LOWER, "|tr '[A-Z]' '[a-z]'";
> pipe UPPER, LOWER;
> open OUTPUT, ">output.txt";
> pipe LOWER, OUTPUT;
> 
> print UPPER "up and down, up and down...";

pipe() creates two *new* filehandles. It works like the lowlevel
system call of the same name and creates a new unidirectional pipe. To
do what you want with pipe() alone, would require multiple pipes and
forked children (just like C). With higher level piping, if you want
to do something involving constructs like "|tr|", you need to use
IPC::Open2 or Open3. There's probably a module that lets you do what
you wanted more directly, but here's[1] a simpler[2] solution[5]
similar to your problem:

#!/usr/bin/perl -w

use IPC::Open2;
use strict;

my($content) = <>;
open2(\*SUB_OUT, \*IN, "rot13") or die "suspicious!\n";
open2(\*OUT, \*SUB_IN, "wc -l") or die "dangerous!\n";

print IN $content;
close(IN);

my($translated) = <SUB_OUT>;
close(SUB_OUT);

print SUB_IN $translated;
close(SUB_IN);

my($count) = <OUT>;
close(OUT);

print $count;

[1] Use it like this: "perl foo < some_document"
[2] And useless[3]
[3] And not even efficient[4]
[4] But then again, maybe perl helps optimize some of this
[5] "\*OUT" is a convention required for strict because open2 is a
sub, not a native function.[6]
[6] Also notice that the order of close()'s is important. If you don't
close the input on, e.g., rot13, it won't stop reading and flush its
output.

-- 
chris kb7rnl =->

***Dancing Barefoot
Order Number: 6748
Wil Wheaton--blogger, geek, and Star Trek: The Next Generation's Wesley
Crusher--gives us five true tales of life, love, and the absurdities of
Hollywood in "Dancing Barefoot." Far from the usual celebrity tell-all,
"Dancing Barefoot" is a vivid, personal account of Wil's search for his
true self. If you've ever fallen in love, attended a Star Trek convention,
or pondered the meaning of life, you'll find a kindred soul in the pages
of "Dancing Barefoot."
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/barefoot/


***Mac OS X Unwired
Order Number: 5083
"Mac OS X Unwired" is a one-stop, wireless information source for
technically savvy Mac users. The book provides a complete introduction to
all the wireless technologies supported by Mac OS X, including Wi-Fi,
infrared, Bluetooth, and GPRS. If you're considering wireless as an
alternative to cable and DSL, or using wireless to network computers in
your home, office, or on the road, this book will show you the
full-spectrum view of the wireless capabilities of Mac OS X, and how to
get the most out of them.
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/macxunwire/

Chapter 4, "Wi-Fi on the Road," is available online:
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/macxunwire/chapter/index.html


***The Best of The Joy of Tech
Order Number: 5784
Frustrated and frazzled by technology? Or perhaps your cynicism is
starting to wane? This book is a collection of the very best from The Joy
of Tech online series. It also features several new, never-before-seen
comics, exclusive notes from the artists about their work, an appendix of
the JoyPolls, a lexicon of JoyWords, and an introduction by David Pogue.
"The Best of The Joy of Tech" is an oasis of top-notch humor and images
sure to refresh the mind's page and reboot the will to live.
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/bestjoytech/

***Wil Wheaton to Write Three Books for O'Reilly
Any honest computer geek will admit that his obsessive coding is, at
heart, a futile attempt to create a world as cool as those depicted in
science fiction. New evidence of the symbiotic relationship between Sci Fi
and geekdom surfaced, as O'Reilly, the geek publisher-of-record, announced
plans to publish three books by Wil Wheaton, blogger, geek, and the actor
who portrayed Wesley Crusher on Star Trek: The Next Generation. Wil's
first two books, "Dancing Barefoot" and "Just a Geek," are almost
unbearably honest tales of life, love, and the rigors of being an ensign
on the Starship Enterprise.

Take a look at Wil's December 2 blog announcement:
http://wilwheaton.net/

And you can read our press release:
http://press.oreilly.com/pub/pr/1125

***BIND DoS Attack
Noel Davis looks at a denial-of-service attack against BIND and problems
in KDE, GnuPG, screen, Ethereal, FreeRadius, mod_gzip, Pan, detecttr,
OpenCA, EPIC, and libnids.
http://linux.oreillynet.com/pub/a/linux/2003/12/01/insecurities.html


***RouteWord: An Interesting Diversion
Graphs--loosely connected, unordered collections of nodes--are highly
important to computer science. Visualizing graphs is even more important:
think of maps, routes, webs, and any other interconnected relationships.
O'Reilly author Andrew Odewahn explains how he accidentally created a new
type of word puzzle while playing around with graph visualization.
http://www.onlamp.com/pub/a/onlamp/2003/11/26/routewords.html

Throughout the month of December, we're running daily RouteWord puzzles
from Andrew Odewahn. Here's today's puzzle:
http://www.onlamp.com/pub/a/onlamp/2003/12/routeword/index.html
---------------------
Java
---------------------
***Introduction to the Peer-to-Peer Sockets Project
The Peer-to-Peer Sockets project reimplements Java's standard Socket,
ServerSocket, and InetAddress classes to work on the JXTA peer-to-peer
network rather than on the standard TCP/IP network. Brad Neuberg shows how
to configure and set up the P2P Socket libraries to run on your system,
how to create and run P2P server and client sockets, and how to work with
the P2P InetAddress class, and discusses security issues and limitations
in the framework.
http://www.onjava.com/pub/a/onjava/2003/12/03/p2psockets.html


***Java vs. .NET Security, Part 1
Java and .NET address similar code security issues, but which one offers
the best security implementation? Denis Piliptchouk's series starts with a
side-by-side look at how each performs configuration, code verification,
and memory isolation.
http://www.onjava.com/pub/a/onjava/2003/11/26/javavsdotnet.html
---------------------
XML
---------------------
***Five XSLT Basics
This article by Michael Fitzgerald introduces newbies to the five basics
of XSLT 1.0, from what it is to how to get it to work--information you'll
also find in the first chapter of Michael's book, "Learning XSLT."
http://www.xml.com/pub/a/2003/11/26/learnXSLT.html

Learning XSLT
Order Number: 3277
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/learnxslt/index.html

.NET
---------------------
***Creating Your Own Code Snippets with Whidbey
One of the new features found in Visual Studio .NET Whidbey is Insert
Snippets. The Insert Snippets feature allows you to insert commonly-used
code blocks into your project, thereby improving the efficiency of your
development process. Wei-Meng Lee shows you how to add your own snippets
to Whidbey.
http://www.ondotnet.com/pub/a/dotnet/2003/12/01/whidbeysnippets.html

***iPod as Digital Photographer's Best Friend
Yes, the iPod can store thousands of songs. But now you can use it to
upload thousands of pictures too, directly from the memory card. And
thanks to Panther, that's only the beginning of what is sure to become an
indispensable tool for many digital photographers.
http://www.macdevcenter.com/pub/a/mac/2003/12/02/photo_ipod.html


***Collaborative Editing with Rendezvous
Apple's adoption of Zeroconf networking (branded as "Rendezvous") has
opened the door to new ways of sharing information on local networks. In
this article, Wei Meng Lee shows you how to use two collaborative editing
tools: SubEthaEdit and iStorm.
http://www.macdevcenter.com/pub/a/mac/2003/12/02/rendezvous.html

On Tue, 2003-12-09 at 12:45, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   Can someone suggest where I get the vendor and product codes for this
> puppy? Also, I do not have usb-serial.o on my new laptop; only usb-serial.h.
> However, I do have /dev/ttyUSB0 and /dev/ttySUB1.
> 

They will be in dmesg or /var/log/message when linux sees the usb device
attach.

Getting latest hotplug, http://hotplug.sf.net, should help.  Really, it
may very well take care of all your issues.

The module that gets built is usbserial.o (no -).  

'locate usbserial' shoudl find it.  Otherwise you will need to compile
the kernel module.  In RH9 I see it just fine.
        /lib/modules/2.4.20-20.9/kernel/drivers/usb/serial/usbserial.o


>   What I want to connect is my digital camera: an Olympus D-340L. Yes, it's
> an antique, but it does all I need it to do.
> 

I take it the laptop does not have a serial port at all?

> All suggestions appreciated,
> 
> Rich

On Tue, 2003-12-09 at 08:10, Paul Heinlein wrote:
> On Mon, 8 Dec 2003, AthlonRob wrote:
> 
> > This morning about about 10AM, Web-ster, my ISP (and only choice for
> > an ISP), began blocking outbound connections to port 25.
> 
> As someone else mentioned, EarthLink began doing that a while ago.
> 

Actually this is done by the dial up POP people as well.  RADUIS has the
fields in it now to allow connections to the accounts specified SMTP
servers, but I could not get Earthlink to accept mine.  I didn't fight
very hard.

The way I know this is done by the POP not the ISP is that earthlink
will allow SMTP at *some* dialups and not others.  That was so much to
remote troubleshoot to the VP of sales.....

Shortly after that a Virtual ISP I help admin had to fill those fields
out in Radius.....




> Other ISPs have also jumped on the bandwagon, in worse ways. The
> outfit that provided Internet connectivity for the OGI faculty retreat
> last year *silently* redirected all port-25 traffic to its own mail
> server.

Worse is tmobile/starbucks hotspots.  They say it works, but they hijack
the stream, and send the mail themselves while foobaring the DNS.  This
means sites like mine that refuse mail servers with bad DNS in helo, it
rejects them.

I have seen this in Lake Oswego and Chicago.  

The best is T-Mobile states something that leads tech-savvy people
believe they are sending via the users ISP's account....

> 
> They will be in dmesg or /var/log/message when linux sees the usb device
> attach.

An alternative: mount -t usbfs none /proc/bus/usb (or make sure it's
in /etc/fstab) and then get the usb utilities and issue "lsusb". Kinda
like lspci.

I'm fairly certain you need to the mount to make hotplug work right, too.

From ed at alcpress.com  Tue Dec  9 13:24:01 2003
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)
Date: Tue Dec  9 13:24:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] A dilema
Message-ID: <1071005607.16708.38.camel@nat.alcpress.com>

I need some opinions to solve a moral and business
dilemma.

I have a consulting customer that runs a Windows shop.
At least two of their Windows computers have been
attacked and we've reinstalled Windows each time. They
then install their Norton software on the computer and
declare it secure. Surely, nothing bad should happen if
Norton is installed, they think.

We've replaced their Windows 2000 server with Linux acting
as a firewall and router so we now have control over that
part of the network but we have no control over desktop
computers running Windows. They run Outlook and I suspect
this is how they're being attacked.

The main problem is my customer's attitude. They do not
care about security if it's the least bit inconvenient.
Worse, they don't care about the privacy of their customer
data. Their customers are individuals who would be devastated
by identity theft. Their personal data is stored on this
company's server and there's no effort to protect it.

As long as attackers don't delete their data files, this
company doesn't seem to care if their data files leak out to
the Internet. They would be unwilling to spend the money to
have me secure their computers. 

I'm concerned about numerous issues. Primarily, I see this
as criminal negligence and I don't know what to do about it.
Secondarily, I'm wondering about the risk of being named as
a defendant should one of their customers be victimized in
some way.

Ed

From heinlein at madboa.com  Tue Dec  9 13:30:14 2003
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Tue Dec  9 13:30:14 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Damned ISPs! [OT?]
In-Reply-To: <1071003473.26545.71.camel@kat.zotnet.com>
References: <1070936159.11639.46.camel@dell.linux.box> 
 <Pine.LNX.4.58.0312090759490.7074@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
 <1071003473.26545.71.camel@kat.zotnet.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0312091323380.7074@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Tue, 9 Dec 2003, Zot O'Connor wrote:

> > Other ISPs have also jumped on the bandwagon, in worse ways. The
> > outfit that provided Internet connectivity for the OGI faculty
> > retreat last year *silently* redirected all port-25 traffic to its
> > own mail server.
>
> Worse is tmobile/starbucks hotspots.  They say it works, but they
> hijack the stream, and send the mail themselves while foobaring the
> DNS.  This means sites like mine that refuse mail servers with bad
> DNS in helo, it rejects them.

I don't even bother using sendmail when I'm on a laptop because I hate
having to tail the mail log just to see if what did and didn't get
delivered.

Instead, I have SMTP/AUTH over TLS enabled on port 587 both at home
and at work. If an ISP did hijack the connection, I'd know because
pine would complain about the cert. :-) Plus, if the addressee's MX is
down, the message spools on a machine that will almost surely be
powered on and connected to the Internet when the queue is run again.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>



From jason at vancleve.com  Tue Dec  9 13:31:02 2003
From: jason at vancleve.com (Jason Van Cleve)
Date: Tue Dec  9 13:31:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] what is the point of PGP-signed emails?
In-Reply-To: <1070998375.26545.45.camel@kat.zotnet.com>
References: <200312071042.33484.carla@bratgrrl.com>
	<1070871791.24781.19.camel@kat.zotnet.com>
	<20031209012620.GC9506@ursine.ca>
	<20031209021551.GE17763@maybe.net>
	<20031209025128.GB25747@ursine.ca>
	<20031209121846.3831bfc9.jason@vancleve.com>
	<1070998375.26545.45.camel@kat.zotnet.com>
Message-ID: <20031209143019.0462505b.jason@vancleve.com>

Quoth Zot O'Connor, on Tue, 09 Dec 2003 11:32:55 -0800:

>         Sign as a unknown user
>                 This will raise their spam score.
>                 Once this is a known spammer it will clinch it

How long would that take?

>         Sign as a different user each mail
>                 This always makes them an unknown and makes it harder
>                 to send bulk mail.

Why would that make it harder?  Keys can be generated easily enough, and
spamming from multiple servers (as is often done using RATs) would make
it even easier.

>         Not sign the mail
>                 The most likely tactic, this will raise their score

Why score unsigned emails at all, since mere addresses can be spoofed? 
Aren't unsigned emails filtered in this hypothetical future?

I still don't see a spam solution here.  For one thing, it seems a
single key could be used for thousands of UCEs before being effectively
blacklisted.  For another, even using a different key for each email
does not seem impracticable.

--Jason Van Cleve

--
"Out of environment space" -- MS-DOS Command Interpreter

2.96 and GCC 3.2.1 to the already existing GCC 2.95 Slackware 8.1
shipped with.

Rob

From felix.1 at canids.net  Tue Dec  9 13:44:02 2003
From: felix.1 at canids.net (Felix Lee)
Date: Tue Dec  9 13:44:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Perl Pipes 
In-Reply-To: <20031209194422.GB24287@maybe.net> 
    on Tue, 09 Dec 2003 11:44:22 PST
    from Chris Jantzen <chris@maybe.net> 
References: <33682.68.110.171.77.1070991937.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>  <20031209194422.GB24287@maybe.net> 
Message-ID: <20031209214310.87A3C15882B@kanga.canids>

Chris Jantzen <chris at maybe.net>:
> IPC::Open2 or Open3. There's probably a module that lets you do what
> you wanted more directly, but here's[1] a simpler[2] solution[5]
> similar to your problem:

your solution deadlocks.

> open2(\*SUB_OUT, \*IN, "rot13") or die "suspicious!\n";
> print IN $content;
> close(IN);
> my($translated) = <SUB_OUT>;
> close(SUB_OUT);

rot13 doesn't have to slurp all the input before writing output.
if $content is large, say more than 40k, then the 'print' will
block waiting for 'rot13' to read, and 'rot13' will block waiting
for perl to read.

pipefitting is nontrivial, and it's also a solved problem.  just
let the shell do it.
    open OUT, "| program1 | program2 > file.out";
unless you really want to handle the pipefitting yourself.

some reasons you might want to do it yourself
    error handling
    problems safely quoting args for the shell
    no shell
can't think of anything else offhand.
--

>   According to the linux-usb.org USB-Guide, I need to "turn on USB Serial
> Converter support, and then select whichever of the various particular
> drivers you need. The Generic Serial Driver can be used with a wide range of
> converters, by specifying the vendor and product ID codes when you load the
> USB serial converter module: insmod usb-serial.o vendor=0xVVVV

What happens when you plug the device in?  Usually USB devices, even if
they have no drivers will still load their identifying codes (that is
how hotplug knows which drivers to load for the device).  Check syslog,
or console for the output.

In /etc/fstab:

none /proc/bus/usb usbfs defaults 0 0

But make sure it's after the normal /proc. :-)

(On Debian the hotplug package handles this all implicitly, in case
you were and we're doing too much.)

From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Tue Dec  9 13:47:03 2003
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)

Subject: [PLUG] A dilema
In-Reply-To: <1071005607.16708.38.camel@nat.alcpress.com>

On Tue, 2003-12-09 at 13:33, Ed Sawicki wrote:
> I need some opinions to solve a moral and business
> dilemma.
> 
> I have a consulting customer that runs a Windows shop.
> At least two of their Windows computers have been
> attacked and we've reinstalled Windows each time. They
> then install their Norton software on the computer and
> declare it secure. Surely, nothing bad should happen if
> Norton is installed, they think.

Don't you just love that attitude?  In my experience, Norton is one of
the worst players in the AV field.  It is somewhat unreliable, it
detects fewer things than McAfee or PC-Cillin, and it cannot be trusted
to automatically update itself as some others can be.

> We've replaced their Windows 2000 server with Linux acting
> as a firewall and router so we now have control over that
> part of the network but we have no control over desktop
> computers running Windows. They run Outlook and I suspect
> this is how they're being attacked.

Is this server running an email server, as well?  While not quite on the
business/ethical side of things... but rather on the technical end - you
could quite effectively use this to filter incoming content or viruses. 
Even if you aren't running the SMTP stuff yourself, you can capture POP3
and scan it.

If you're running the SMTP stuff yourself, go get AMaViSd-New and
ClamAV.  As we discussed in the "Damned ISPs" thread, it's pretty easy
to silently force all outbound SMTP connections through the scanning
SMTP server.

POP3VScan, I think is the software that can be used to act as a POP3
proxy, filtering things through a virus scanner.  I have a friend who is
attempting to branch the thing after adding support for SpamAssassin
(making it as effective as Postfix+AMaViS when you are not running your
own mail server).  I can look up specifics on that if you wish.

If you aren't running a transparent Squid proxy on their gateway, you
may look in to that.  It will speed up web browsing for them and offer
an easy alternative to local ad-zapping software.  They could also
filter out sites they don't want their customers connecting to.  There's
also an OAV software program called 'Squid-vscan' which will allow you
to scan all HTTP traffic for viruses.

I have experience with most of the above (just not the POP3 stuff,
really) if you decide to go forward with it and need a hand...

> The main problem is my customer's attitude. They do not
> care about security if it's the least bit inconvenient.
> Worse, they don't care about the privacy of their customer
> data. Their customers are individuals who would be devastated
> by identity theft. Their personal data is stored on this
> company's server and there's no effort to protect it.

There has to be somebody in the office with a Clue or somebody who might
respond well to a clue-stick-beating...

If their customer data leaked, and they have a decently sized customer
base, they surely must realize if criminal charges were not filed, they
would at the very least come out of the thing with a black eye and many
lost customers.

> As long as attackers don't delete their data files, this
> company doesn't seem to care if their data files leak out to
> the Internet. They would be unwilling to spend the money to
> have me secure their computers. 
> 
> I'm concerned about numerous issues. Primarily, I see this
> as criminal negligence and I don't know what to do about it.
> Secondarily, I'm wondering about the risk of being named as
> a defendant should one of their customers be victimized in
> some way.

I don't know that I would call it criminally negligent, but I suppose it
depends on the DA.  In Portland, I guess one really never knows.  Maybe
ol' Cats will decide to jump in and make sure she gets a few seconds on
the news.  *Especially* if there are any African Americans involved.

If you present them with your point of view that their setup is
insecure, and they need to do this, this, this, and that to secure it...
and they refuse you, I really can't see any likelyhood of you being
named as a defendant.  Even if you say nothing at all, I don't see it as
being very likely.

If I were you, I would just be extremely sure your point of view that
what they are doing is not good is heard, even at the risk of
potentially losing a customer...

Rob

> The main problem is my customer's attitude. They do not care about
> security if it's the least bit inconvenient. Worse, they don't care
> about the privacy of their customer data. Their customers are

Some discussions that might help:

http://ask.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=02/05/21/1836256
http://ask.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=02/12/13/0333231

And this might provide some guidance:

http://sageweb.sage.org/resources/publications/code_of_ethics.html

As a consultant you have the advantage that you can walk away easier than
if you were an employee.  Unfortunately, you also have the disadvantage
that they probably value your opinions even less than usual.

One thought that might help get their attention-- go see a lawyer and
draft up an exclusion of liability which basically states that you KNOW
there are massive security problems and have been prevented from repairing
them.  Have the company assume any liability for damages which might be
brought against you and have the paper signed by an officer of the
company, preferably the CEO.

I'm pretty sure you can't reassign liability for criminal charges, so if
it's really criminally negligent-- get out fast.

  -- Steve



From sasha_romanosky at yahoo.com  Tue Dec  9 14:04:02 2003
From: sasha_romanosky at yahoo.com (Sasha Romanosky)
Date: Tue Dec  9 14:04:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] A dilema
In-Reply-To: <1071006243.1076.8.camel@linuxhans>
Message-ID: <004801c3bea0$2839b060$6401a8c0@laptop>

I think you'll always find there are inconsistencies when dealing with
others regarding infosec; they'll have their biases and approach and
you'll have yours. I don't believe the solution lies in forcing them to
change at any cost (assuming you still want to maintain a relationship),
but to find a way to manage the situation. 

One such solution might be to outline exactly what you think the the
threats are to the systems and their vulnerabilities and asses what you
feel the overall risks are. Provide them the information, obtain some
acknowledgement that they've read and understood it, then let them
decide on a course of action. That is consulting, after all. 

Ideally, they become more aware, you become absolved, and you maintain
your customer. 

Hope that helps.

cheers,
Sasha

modules).

appropriate is user space.  Often it loads to right modules and sets up
mounts.  It is automagic.  So either it does the trick, or not.

From barryb at proaxis.com  Tue Dec  9 14:58:02 2003
From: barryb at proaxis.com (Bill Barry)
Date: Tue Dec  9 14:58:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] USB serial support
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0312091407370.30860@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0312091233070.30860@salmo.appl-ecosys.com> <1071006404.2735.24.camel@fastlinux.homenet> <Pine.LNX.4.56.0312091407370.30860@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <20031209225710.GA11142@edge>

On Tue, Dec 09, 2003 at 02:12:58PM -0800, Rich Shepard wrote:
> 
>   When I type 'lsusb' with the camera connected via the adapter I see:
> 
> Bus 002 Device 001: ID 0000:0000 Virtual Hub
> Bus 002 Device 002: ID 054c:0069 Sony Corp. Memorystick MSC-U03 Reader
> Bus 001 Device 001: ID 0000:0000 Virtual Hub
> Bus 001 Device 002: ID 0b39:0421
> 
>   The bottom line is new so I think I'm getting there.
> 

That last line for ID 0b39:0421 is the device id for 
the usb to serial adapter produced by
Omnidirectional Control Technology Inc. 
http://www.octinc.com.tw/products/usb_to_serial.html

looking through the kernel, this device is supported
by the ftdi_sio driver http://ftdi-usb-sio.sourceforge.net/
I don't know if you have to explicity load this module 
or if usbserial loads it for you, but you might try
modprobe ftdi_sio

Bill Barry

Yeah, plugging it in changes everything. As has been mentioned, the
last line is your convertor.

> > (On Debian the hotplug package handles this all implicitly, in case
> > you were and we're doing too much.)
> 
>   I don't know that hotplug's loaded or is automatically loaded. I'm in
> completely unfamiliar waters here.

Various distributions have support daemons, but ultimately how it
works is that the kernel itself issues a /sbin/hotplug command on
hotplug event. If the script is present and does something fine, if
not, fine. (This is kind of like how modules used to work.)

> Bus 001 Device 002: ID 0b39:0421  
> Device Descriptor:
>   bLength                18
>   bDescriptorType         1
>   bcdUSB               1.10
>   bDeviceClass            0 Interface
>   bDeviceSubClass         0 
>   bDeviceProtocol         0 
>   bMaxPacketSize0         8
>   idVendor           0x0b39 
>   idProduct          0x0421 
>   bcdDevice            2.00
>   iManufacturer           1 Generic
>   iProduct                2 USB to Serial Converter
>   iSerial                 3 OCB9C01Z
>   bNumConfigurations      1

Notice the product class. :-)

It does sound like if you follow Zot's advice on permissions and the
module is getting loaded correctly by hotplug, then you're in the home
stretch.

 You can remove this file after you've read it, of course... (after
 all, it IS your home directory)
 
 Your home directory is readable by anyone on the system.  It is
 configured that way ON PURPOSE.  Think of ~ as your "front porch",
 where you may greet guests, or leave things for them to pick up when
 you are not home.
 
 The ~/Drop_Box directory is writeable by anyone, and setgid to your
 personal group.  This way, anyone with access to the system may drop
 a file in there for you.  You will have full permissions on that file
 (and so will they).  Hopefully this won't be abused --- we intend to

 local convention.

From zot at whiteknighthackers.com  Tue Dec  9 16:49:01 2003
From: zot at whiteknighthackers.com (Zot O'Connor)
Date: Tue Dec  9 16:49:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] what is the point of PGP-signed emails?
In-Reply-To: <20031209143019.0462505b.jason@vancleve.com>
References: <200312071042.33484.carla@bratgrrl.com>
	 <1070871791.24781.19.camel@kat.zotnet.com>
	 <20031209012620.GC9506@ursine.ca> <20031209021551.GE17763@maybe.net>
	 <20031209025128.GB25747@ursine.ca>
	 <20031209121846.3831bfc9.jason@vancleve.com>
	 <1070998375.26545.45.camel@kat.zotnet.com>
	 <20031209143019.0462505b.jason@vancleve.com>
Message-ID: <1071016882.26545.224.camel@kat.zotnet.com>

On Tue, 2003-12-09 at 13:30, Jason Van Cleve wrote:
> Quoth Zot O'Connor, on Tue, 09 Dec 2003 11:32:55 -0800:
> 
> >         Sign as a unknown user
> >                 This will raise their spam score.
> >                 Once this is a known spammer it will clinch it
> 
> How long would that take?

Minutes to days.  I've seen some spam get register minutes after it was
detected.

Does it matter how long?  As long as the time period is less than the
point in time when 100% of the mail is read by victims, then it works. 
If you want, you can hold all unknown mail for a period of time (2 hours
as a guess) until the peak time (when the spammer key is mostly likely
identified and has been reported to the razor-PGP servers).

> 
> >         Sign as a different user each mail
> >                 This always makes them an unknown and makes it harder
> >                 to send bulk mail.
> 
> Why would that make it harder?  Keys can be generated easily enough, and
> spamming from multiple servers (as is often done using RATs) would make
> it even easier.

Oh come on.  By definition it is harder than what spammer can currently
do.  

1)  It forces them to send 1 mail per user.  This greatly increases
overheard *per* mail.  Most spammers still bulk send their mail.

2)  It makes them calculate keys per mail, and sigs per mail. Even
milliseconds adds up when we are talking millions of mails.

3)  It may even make them have to keep those keys around.  If the return
contact is not via web/phone, they have a logistics issue.

4)  All of these processes leave huge forensics trails.

One of the main ways to attack spammer is to penny them to death.  The
average person rarely *sends* less than 100 mails a day.  By making it
troublesome to *generate* and *send* that many mails, but not impact the
per human-generated mail experience (i.e. we do not care about
milliseconds).  This is what challenge-response does.  It is a minor
(for some, major for me) pain in the ass for humans to do once in a
while.  It is currently not worth doing for spammers.


> 
> >         Not sign the mail
> >                 The most likely tactic, this will raise their score
> 
> Why score unsigned emails at all, since mere addresses can be spoofed? 
> Aren't unsigned emails filtered in this hypothetical future?
> 

filtering == scoring.  You can score unsigned mail at 100% spam (raise
the spam score above the threshold, or rank them against current style
filters.  My large addressbook has been ported to SP and everyone added
with a non-spam bonus (negative score).  This means the notes from my
friends which look like spam, are protected.


> 
> --Jason Van Cleve

-- 
Zot O'Connor

http://www.ZotConsulting.com
http://www.WhiteKnightHackers.com

*worries* to the client in a way that he knows you are documenting.

On Tuesday 09 December 2003 1:33 pm, Ed Sawicki wrote:
<snip> 
> The main problem is my customer's attitude. They do not
> care about security if it's the least bit inconvenient.
> Worse, they don't care about the privacy of their customer
> data. Their customers are individuals who would be devastated
> by identity theft. Their personal data is stored on this
> company's server and there's no effort to protect it.
> 
> As long as attackers don't delete their data files, this
> company doesn't seem to care if their data files leak out to
> the Internet. They would be unwilling to spend the money to
> have me secure their computers. 
> 
> I'm concerned about numerous issues. Primarily, I see this
> as criminal negligence and I don't know what to do about it.
> Secondarily, I'm wondering about the risk of being named as
> a defendant should one of their customers be victimized in
> some way.

For me, there's a bigger issue here- if they're not going to listen to 
you, and take your advice, why do you want them for a customer? 
Especially over an issue this important. I would run, not walk, away 
from them. 

As far as potential liability, it does not matter how good a contract 
you have, and how rock-solid your disclaimers of responsibility are. If 
someone wants to include you in a lawsuit, you're hosed, even if you 
win. Lawsuits, even suits that go nowhere, cost a tremendous amount of 
time and energy, as well as money. Instead of being able to run your 
business and have life, your life gets eaten up.

IMO, it's not worth it. I would bid them farewell, and document why. I 
think you need to put your concerns in writing, just in case someone 
down the road gets mad and sics the lawyers on them. It could still 
rebound on you, so CYA well on the way out.

From greg at kroah.com  Tue Dec  9 17:07:01 2003
From: greg at kroah.com (Greg KH)
Date: Tue Dec  9 17:07:01 2003
Subject: [Fwd: [PLUG] USB serial support]
In-Reply-To: <1071002981.26545.60.camel@kat.zotnet.com>
References: <1071002981.26545.60.camel@kat.zotnet.com>
Message-ID: <20031210002815.GA2171@kroah.com>

>   I just purchased a USB->serial converter manufactured (or, at least sold)
> under the brand name "SIIG". No model number.
> 
>   According to the linux-usb.org USB-Guide, I need to "turn on USB Serial
> Converter support, and then select whichever of the various particular
> drivers you need. The Generic Serial Driver can be used with a wide range of
> converters, by specifying the vendor and product ID codes when you load the
> USB serial converter module: insmod usb-serial.o vendor=0xVVVV
> product-0xPPPP, where you need to change the VVVV and PPPP to match your
> device."
> 
>   Can someone suggest where I get the vendor and product codes for this
> puppy? Also, I do not have usb-serial.o on my new laptop; only usb-serial.h.
> However, I do have /dev/ttyUSB0 and /dev/ttySUB1.

Ick, no, do not use the generic usb serial driver.  Almost NO ONE should
use that driver for a real usb serial device.

Instead, use the driver that is for your device.  What does
/proc/bus/usb/devices show with your device plugged in?

Oh, and there is no such thing as "usb-serial.o" anymore, that's quite
old docs.  It's usbserial.o (usbserial.ko for 2.6).  Just modprobe it
and away you go:
	modprobe usbserial

And on all "modern" distros, the hotplug scripts would just
automatically load the proper driver for your device when it is plugged
in.  Why isn't this happening for you?  Are you using a custom kernel?
An old distro?

greg k-h

anywhere, and don't leave services you don't use installed.

[Discussions of blocked port 25 ...]

I am on Comcast, and it is my only option.  I am not suffering from
blocked ports, and my SMTP out goes through smtp.comcast.net, so this
is not a problem for me - yet.  But the Comcast TOS permits them 
restricting damned near everything, so I assume I am living on borrowed
time.

I talked with a fellow over at Pacifier, and they have a stack of old
Cobalt Raq3's that they aren't using.  They would be willing to fire one
up and rent it to me for a co-location server for a pretty reasonable
price, with a static IP.  My thought is that I could set up an inbound
VPN to the Raq3 (from/to any ports I want, yes? Comcast can't block 
outbound requests to port 80, right?), so I could run my services
through that Raq3.  I see no reason why that connection couldn't be
shared among trustworthy people, with a number of domains terminating
at that single static IP.

BTW, a Raq3 is a P100 with a 15GB disk, and runs Redhat 6 .  I imagine
it could be convinced to run a modern, non-graphic Fedora or Debian
without a great amount of work.   As it is, it runs Apache and has
a pretty decent set of apps on it;  I assume that they are old and
full of security holes, though.  Perhaps the distro can merely be
updated.

I don't have the spare cycles to lead a project like this, but if 
someone else wanted to pursue it I could kick in some labor and some
time.  

Keith

On Tue, Dec 09, 2003 at 01:46:29PM -0800, AthlonRob wrote:

> Even if you aren't running the SMTP stuff yourself, you can capture POP3
> and scan it.

Fetchmail is your friend.  It makes it so you can work with mail like
it's being received via SMTP.

> If you're running the SMTP stuff yourself, go get AMaViSd-New and
> ClamAV.  As we discussed in the "Damned ISPs" thread, it's pretty easy
> to silently force all outbound SMTP connections through the scanning
> SMTP server.

iptables is your friend.  Also good in combination with adzapper and
squid to set up a transparent, caching and adzapping proxy.

> If you aren't running a transparent Squid proxy on their gateway, you
> may look in to that.  It will speed up web browsing for them and offer
> an easy alternative to local ad-zapping software.  They could also
> filter out sites they don't want their customers connecting to. 

Until a couple years ago, adzapper's license absolutely prohibited
using the software for censorship purposes.  It's now under the BSD
license, but the developer still tells you not to use it for
censorship.
http://adzapper.sourceforge.net/

> There's also an OAV software program called 'Squid-vscan' which will
> allow you to scan all HTTP traffic for viruses.

Ooh, that sounds like a good idea.  Debian package?

On Tue, Dec 09, 2003 at 04:42:14PM -0800, Russ Johnson wrote:
> Where is this specified? Where in Oregon Law does it say that I can't
> have a clear plastic license plate cover?



> Another question I can't find the answer to in any O.R.S. is, where does
> it say I must have a front license plate?

It helps to know the state calls them "registration plates."  The way
it reads to me is you get issued a certain number of plates, you have
to mount both where they're plainly visible (and not covered or
vandalized with shellac, or in the case of front plates, thrown on the
dashboard).  Use your head: Why bother having license plates if you're
going to hide them?

http://www.leg.state.or.us/ors/803.html


803.525 Number of plates issued. The Department of Transportation
    shall issue two registration plates for every vehicle that is
    registered by the department except as otherwise provided in this
    section. Upon renewal or when otherwise provided under ORS
    803.555, the department may issue stickers in lieu of or in
    addition to registration plates. The following shall be issued
    plates as described:

(1) Only one registration plate shall be issued for a moped,
    motorcycle, trailer, antique vehicle or vehicle of special
    interest registered by the department.

(2) Only one plate shall be issued for a camper that is
    registered. Stickers may be issued in lieu of a plate.

803.540 Failure to display plates; exceptions; penalty. (1) A person
    commits the offense of failure to display registration plates if
    the person operates, on the highways of this state, any vehicle or
    camper that has been assigned registration plates by this state
    and the registration plates assigned to the vehicle or camper are
    displayed in a manner that violates any of the following:

(a) The plate must be displayed on the rear of the vehicle, if only
    one plate is required.

(b) Plates must be displayed on the front and rear of the vehicle if
    two plates are required.

(c) The plates must be in plain view and so as to be read easily by
    the public.

(d) The plate must not be any plate that does not entitle the holder
    thereof to operate the vehicle upon the highways.

(2) A person is not in violation of this section if the person is
    operating a vehicle or camper under and in accordance with the
    requirements for any of the following:

(a) A temporary application permit issued under ORS 803.615.

(b) An agent temporary registration permit issued under ORS 803.625.

(c) Provisions established under ORS 826.007, 826.009 or 826.011 for
    the display of registration plates or other evidence of
    registration on vehicles that are proportionally registered under
    ORS 826.009 or 826.011.

(3) The offense described in this section, failure to display
    registration plates, is a Class D traffic violation. [1983 c.338
    261; 1985 c.668 13; 1989 c.43 28; 1995 c.383 -6]


Also, what legitimate reason is there not to have a front license
plate?  Makes your vehicle easier to identify from the front if it's
stolen and/or involved in a crime, so what drawbacks could there
possibly be by having it there?

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Tue Dec  9 20:45:03 2003
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Tue Dec  9 20:45:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Notebook accessory (USB->Serial adapter)
Message-ID: <20031210044304.GA2357@gate.kl-ic.com>

Rich writes:

> > Which USB->serial adapter did you get?
>
>   The brand is SIIG. It has a DB-9 female on one end and a USB male on the
> other end. There may well be some sort of intelligence built into the DB-9
> case, but I have no idea what it might be. It's a model US2308 and comes
> with a mini-cdrom for winduhs and macs. Nothing on their Web site that
> suggests anything about a chip or whatever. It does support USB-1.1 so I
> imagine that it's back-compatible with USB-2.0.

I bought a Siig USB2 board from Fry's once - never did get it to work with
Linux - in fact, it locked up the system.  I don't know whether that was
(1) Fry's repackaged defective junk, (2) Siig incompatability, (3) error
between keyboard and chair.  But if a smart fellow like you can't get
your USB adapter running with the help of all the smart people here, it
may be problem (1) or (2) above.

Note that some cheaper USB controllers are designed to load their firmware
over the USB bus (and the more expensive ones load their firmware the same
way and put it in NVRam) .  So it may be that the unit will never work 
unless it talks to a fancy driver available only for windoze.

I hope that is not too discouraging - you have the thing working with
just a bit more work - but if you keep having troubles you may want to
try the thing with a windoze box;  if it doesn't work there, you've
been Fry'd.

Keith

> Also, what legitimate reason is there not to have a front license
> plate?  Makes your vehicle easier to identify from the front if it's

> possibly be by having it there?

If you happen to be a speeder who believes he is above the law so long
as he can get away with it, having a front license plate makes it much
easier for the police to identify you as speeding.  Laser speed guns
work quite well on front plates.  Photo radar, AFAIK, only takes a
picture of the front of your car.

Rob

From jason at vancleve.com  Tue Dec  9 21:18:02 2003
From: jason at vancleve.com (Jason Van Cleve)
Date: Tue Dec  9 21:18:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] what is the point of PGP-signed emails?
In-Reply-To: <1071016882.26545.224.camel@kat.zotnet.com>
References: <200312071042.33484.carla@bratgrrl.com>
	<1070871791.24781.19.camel@kat.zotnet.com>
	<20031209012620.GC9506@ursine.ca>
	<20031209021551.GE17763@maybe.net>
	<20031209025128.GB25747@ursine.ca>
	<20031209121846.3831bfc9.jason@vancleve.com>
	<1070998375.26545.45.camel@kat.zotnet.com>
	<20031209143019.0462505b.jason@vancleve.com>
	<1071016882.26545.224.camel@kat.zotnet.com>
Message-ID: <20031209221720.3313f4fe.jason@vancleve.com>

Quoth Zot O'Connor, on Tue, 09 Dec 2003 16:41:22 -0800:

> Does it matter how long?  As long as the time period is less than the
> point in time when 100% of the mail is read by victims, then it works.

Er, if a spammer can pump out 100,000 ads in an hour, but it takes days
to identify it, then "it works" doesn't mean much overall.

> If you want, you can hold all unknown mail for a period of time (2
> hours as a guess) until the peak time (when the spammer key is mostly
> likely identified and has been reported to the razor-PGP servers).

Two hours for a process which may take two days?  Sounds like a lot of
inconvenience just to break off a little corner of spam traffic, doesn't
it?

> > Why would that make it harder?  Keys can be generated easily enough,
> > and spamming from multiple servers (as is often done using RATs)
> > would make it even easier.
> 
> Oh come on.  By definition it is harder than what spammer can
> currently do.  

Which hardly means it will slow down spam appreciably.

> 1)  It forces them to send 1 mail per user.  This greatly increases
> overheard *per* mail.  Most spammers still bulk send their mail.

> 2)  It makes them calculate keys per mail, and sigs per mail. Even
> milliseconds adds up when we are talking millions of mails.

Why is that?  I thought only the body of the message is signed.

> 3)  It may even make them have to keep those keys around.  If the
> return contact is not via web/phone, they have a logistics issue.

Not sure what this means, sorry.  They'll be creating arbitrary keys
just to get through filters.  The contact method won't change.

> 4)  All of these processes leave huge forensics trails.

How?  A single virus can be written to gen' keys and send spam from a
compromised host.

> One of the main ways to attack spammer is to penny them to death.  The

Great theory, like charging everyone a fraction of a penny for each
email sent.  Thing is, spam is sent anonymously from hijacked servers. 
(RATs are generating a third of it, for example.)  So spammers won't
really feel it.

--Jason Van Cleve

--
Quidquid latine dictum sit, altum videtur.

From alex at daniloff.com  Tue Dec  9 22:29:01 2003
From: alex at daniloff.com (Alex Daniloff)
Date: Tue Dec  9 22:29:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] License plates and covers.
In-Reply-To: <1071032852.1313.33.camel@dell.linux.box>
References: <05AD3C7EEA42D311809300902785AC8A07FD4371@eft01ms01.eft.fiserv.net> <20031210034933.GW31122@ursine.ca> <1071032852.1313.33.camel@dell.linux.box>
Message-ID: <200312091027.54974.alex@daniloff.com>

If you apply thin layer of the transparent acrylic enamel mixed with
Pb2O3 or Pb3O4 onto your license plate, it will reliably dissipate 
laser radar beam in a pretty wide range. So you won't get a ticket. 
This coated license plate looks like a regular one. 
The proportion of this crystallic Pb salt should be about 25-30%.
There are at least to methods how to blind photo cameras when you go on the 
red light.

Alex
