From: guy1656 at ados.com (guy1656)
Date: Tue Dec  9 23:35:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Re: OT - License plates and covers.
In-Reply-To: <20031210034933.GW31122@ursine.ca>
References: <05AD3C7EEA42D311809300902785AC8A07FD4371@eft01ms01.eft.fiserv.net> <20031210004214.GC22555@sthelens.dimstar.net> <20031210034933.GW31122@ursine.ca>
Message-ID: <200312092329.46762.guy1656@ados.com>

Paul Johnson wrote:
: On Tue, Dec 09, 2003 at 04:42:14PM -0800, Russ Johnson wrote:
: > Where is this specified? Where in Oregon Law does it say that I can't
: > have a clear plastic license plate cover?
: >
: > Another question I can't find the answer to in any O.R.S. is, where does
: > it say I must have a front license plate?
:
: It helps to know the state calls them "registration plates."  The way
: it reads to me is you get issued a certain number of plates, you have
: to mount both where they're plainly visible (and not covered or
: vandalized with shellac, or in the case of front plates, thrown on the
: dashboard).  Use your head: Why bother having license plates if you're
: going to hide them?

A fun thing to consider:

Does the law clearly forbid 'conditioning the atmosphere' in the vicinity of 
the plate so as to render the plate illegible? In other words, although there 
is no physical object between the plate and the viewer, a small array of 
Tesla coils around the periphery of the plate could draw arcs across the 
viewing area at a distance from the plate and prevent the numbers from being 
read or photographed. Perhaps plasma channels may not be covered or defined 
sufficiently by the words of the law. If that is the case, then a sort of 
instant-on mini lightning generator (think Spencer's) might work for coasting 
through those darn photo-intersenctions...

GLL




From mikedela at theplatinumrule.com  Tue Dec  9 23:36:02 2003
From: mikedela at theplatinumrule.com (Mike De La Mater)
Date: Tue Dec  9 23:36:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] A dilema
In-Reply-To: <1071005607.16708.38.camel@nat.alcpress.com>
References: <1071005607.16708.38.camel@nat.alcpress.com>
Message-ID: <1071041757.1223.21.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>

On Tue, 2003-12-09 at 13:33, Ed Sawicki wrote:

> The main problem is my customer's attitude. They do not
> care about security if it's the least bit inconvenient.
> Worse, they don't care about the privacy of their customer
> data. Their customers are individuals who would be devastated
> by identity theft. Their personal data is stored on this
> company's server and there's no effort to protect it.

I feel for you , Ed. I had a customer connected to a LAN in an insurance
office where there was NOTHING installed, no firewall, hardware or
otherwise and the McAffee that had expired years ago.

I wound up disconnecting the customer and walking away. I could not bear
the thought of 5,600 people's home addresses, vehicle VINs, SSANs,
incomes and bank account information floating around, free form on the
web.

I tried to give them a clue by presenting a nice letter as I left their
circle of vendors, but they only stuck their heads in the sand further.
Hopefully they have since found someone whose advice they can trust more
than mine.

People are paranoid that we're trying to over-protect them for our
personal gain. They think it's being over-sold, like too big an air
conditioner or an extended warranty that won't fix the stuff they need.
I do not know how to bridge that gap, so I have to leave them to their
silliness.

Run, man. run. In the end you can be proud of what you do. there are
just some people out there that don't want what you do. For them,
there's an MCSE.

-- 
Mike De La Mater
Small Business Networks and Computers
Your key to technology that works

503-702-6749

From iconoklastic at yahoo.com  Wed Dec 10 01:02:02 2003
From: iconoklastic at yahoo.com (Robert Kopp)
Date: Wed Dec 10 01:02:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] SuSE 9.0 installation
In-Reply-To: <1070927911.6560.1.camel@halo.selover.net>
Message-ID: <20031210090148.15854.qmail@web9605.mail.yahoo.com>

--- Holger Stephan <holger at frogleg.net> wrote:
> On Mon, 2003-12-08 at 13:46, Russell Evans wrote:
> > The SuSE installation disks on Ebay are illegal if
> they are copies and
> > the person providing them charge for the disks. 
> 
> >From what I heard this is not true. Please provide
> a proof. 
> 
Under the provisions of the GPL, sellers of media can
charge a "reasonable" amount for material costs. The
tendency, however, is for distributions not to be
provided as .iso's, so that people will buy the retail
product which includes "support," often very
inadequate, due to the inconvenience associated with
installing individual packages.

As a safety measure, SuSE provides very little
downloadable documentation. Red Hat apparently
restricts the use of its name, so that disks of its
software provided by third parties are marketed as
"Linux 9.0," or whatever. 

=====
Robert "Tim" Kopp
http://analytic.tripod.com/

> Er, if a spammer can pump out 100,000 ads in an hour, but it takes days
> to identify it, then "it works" doesn't mean much overall.

You are failing to understand:  "When sent", and even "when delivered"
is not the same as "when read/detected."  Not everyone reads all the
email within minutes of it being sent.  As stated below if the time
period is 2 hours, that may be faster than the email can be delivered.

> 
> > If you want, you can hold all unknown mail for a period of time (2
> > hours as a guess) until the peak time (when the spammer key is mostly
> > likely identified and has been reported to the razor-PGP servers).
> 
> Two hours for a process which may take two days?  Sounds like a lot of
> inconvenience just to break off a little corner of spam traffic, doesn't
> it?

Um, are you purposely taking things out of context, or am I not clear.

The above "days" was a maximum.  The 2 hours listed here is my guess as
to as to what the average peak time was (in other words, the best time
to hold email from a signed unknown, so that it is most likely that the
unknown spam account has been detected).

If I am not clear, I am sorry,  otherwise please stop juxtaposing unlike
values.


> > 1)  It forces them to send 1 mail per user.  This greatly increases
> > overheard *per* mail.  Most spammers still bulk send their mail.
> 
> > 2)  It makes them calculate keys per mail, and sigs per mail. Even
> > milliseconds adds up when we are talking millions of mails.
> 
> Why is that?  I thought only the body of the message is signed.
> 

Um, I am confused.  Yes, only the body of the email is signed, but it is
still a real value to run the key creation, signature calculation, and
signature attachment.

If you do not think so please test this.

Send 5 million emails on a LAN (a virtual catch all account should do
it).  It is all the same exact note, just the TO: field changes.

Now run the process that creates unique senders, keys, and signatures
for each of the mails.  See if it is negligible.



> > 3)  It may even make them have to keep those keys around.  If the
> > return contact is not via web/phone, they have a logistics issue.
> 
> Not sure what this means, sorry.  They'll be creating arbitrary keys
> just to get through filters.  The contact method won't change.
> 

Many of the Nigerian scams use the email for the return address.  Access
to those emails can be monitored but traces are easier to cleanse.  If a
key in involved, that key must be kept around at the scammers end (or
access to it).

> > 4)  All of these processes leave huge forensics trails.
> 
> How?  A single virus can be written to gen' keys and send spam from a
> compromised host.

And that process leaves a ton of information.  In this case it would
merely prove that the virus used that machine to generate the keys. 
While that makes for a great story, lots of spam is still generated on
within the spammers' machines.


> 
> > One of the main ways to attack spammer is to penny them to death.  The
> 
> Great theory, like charging everyone a fraction of a penny for each
> email sent.  Thing is, spam is sent anonymously from hijacked servers. 
> (RATs are generating a third of it, for example.)  So spammers won't
> really feel it.

Umm, you are taking the line out of context.  The point was to make each
email have a resource use that needs real time (milliseconds).  You and
I will not notice it, but even a virus will be impacted (as per the 5
million email examples above).  A monetary tax makes no sense since it
will not be billed to the right person or entity (though in general it
might make everyone must tighter about security, but that won't happen
for a while).

From iconoklastic at yahoo.com  Wed Dec 10 10:49:01 2003

I'm having a problem I don't understand very well, and
any insight would be appreciated. I am using an add-on
drive controller (Promise Ultra100 TX2). Although
Linux is said to support it, I am beginning to doubt
it. At the same time, the controller is needed to
support the large drive I am now using.

The installation of Red Hat and SuSE cannot be
completed at all. In both cases, about halfway through
it says something about the media being defective, and
you can reboot now. It worked before the installation
of the new controller, though.

As I mentioned, Mandrake really comes close. About the
only problem is that the CD drives, connected to the
onboard controller, are not set up properly, and there
are no block devices that correspond to them
(/dev/cdrom, /dev/scd0, etc.).

What do you do about that? One possibility I can think
of is to disconnect the power cables to the CD drives
during the installation and to install either from a
hard disk partition, or from a removable CD drive. I
have room to copy the installation disks to a hard
disk partition, though I don't know how to do it. As
to a removable CD drive, it wouldn't be bootable, so
that would entail making a boot floppy. (Apparently
that is pretty easy.)

Maybe kernel parameters would offer an easier
solution. I don't think the kernel is able to
distinguish between the two controllers properly. And
no, when I posted this to the Mandrake mailing list, I
didn't get an answer.

From jason at vancleve.com  Wed Dec 10 11:54:01 2003
From: jason at vancleve.com (Jason Van Cleve)
Date: Wed Dec 10 11:54:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] what is the point of PGP-signed emails?
In-Reply-To: <1071050423.1180.24.camel@kat.zotnet.com>
References: <200312071042.33484.carla@bratgrrl.com>
	<1070871791.24781.19.camel@kat.zotnet.com>
	<20031209012620.GC9506@ursine.ca>
	<20031209021551.GE17763@maybe.net>
	<20031209025128.GB25747@ursine.ca>
	<20031209121846.3831bfc9.jason@vancleve.com>
	<1070998375.26545.45.camel@kat.zotnet.com>
	<20031209143019.0462505b.jason@vancleve.com>
	<1071016882.26545.224.camel@kat.zotnet.com>
	<20031209221720.3313f4fe.jason@vancleve.com>
	<1071050423.1180.24.camel@kat.zotnet.com>
Message-ID: <20031210125401.2680b8c6.jason@vancleve.com>

Quoth Zot O'Connor, on Wed, 10 Dec 2003 02:00:23 -0800:

> You are failing to understand:  "When sent", and even "when delivered"
> is not the same as "when read/detected."  Not everyone reads all the
> email within minutes of it being sent.  As stated below if the time
> period is 2 hours, that may be faster than the email can be delivered.

No, I understand the process, I think.  I'm just saying that where it
takes more than a day for spammers' certificates to be flagged as evil,
spam will still get through to the recipient, since most people check
their email at least once a day.

> If I am not clear, I am sorry,  otherwise please stop juxtaposing
> unlike values.

I'm not sure I did.  You said at first that detection would take
"minutes to days".  If so, then a two-hour wait time would only catch a
small percentage of spam (based on a linear proportion of detection
times), correct?  Unless you believe the majority of spam will be caught
within two hours, and that only a few will take as long as days. 
Obviously, neither of us has graphed this prediction.  The point is,
unless that two-hour wait is ample for a large majority of spam, it is a
high price to pay, because most people want speedy delivery, as someone
else mentioned.  So it does matter how long detection takes.

Remember, we are up against a great ROE for spammers.  That's why it's
such a big goddamn problem.  If we only try to further inconvenience
them, they'll just get better at what they do.

> Send 5 million emails on a LAN (a virtual catch all account should do
> it).  It is all the same exact note, just the TO: field changes.
> 
> Now run the process that creates unique senders, keys, and signatures
> for each of the mails.  See if it is negligible.

Yes, sir, that would require more processing.  My question, why should
the spammer need to create a different key for each email?  I see that
it would ensure delivery (not accounting for traditional spam filters)
and would make that two-hour wait a moot point, but if it really makes
it so difficult to spam in bulk, then couldn't the spammer just use the
same key for a number of emails?

> Many of the Nigerian scams use the email for the return address. 
> Access to those emails can be monitored but traces are easier to
> cleanse.  If a key in involved, that key must be kept around at the
> scammers end (or access to it).

This is a process of which I lack understanding.  In my mind, the
spammer will generate arbitrary keys just to get emails through to the
consumer.  Nobody knows anything about those keys, thus they are just as
useless as a return address for finding out who sent the spam.  Explain
how the key is involved after the email is received.

> And that process leaves a ton of information.  In this case it would
> merely prove that the virus used that machine to generate the keys. 
> While that makes for a great story, lots of spam is still generated on
> within the spammers' machines.

Okay, but even so, how does signing emails with unknown keys leave any
forensics?  Are you thinking spammers' boxes could be seized and the
keys found on them?  Not likely.

(Then again, if it does serve to incriminate the sending machines, that
would only mean rooted and RAT-infested machines would become the
primary MO.  That doesn't sound very nice.)

> Umm, you are taking the line out of context.  The point was to make
> each email have a resource use that needs real time (milliseconds). 
> You and I will not notice it, but even a virus will be impacted (as
> per the 5 million email examples above).  A monetary tax makes no
> sense since it will not be billed to the right person or entity
> (though in general it might make everyone must tighter about security,
> but that won't happen for a while).

Agreed.  But you'll have to quantify this, to make a real argument. 
First, we have to decide how much spam is sent from spammers' own
machines versus how much is sent from hacked boxen--how much processing
power have the spammers at their disposal, considering the rate at which
networks can actually send email.  If as you say a separate key has to
be created for every email (of which I remain dubious), then the flow of
spam may indeed be reduced.  But will it make a difference over time? 
Considering Moore's Law is not yet in any danger, I have to wonder.

But if you think your solution is worthwhile, I'd be interested in
reading a complete description.

--Jason Van Cleve

My new years resolution is 1280x1024.

Date: Wed Dec 10 16:40:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Linux installation
In-Reply-To: <20031210184807.17072.qmail@web9604.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20031210184807.17072.qmail@web9604.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <1071103278.2034.604.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Wed, 2003-12-10 at 10:48, Robert Kopp wrote:
> I'm having a problem I don't understand very well, and
> any insight would be appreciated. I am using an add-on
> drive controller (Promise Ultra100 TX2). Although
> Linux is said to support it, I am beginning to doubt
> it. At the same time, the controller is needed to
> support the large drive I am now using.

It does support it, but can be difficult to install to.
> 
> The installation of Red Hat and SuSE cannot be
> completed at all. In both cases, about halfway through
> it says something about the media being defective, and
> you can reboot now. It worked before the installation
> of the new controller, though.

Do you have a small drive that you can use to install the OS?  When you
get the big drive working, this will most likely require some sort of
kernel upgrade.  When the big drive is working, partition it and copy a
tarball of the file system from the small drive to the large drive.
Untar and start playing with your boot loader to get the of board
controller to boot, you can always go back to the small drive if you
need to. 
> 
> As I mentioned, Mandrake really comes close. About the
> only problem is that the CD drives, connected to the
> onboard controller, are not set up properly, and there
> are no block devices that correspond to them
> (/dev/cdrom, /dev/scd0, etc.).

These are just mis-labeled drives, the onboard controller drives are
probably labeled /dev/hde, /dev/hdf, /dev/hdg and /dev/hdh.  The
symlinks and kernel parameters probably need to be corrected.

> What do you do about that? One possibility I can think
> of is to disconnect the power cables to the CD drives
> during the installation and to install either from a
> hard disk partition, or from a removable CD drive. I
> have room to copy the installation disks to a hard
> disk partition, though I don't know how to do it. As
> to a removable CD drive, it wouldn't be bootable, so
> that would entail making a boot floppy. (Apparently
> that is pretty easy.)
> 
> Maybe kernel parameters would offer an easier
> solution. I don't think the kernel is able to
> distinguish between the two controllers properly. And
> no, when I posted this to the Mandrake mailing list, I
> didn't get an answer.

My guess is that the kernel knows what it is doing, unless your
motherboard is assigning the IRQ of the controller card to another
device as well.  The startup log should shed a lot of light on what the
devices are being called, and the IRQ's that are being assigned.

Good Luck,

Derek Loree

On Wed, 10 Dec 2003, Russ Johnson wrote:
> * Paul Johnson <baloo at ursine.ca> [2003-12-09 19:49]:
> > Also, what legitimate reason is there not to have a front license
> > plate?  Makes your vehicle easier to identify from the front if it's
> > stolen and/or involved in a crime, so what drawbacks could there
> > possibly be by having it there?
>
> In the case of certain cars, it spoils the appearence of the car.

Is this really a greater concern than public safety?  Doesn't that show
some pretty fucked-up priorities?

> Specifically, Corvettes, Camaros and many other sporty type cars are not
> designed to integrate the plate into their design.

The public should not have to accomodate the whims of designers.

> In this case, it's nothing of the sort, as a friend was cited for having
> his plate in the window, since the bumper mount was striped and would
> not hold it.

Nothing of what sort?

Windows have coatings to prevent glare and UV penetration.  License plates
are designed specifically to reflect as much of the spectrum as possible
to allow for many read methods.  Clear covers and windows both limit the
"visibility" of the plate even if your feeble human eyes cannot discern
the difference.

> He asked me the question a few weeks ago, and I didn't find the answer.

Which question?  Your writing is very unclear.

J.

From sandy at herring.org  Wed Dec 10 17:43:01 2003
From: sandy at herring.org (Sandy Herring)
Date: Wed Dec 10 17:43:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Linux installation
In-Reply-To: <20031210184807.17072.qmail@web9604.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20031210184807.17072.qmail@web9604.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <20031211014236.GA20645@kippered.herring.org>

On Wed, 10 Dec 2003, Robert Kopp wrote: 
> I'm having a problem I don't understand very well, and
> any insight would be appreciated. I am using an add-on
> drive controller (Promise Ultra100 TX2). Although
> Linux is said to support it, I am beginning to doubt
> it. At the same time, the controller is needed to
> support the large drive I am now using.
> 
> The installation of Red Hat and SuSE cannot be
> completed at all. In both cases, about halfway through
> it says something about the media being defective, and
> you can reboot now. It worked before the installation
> of the new controller, though.
[...]

I have the same controller running on my RH7.3 system. I had a similar
problem installing RH7.2 since it had the 2.4.2 kernel - which had no
support for ATA100. The install would get most of the way through and
then spontaneously reboot. Once I figured out the problem, I had to
finagle the bagel to load it on my Maxtor 40GB by attaching the drive to
the onboard controller to install RH7.2, then making and booting into
2.4.17 on my RH7.2 system and finally connecting the drive to the
Promise controller. After that I needed to adjust the swap entry in
/etc/fstab and reboot and I was good to go (I use grub as a boot
manager). I've since upgraded to RH7.3.

What kernel are you running?

Sandy

tractors don't get plates, semi trucks only get a front plate,
trailers and campers only get a back plate...

> Burlington Northern and Santa Fe (Union Station), and Lake Oswego

Because they're tracks to not literally criss-cross the city... certainly

a less than 10 minutes' walk can cross 30 different automobile "tracks".

benefits.  Automobiles restrict mobility massively for very little benefit
to most people in most situations.

> get the job done faster and more reliably.

Yes.  Less maintenance, more reliability, etc.  I didn't mean "mass
transit" to only imply human transportation.

On Wed, Dec 10, 2003 at 07:10:18PM -0800, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> Because they're tracks to not literally criss-cross the city... certainly
> not to the extent that the automobile tracks do.

True enough.  They once did, though, in most American cities.  Auto,
tire and oil industries did a pretty damn good job of making sure
streetcars and other forms of mass transit were scrapped to
ineffectiveness in the 1930s on a fairly grand scale.  Had they failed
in their efforts, LA would probably be livable (if you ignore the fact
it's inhabited almost exclusively by shallow morons who should have no
business having a driver's license or, for that matter, ability to
breathe to begin with).

> What you give up in mobility you more than make up in transportation
> benefits.  Automobiles restrict mobility massively for very little benefit
> to most people in most situations.

Exactly.  Even though it's not like we have streetcars on nearly every
street like we used to, TriMet, a bicycle, and a cargo trailer is
everything you'll ever need to get around if you're within two miles
of a transit stop.  Ditch the bike and trailer and replace with a
granny cart if you're within a half mile of transit.  Everybody else
is making up excuses for overbooking their schedule or trying to
justify living centrally located to nothing.

On Wed, 2003-12-10 at 17:30, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> On Wed, 10 Dec 2003, Ed Sawicki wrote:
> > Thanks to everyone that responded. While I know I should walk away, I'd
> > feel guilty about abandoning those people whose private information is
> > at risk.
> 
> I think walking away is the most selfish, irresponsible approach to the
> problem and I'm shocked that anyone would respond with such a suggestion.

No continuing to work without comment is far a more "selfish,
irresponsible approach," but even that would not shock me.

> 
> > I think there are many people and companies who use Windows and have
> > similar attitudes about security and privacy and it would be nice if
> > there was something we (the community) could do to educate them.
> 
> You CAN educate them... 

Only if they want to be educated.

> and if they don't listen, you should go public as
> much as possible.

That may not be legal, ethical, or correct.  There may be more damage by
going public to all parties.  If telling the world a bank has no
security, causes 100,000 people to lose all of their money, is that the
best thing?  Do not assume that the people wopuld withdraw their money
before the criminals could.  Same goes for public companies and stock
prices.

It is never cut and dry in these cases.  The best outcome is for the
management to change priorities.  Walking away may at least not make the
situation worse (through your actions).

BTW there are ways of going public, that are not so public, and may be
legal and ethical.  Reporting this to private entities that are covered
under any NDA would be good.  In the case of the public company, telling
the Board of Directors, or Investors, would not be unethical.

>   Let them know your intentions and perhaps speak with an
> attorney if you're so worried about it, but you can talk to their
> customers and the public about their unsafe practices if they refuse to
> listen to reason.
> 
> I think it's pretty clear that you know what the right thing to do might
> be, but you're looking for something easier.
> 
> Most of the time, the right thing is the absolutely hardest thing.

I would argue the right thing may seem harder, but is often the easiest
in the long run.  One way of making A or B decisions is to ask "in 10
years which would I prefer that I had made.

> J.

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Wed Dec 10 21:29:02 2003
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: Wed Dec 10 21:29:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] GNU hats make good advertising!
Message-ID: <867k13ly7s.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

I was in the grocery store this evening, and as I walked up to the
checkout line, the bagger asks me what my hat means, the baseball cap
with the big yellow GNU on it.  I give him my standard reply, which is
that it's a free software project.  He's never heard of that but asks
if it is related to the animal, and I say that they use the animal as
a kind of mascot.  And then I mention the bit about GNU not actually
being pronounced that way, that apparently in native language it has a
click in it like the Bushmen language has.  Then I turn around and the
checker tells me that he's got Debian GNU/Linux CD's at home but
couldn't install in on his laptop.  Something about the winmodem he
thinks.  After a little diagnosis of what might be thwarting his
attempts, I realize that I'm not going to solve the problem in the
checkout line, and so I tell him about the clinic and tell him where
it is and when it meets.  He writes it all down.

Seems like pretty good market penetration when the checker at the
grocery store is interested in running a GNU system.  It's not just
for hackers anymore.

response from the CD drives after installation. These
are connected to the onboard controller and the large

controllers with devices connected to each might have
complicated the installation. Now I think I'll try it

essential for owners of notebook computers and there

you expect to find it, I understand that

On Wed, 2003-12-10 at 11:54, Jason Van Cleve wrote:
> Quoth Zot O'Connor, on Wed, 10 Dec 2003 02:00:23 -0800:
> 
> > You are failing to understand:  "When sent", and even "when delivered"
> > is not the same as "when read/detected."  Not everyone reads all the
> > email within minutes of it being sent.  As stated below if the time
> > period is 2 hours, that may be faster than the email can be delivered.
> 
> No, I understand the process, I think.  I'm just saying that where it
> takes more than a day for spammers' certificates to be flagged as evil,
> spam will still get through to the recipient, 

This was explained further down, but you snipped it:

        The above "days" was a maximum.  The 2 hours listed here is my
        guess as to as to what the average peak time was (in other
        words, the best time to hold email from a signed unknown, so
        that it is most likely that the unknown spam account has been
        detected).
        
> since most people check
> their email at least once a day.

I am not sure this is true.  For power users yes.  For business users
yes.  But those people can have spam filters that are pretty good and
responsive already.

I bet "most" people check their mail a lot less frequently then you
would expect.  Remember most roads (> 50%) in the United States are
still dirt.....  Personal experience and statistics do not match.

But even once a day is fine since I am guessing at 2 hours.

> 
> > If I am not clear, I am sorry,  otherwise please stop juxtaposing
> > unlike values.
> 
> I'm not sure I did.  You said at first that detection would take
> "minutes to days".  If so, then a two-hour wait time would only catch a
> small percentage of spam (based on a linear proportion of detection
> times), correct?  Unless you believe the majority of spam will be caught
> within two hours, and that only a few will take as long as days. 
> Obviously, neither of us has graphed this prediction.

 I have stated that this is a guess.

>   The point is,
> unless that two-hour wait is ample for a large majority of spam,

This I stated (as my guess).

>  it is a
> high price to pay, because most people want speedy delivery, as someone
> else mentioned.  So it does matter how long detection takes.

I do not think a majority require speedy delivery.  When I leave the
tech, and medium tech business world, and talk to relatives, car part
manufacturers, and the like.  Their use and expectations of email are
far less.

Also this would only be delivery from previously unknown senders.  Known
senders could speed through the system.  Most email exchanges would be
easy.

> > Send 5 million emails on a LAN (a virtual catch all account should do
> > it).  It is all the same exact note, just the TO: field changes.
> > 
> > Now run the process that creates unique senders, keys, and signatures
> > for each of the mails.  See if it is negligible.
> 
> Yes, sir, that would require more processing.  My question, why should
> the spammer need to create a different key for each email?  I see that
> it would ensure delivery (not accounting for traditional spam filters)
> and would make that two-hour wait a moot point, but if it really makes
> it so difficult to spam in bulk, then couldn't the spammer just use the
> same key for a number of emails?

Um read back the emails.  You were commenting on this specific scenario.

The alternative, that each "batch" of spam has one key, means that whole
batch can be identified by the razor-pgp to the sender key.  This is
very very different than the current scoring.

Consider that now a filter for me, if it sees the word "Viagra" can be
%95 sure its spam, but if I work at clinic, that is not as true.  But if
someone on my magic razor-pgp reported this sender key as spam, than it
would be 100% sure when my clinic guy got the mail, or the clinic guy
opened it.

So identifying SPAM has just gotten easier due to sender (which is so
1996).

> 
> > Many of the Nigerian scams use the email for the return address. 
> > Access to those emails can be monitored but traces are easier to
> > cleanse.  If a key in involved, that key must be kept around at the
> > scammers end (or access to it).
> 
> This is a process of which I lack understanding.  In my mind, the
> spammer will generate arbitrary keys just to get emails through to the
> consumer.  Nobody knows anything about those keys, thus they are just as
> useless as a return address for finding out who sent the spam.  Explain
> how the key is involved after the email is received.

Keith needs to post the Mugu baiting site.  Believe it or not, most of
the return emails to the Nigerian scams are monitored by the sender and
you can start a conversation up with them.  Try it, its fun!

In order for that to work int he signed email world, they would have to
maintain the sender key for future emails.

Broadcast email with returns to fake email would not work of course
(that was mentioned prior).

> 
> > And that process leaves a ton of information.  In this case it would
> > merely prove that the virus used that machine to generate the keys. 
> > While that makes for a great story, lots of spam is still generated on
> > within the spammers' machines.
> 
> Okay, but even so, how does signing emails with unknown keys leave any
> forensics?  Are you thinking spammers' boxes could be seized and the
> keys found on them?  Not likely.

Where ever the spam is sent will have more "stuff" done on the machine. 
Calculating keys leaves lots of traces in swap, temp files, etc.  More
than sending emails.

> 
> (Then again, if it does serve to incriminate the sending machines, that
> would only mean rooted and RAT-infested machines would become the
> primary MO.  That doesn't sound very nice.)

This is true of any criminal catching tool.

> But if you think your solution is worthwhile, I'd be interested in
> reading a complete description.

First get everyone using keys, then I will write it up :)

From jschwaber at gmx.net  Wed Dec 10 22:29:02 2003
From: jschwaber at gmx.net (Jeff Schwaber)
Date: Wed Dec 10 22:29:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] scsi drive speed
Message-ID: <1071123947.11208.54.camel@localhost>

I've got an old Adaptec AHA 2940UW card and a Seagate 50G SCSI-3 Drive
(possibly 7200 rpm, don't remember model) and I've got the drive on the
very last connection of a U160-rated cable. I'm getting some odd numbers
on hdparm.

hdparm -t gives 2.66MB/s (read from drive)
hdparm -T gives 163MB/s (read from cache)

I'm really confused. A UW card should be able to run up to 40MB/s, so it
seems rather odd that it would be able to give me reads, even from
cache, of 163MB/s (we're talking drive cache, right? the card doesn't
cache stuff, I don't think), and also odd that the drive would only run
at 2.66 MB/s. Especially because I've got 5400 rpm ide drives running in
the high tens.

Anybody got any ideas? 

I'm using the aic7xxx driver on the 2.6 kernels. Oh, and the only other
piece of the setup I didn't mention is a brand-X converter to convert
the 68 pin SCSI cable to the SCA (or SCA-2, don't remember) 80-pin
connection.

Jeff

The ACT Legislative Assembly passed the Democrats' Open Source Bill last
night, information from party sources says.

The bill was introduced in July by Roslyn Dundas, the member for

member, Helen Cross, and accepted.

The bill says that public bodies should, as far as practicable, consider

DESCRIPTION

       disk ioctls supported by the stock  Linux  ATA/IDE  device
       driver  subsystem.   Some  options may work correctly only
       with the latest kernels.  For best results, compile hdparm
       with the include files from the latest kernel source code.

On Wed, 10 Dec 2003, Kyle Accardi wrote:
> What I'd like to see is a technical pronunciation key.  My webster's
> says to pronounce the animal (using chars I can't type here) "new".  I
> always pronounce the software project as "gnew".  Where does RMS put the
> clicks and what do they sound like?

RMS doesn't put in the click and never has.  He learned of the click much
later.  He has always pronounced it G'NU.  The english word is pronounced
NU.  The original word would be written today as !NU where the !
represents the tongue click.  Very often you'll find the imperialists
would just throw any old letter in where there was a sound they didn't
normally use in their native language.  That's one of the reasons nearly
everything in Africa and Southeast Asia has had to change its name in the
past forty years.

> A long time ago I said "line-ux" just because I preferred the long
> vowel.

I think it's because of the english pronunciation of Linus (as in Pauling
and Van Pelt).

> But when I met other users face-to-face I adopted the correct form
> "lin-ux".

I'm not sure where you get the "correct".

I mean, Linus isn't "leenuss" as much as he's "leenoos" and HE pronounces
it "leenooks".  Whereas most folks I know say something between "linnuks"
and "linooks".

> It's funny how folks develop their own pronunciations when not exposed
> to the words in the wild.  The other day a friend, who is well educated,
> was speaking of a sickly person and meant to say "invalid" but said "in
> valid"  (as in not legitimate).

I had a friend who said "mizl'd" to describe the act of deliberately
taking one astray in thought or action.  So you could misle somebody and
they would be misled.  Get it?

J.

From raanders at acm.org  Thu Dec 11 07:48:01 2003
From: raanders at acm.org (Roderick A. Anderson)
Date: Thu Dec 11 07:48:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Damned ISPs! [OT?]
In-Reply-To: <20031209125446.466c056d.jason@vancleve.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0312110731300.24403-100000@main.cyber-office.net>

On Tue, 9 Dec 2003, Jason Van Cleve wrote:

> I think the motivation was just complaints about spam coming from their
> IPs, regardless of whether it went through their SMTP relay or not.  So
> now they're trying to filter all mail traffic in hopes of avoiding phone
> calls and blacklists.  It's really not the ISP's responsibility, and
> they shouldn't be firewalling their customers, but it's a pragmatic
> issue.

I work for a local franchise of a larger ISP.  The Corporate office blocks
port 25 (ie. you have to use their SMTP server) and we have a local mail
server for the local users accounts plus domains hosted locally.  When
someone travels and uses a non-local dialup point they have to have two
mail accounts.  One on the local system and one on the corporate system
for outbound mail.  (They can use the corporate account only but we put 
the local in because we can respond and fix problems quicker.) 

   Locally we don't block any traffic.  You want a mail server on you DSL
(or dialup line) go for it.  Problem is if your machine is used for
SPAM'in by you or because it is an open relay - it costs.  $100 per
incident and if you don't fix the open relay or are doing the SPAM'in on
purpose $100 per message.  Once they (the customers) hear this they are
very willing to fix it and keep it fixed.

   Of course monitoring bandwidth usage and the type of traffic makes us 
much faster to respond.  We have taken a couple of DSL lines down when we 
couldn't get someone in charge or knowledgable to respond to our calls.  
That cost them $50.00 to reactivate the DSL line.

Not quite as draconian as port blocking but effective so far.


Rod

    "Open Source Software - You usually get more than you pay for..."
     "Build A Brighter Lamp :: Linux Apache {middleware} PostgreSQL"

From Steve.Daggett at fiserv.com  Thu Dec 11 09:40:02 2003
From: Steve.Daggett at fiserv.com (Daggett, Steve)
Date: Thu Dec 11 09:40:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] minicom scripting?
Message-ID: <05AD3C7EEA42D311809300902785AC8A07FD4388@eft01ms01.eft.fiserv.net>

Russell Senior asks:
>  Does
> anyone know how to script sending a file in minicom, or a more direct
> way to stuff a file out the serial port (at 2400 baud 7E1)?
> 

stty -F /dev/ttyS0 speed 2400 -parodd -cstopb -ixon
cat FILE > /dev/ttyS0

  You may or may not want XON/XOFF.  The man page is pretty good.

stty -a -F /dev/ttyS0, will show you how COM1 is currently configured.
 
Steve D...

Yeah, I think the installer wants you to rerun sndconfig instead of just
migrating the old module lines (module names change, new drivers get
added,
this sort of stuff). Usually sndconfig gets run at some point during the
upgrade, but may be it decided to skip it for some reason, or you hit
cancel
in the wrong place.

In-Reply-To: <1071121243.4475.46.camel@kat.zotnet.com>
References: <200312071042.33484.carla@bratgrrl.com>
	<1070871791.24781.19.camel@kat.zotnet.com>
	<20031209012620.GC9506@ursine.ca>
	<20031209021551.GE17763@maybe.net>
	<20031209025128.GB25747@ursine.ca>
	<20031209121846.3831bfc9.jason@vancleve.com>
	<1070998375.26545.45.camel@kat.zotnet.com>
	<20031209143019.0462505b.jason@vancleve.com>
	<1071016882.26545.224.camel@kat.zotnet.com>
	<20031209221720.3313f4fe.jason@vancleve.com>
	<1071050423.1180.24.camel@kat.zotnet.com>
	<20031210125401.2680b8c6.jason@vancleve.com>
	<1071121243.4475.46.camel@kat.zotnet.com>
Message-ID: <20031211115523.20e5b7ca.jason@vancleve.com>

Quoth Zot O'Connor, on Wed, 10 Dec 2003 21:40:44 -0800:

> Keith needs to post the Mugu baiting site.  Believe it or not, most of
> the return emails to the Nigerian scams are monitored by the sender
> and you can start a conversation up with them.  Try it, its fun!

Keith?

> In order for that to work int he signed email world, they would have
> to maintain the sender key for future emails.

I see.  Or they could just generate a new one in those cases.  Savvy
users will notice the discrepancy, of course, but then, most people who
reply to spam are not savvy.  In any case, it would be easy to obscure
an incriminating set of keys, should the trail need to be covered.

> > (Then again, if it does serve to incriminate the sending machines,
> > that would only mean rooted and RAT-infested machines would become
> > the primary MO.  That doesn't sound very nice.)
> 
> This is true of any criminal catching tool.

But a solution which doesn't encourage hacking would surely be
preferable.

> > But if you think your solution is worthwhile, I'd be interested in
> > reading a complete description.
> 
> First get everyone using keys, then I will write it up :)

Aye, first give me the chicken, then I'll produce the egg!  Anyway, this
is getting a tad complex, so let me try to get it strait.  Email servers
(SMTP?) would require a razor-PGP-like filter, and unsigned emails would
be filtered categorically.  Those signed with a key that is known to the
razor service/network and in good standing, would be forwarded without
delay.  Emails signed with an unknown key would be held in queue for a
period of time, a sort of probation.  If during that time the key were
not reported as abusive--to the specific service/network being applied
(or would that be universal?)--then the mail would be shuttled along to
the recipient, and otherwise it would be filtered.  At some point, after
some number of successful deliveries, a key would achieve a "known"
status.

The following problems seem to remain:

If all the mail servers are stalling emails for our hypothetical two
hours, who in that time will read and report them as spam?  It would
have to be a large subset of users, for every spam is not sent to
everyone.  I suppose it would be voluntary, and if enough people get
tired of doing it and revert to waiting themselves, the plan will fail.

If the two-hour wait period is effective after all, spammers will resort
to signing each email with a new key, rendering the probationary period
moot.  (Or they will send only a small number of emails per key, which
would be about as effective.)  You say the process of generating keys
will slow them down appreciably.  I doubt it.  Spammers are
sophisticated assholes.  And all of this will encourage them to hijack
other people's machines to do their work.

Another possibility is that spammers will generate a key, send a few
legitimate, hi-how-ya-doin' type emails to his friends (if he has any)
in order to make the key "known", then use it to send five million
penis-pill ads, many of which will reach their destinations before
razor-pgp knows what hit it.


I'd like to know if there is any feasibility to the idea of a universal
web of trust, where users worldwide would have to join, or their emails
would be filtered by default.  Thus unknown keys would never be
delivered at all.

--Jason

--
If you drink, don't park, accidents cause people.

On Thu, 2003-12-11 at 10:55, Jason Van Cleve wrote:
> Quoth Zot O'Connor, on Wed, 10 Dec 2003 21:40:44 -0800:


>   Anyway, this
> is getting a tad complex, so let me try to get it strait.  Email servers
> (SMTP?) would require a razor-PGP-like filter,

The trick is that this can be done at the email servers *and* the
client.  Currently some spam filters operate on the server before relay,
before delivery and at the client end.

If we allow for all those cases then power users and business users, who
want fast email, would likely turn off the delay, but still report.

In actuality if you check upon "attempt to pull mail" (either from the
client or the server), the the two delay is likely to be there for
non-power user and non-business users.

Also the razor-pgp would be a blacklist.  White Lists are local.

> 
> The following problems seem to remain:
> 
> If all the mail servers are stalling emails for our hypothetical two
> hours, who in that time will read and report them as spam?

As I mentioned above, I did not intend to quarantine the mail, but that
is not a bad idea.  Something like this may work
  If spamscore > 6 and key == unknown then hold

This could just work like bulk/spam filters work now, they put the
likely spam in a mailbox for you to decide.

By linking the spam score with the key, you will catch even more.

>   It would
> have to be a large subset of users, for every spam is not sent to
> everyone.

spam is pretty non-discriminatory.  Scams used to be, but now are not.

>   I suppose it would be voluntary, and if enough people get
> tired of doing it and revert to waiting themselves, the plan will fail.

If they had to wait yes.

> 
> If the two-hour wait period is effective after all, spammers will resort
> to signing each email with a new key, rendering the probationary period
> moot.  

Yes which make them work harder, but not you and I.  You still have the
forced then to work, and sign.

> (Or they will send only a small number of emails per key, which
> would be about as effective.)

This is a good thought (or evil thought).

>   You say the process of generating keys
> will slow them down appreciably.  I doubt it.  Spammers are
> sophisticated assholes.  And all of this will encourage them to hijack
> other people's machines to do their work.
> 

Even if they hijack, it makes their job more difficult, and *clearly*
illegal.  No free speech arguments now.

Just because it forces spammers to hijack other servers does not make it
bad.  I think it is good.  It makes then state their position, risk far
more personal issues, and work harder. 

To some extent it is like saying jewel thieves now have to break into
stores because the mean owners put locks up.

> Another possibility is that spammers will generate a key, send a few
> legitimate, hi-how-ya-doin' type emails to his friends (if he has any)
> in order to make the key "known", then use it to send five million
> penis-pill ads, many of which will reach their destinations before
> razor-pgp knows what hit it.

No this will not work.  The razor-pgp is a blacklist.  Whitelists are
local.  So his friends will be the only ones to get his spam.

> 
> 
> I'd like to know if there is any feasibility to the idea of a universal
> web of trust, where users worldwide would have to join, or their emails
> would be filtered by default.  Thus unknown keys would never be
> delivered at all.
> 

I think universal webs of trust do not work.  Small webs of trust do,
and large webs of distrust work.

The trick is getting people to use a verifiable delivery systems (pgp
keys) in the first place.  Then webs of [dis]trust start to work.

This is how it works in the real world.  You know Bob, so if Bob say the
show is good you trust him.  If an unknown John say its good, you
hesitate.  If you meet John socially and get to know him, then you trust
him.

-- 
Zot O'Connor

http://www.ZotConsulting.com
http://www.WhiteKnightHackers.com

Good news:  Amtrak serves the I-5 corridor with local service to towns
throughout the west.

> Riding the bus or train to another city is both more expensive (in MY 
> pocketbook, Jeme!) and slower. I can get to Eugene (for example) in 1.5

$40/round trip is cheaper than driving?  You must not be factoring in
wear and tear, insurance, or the car payment if it's not paid off.

> > is making up excuses for overbooking their schedule or trying to

> So just where are all these people supposed to live? If everyone lives

You failed social studies in high school, or just forget why Metro
exists?

Actually, that's exactly the kinds of populations cities are designed
to absorb.  Suburbs where originally where the population not
fortunate enough to be able to centrally locate themselves live.  And
for good reason: No lawn to mow, and you're walking distance to almost
everything instead of walking distance to a transit stop.  Smaller
cities also net you more open space to put towards agricultural and
recreational uses, less traffic, and faster, more effective transit.
LA and Seattle are classic examples of an almost uniquely American
mistake: The concept that the suburb is the city.

Actually, mass transit fares usually pay between 40 and 60% of
TriMet's income depending on what all is going on.  The motorist
equivalent, being gas tax, vehicle registration, parking meters, and
the occasional toll road don't quite cover 10% of the ODOT budget.  So

storage space outside of downtown areas, free access to non-toll
roads, noise, air and water pollution.  Who's screwing whom here?

On Thu, Dec 11, 2003 at 06:57:34PM -0800, AthlonRob wrote:
> I'm not sure on this one, but it seems to me Tri-Met uses buses a lot. 
> I think those buses drive on the same roads I drive on.

Yes.  But consider gas consumption per person.  TriMet's fleet of
diesel-hydraulic busses get between 3 and 6 MPG and average hundreds
of riders a day each, with busier routes getting into the thousands of
passengers, whereas your car likely gets somewhere between 13-33 MPG
and you can count the number of passengers a day on one hand in most
cases.

> I think most parking outside of downtown areas is in parking lots.

bike lane bordered by a ditch or a curb instead of a shoulder...

Quoth Zot O'Connor, on Thu, 11 Dec 2003 12:41:26 -0800:

> Even if they hijack, it makes their job more difficult, and *clearly*
> illegal.  No free speech arguments now.

A curiously happy side-effect.  Not a very strong argument, but a good
point.

> To some extent it is like saying jewel thieves now have to break into
> stores because the mean owners put locks up.

More like having to steal jewels from people's houses instead.

> No this will not work.  The razor-pgp is a blacklist.  Whitelists are
> local.  So his friends will be the only ones to get his spam.

I understand that, but weren't we talking about "known" and "unknown"
keys on the razor-pgp servers?

> I think universal webs of trust do not work.  Small webs of trust do,
> and large webs of distrust work.

Just to clarify, "universal" implies singularity.  When you use "webs"
in the plural, you may mean something else.

As with webs of trust (as they exist), the more fragmented and numerous
they are, the more secure, and the less useful.  Maybe webs could join
in trust, as you describe with people, but then you'd have something
universal.  (There's a political metaphor here.)

> The trick is getting people to use a verifiable delivery systems (pgp
> keys) in the first place.  Then webs of [dis]trust start to work.

Dunno, I really doubt you'll get more than 10% of email users signing
their emails, no matter how easy it is, unless you can convince them
there is a feasible solution to their personal spam problem.

--Jason

I like the new OS X Macs, they are pretty darn cool. But it's hard to 
like Apple any better than Microsoft. The only difference is they're 
less successful in their evil. 

From a technical and usability standpoint, I like an open hardware 
platform, as well as open software. Several of my Linux customers have 
hired programmers, from time to time, to tweak applications, and a 
couple of times to audit the source code. Not to mention being able to 
compile for different platforms, or compiling in different options. So 
having the sources does matter to non-programmers. 

It does present some difficulties, because Linux is much closer to being 
a "Hole Hawg Drill" than the computer on the Enterprise, which is more 
like a magic genie. So I have to work harder to set things up for 
users, and they need more coaching. 

And don't forget the reason for poor hardware support in Linux is retard 
hardware manufacturers, who I suspect are so deeply in Microsoft's 
pocket they dare not support Linux. Otherwise how can anyone possibly 
explain their continued refusal to make use of the huge free Linux 
talent pool, which toils to write drivers even in the face of 
opposition? They don't even have to write their own, it's already being 
done. But too many of them won't even supply specs, or product for 
testing. 

My first job is to meet my user's needs, so that often means they use 
winduhs or Apple. But I get Linux in there whenever possible, because I 
do not care to be held hostage by such as microsoft or apple. They have 
proven again and again they cannot be trusted.

On Thu, Dec 11, 2003 at 08:52:23PM -0800, Phil Tomson wrote:
> Anyone else wishing they could move to OSX?  (this is the Portland Linux 

I just did, for my laptop at least (12" powerbook G4).  Aside from
being fed up with lugging a 10lb. dell on my back all day for a
whopping 1:45 on the battery, I wanted a system that "just works".  I
love debian, and use it (almost) everywhere, but I've not been
thrilled with the entire Linux on a laptop adventure--The hardware
support is sufficient, but the installation/configuration is a bitch
when compared to MacOS.

So far I've been thrilled with the OS and the hardware.  With normal
use (programing, running time tests, configuring the environment--but
not playing mp3's) I get about 5 hours on the battery.
Powermanagement works excelently as well, not to mention stability.

The uptime clock apparently counts the time it's asleep as being
online, which is weird, but oh well.

Basically, it's been able to provide a stable low-hassle OS with apt,
bsd ports, and all the applications I use on a normal Debian system.
It also weights half what my "old" (6 month) Dell did.

The only difficulties I've had is with getting XDarwin to start up
with a Dvorak key layout, and setting the caps lock key to work as
control (it's "sticky", but I think that's a function of the hack I
used to remap it).

-Rogan


ps: Truly transparent terminals are a thing of beauty and productivity.



From aaron at speakeasy.org  Thu Dec 11 22:05:02 2003
From: aaron at speakeasy.org (Aaron Burt)
Date: Thu Dec 11 22:05:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Fedora or Red Hat (or OSX)
In-Reply-To: <200312112116.21280.carla@bratgrrl.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0312112044270.19920-100000@onyx.spiritone.com> <200312112116.21280.carla@bratgrrl.com>
Message-ID: <20031212060345.GB9719@bavariati.org>

[Warning: long-winded answer.]
On Thu, Dec 11, 2003 at 09:16:20PM -0800, Carla Schroder wrote:
> And don't forget the reason for poor hardware support in Linux is retard 
> hardware manufacturers, who I suspect are so deeply in Microsoft's 
> pocket they dare not support Linux. Otherwise how can anyone possibly 
> explain their continued refusal to make use of the huge free Linux 
> talent pool, which toils to write drivers even in the face of 
> opposition? They don't even have to write their own, it's already being 
> done. But too many of them won't even supply specs, or product for 
> testing. 

Three major reasons:
1. IP entanglement.  Most devices are made with chips from a few
different sources, and info about how they work is tied up in NDAs and
other contractural agreements.  It takes money, time (money), lawyers
(money) and internal politicking (money) to untangle things enough to
allow for open-source drivers and/or open specs.
 
2. Communication issues.  Oftentimes, components or even whole devices
are bought via a middleman or from a manufacturer who may feel that they
put their money into supplying a set of generic drivers and manual just
so they wouldn't have to deal with OEMs bugging their engineers.  The
engineers may be perfectly willing to supply the info to someone who's
capable of doing the drivers, but technical companies are organized to
keep the pesky customers from bugging the engineers.

3. Marketing issues.  Many important decisions end up being made in
Marketing, including things like platform support and target market.  
It may seem weird, but I hear that in some companies, when Marketing
says "XP and Win2K only", they mean it, and don't like folks messing
with their decisions.

So, yeah, stupid.

Oh, and don't forget the whole issue of hacking.  I'm sure manufacturers
worry that badly-written drivers could break hardware and cause warranty
claims, and I hear Intel doesn't like the fact that open-source drivers
for their Centrino WiFi chipset could allow for illegal transmit power
levels.

It's changing, though.  And I think that as long as it's easy to supply
specs or GPL code to someone who'll get it into the kernel, and really
heard to ship a binary driver for Linux, it'll continue to change.

Still, I wish there were a li'l library of reverse-engineering tools
(various sorts of bus scanners, etc.) to help with driver development.
Heck, maybe some well-funded Linux-booster organization could fund a
couple driver hackers and give 'em workbenches...

From mikedela at theplatinumrule.com  Fri Dec 12 06:54:04 2003
From: mikedela at theplatinumrule.com (Mike De La Mater)

Subject: [PLUG] Fedora or Red Hat

On Fri, 2003-12-12 at 02:26, Bill Spears wrote:
> This may not be so theoretical. Hard drives making growling sounds
> doesn't mean they're hungry, right?  This is usually a bad thing, right.

Bigfoot drives growl naturally, but Barracudas put the bite on you
silently. The Barracuda drive liked to eat Caviar, but they couldn't
stay on-line during the 4GB era. The DeskStar needs a while to get
charged up, is a silent killer, but is vulnerable through the vent. The
Fireball also attacks silently. Quantum has problems dealing with small
bits, but handles very large issues well.

Please send me more fun model names (off-list) and I'll post them on a
web page. (without the humor)

IMO (In My Observation) "growling" usually comes from a dying fan, while
"whining" comes from a failing hard drive. I've heard SCSI drives that
whine quite loudly for over a year before dying. 

I'd check the fans before diving checking the drive. I just jam
something into standard PS and case fans to stop them. I LOVE it when
customers tell me that their growling noise just stopped after a while.
Most assume that it fixed its self. I REALLY would like responsible PC
builders to quit using sleeve bearing fans in all PCs.

-- 
Mike De La Mater
Small Business Networks and Computers
Your key to technology that works
mikedela at ipns.com

From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Fri Dec 12 09:08:02 2003
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Fri Dec 12 09:08:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Fedora or Red Hat
In-Reply-To: <1071245633.1060.3.camel@apollo.spears.org>
References: <1071184856.2432.18.camel@apollo.spears.org>
	 <1071224801.1042.3.camel@apollo.spears.org>
	 <1071240823.2255.476.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
	 <1071245633.1060.3.camel@apollo.spears.org>
Message-ID: <1071250684.5481.12.camel@dell.linux.box>

On Fri, 2003-12-12 at 08:13, Bill Spears wrote:

> And the grand prize goes to Mike for his prescient diagnosis of my
> problem. In mid browse we went to black.  I mean no witty error message
> or warning just machine down.  It is running right now but the power fan
> is _not_ turning.
> 
> I guess the solution is a new case, right?  

The system just went down?  Since you say it is running right now, I'm
going to assume it came back on.  It powering down like that is not a
good thing... it tends to imply hardware failure somewhere along the
line, unless you have ACPI running.

If the powersupply fan isn't turning, you just need to replace that. 
You aren't 'supposed' to open a PSU and replace the fan, though... it's
supposed to be dangerous, what with all the capacitors in there.  If a
PSU fan goes out, I usually replace the whole thing - they aren't too
terribly expensive and help get me ready for my next upgrade.

You don't need to replace the whole case.  The powersupply is likely
attached to the case only by the wires plugging in to devices inside the
case and four screws on the face of the thing, on the back of your
case.  Remove all those, slide the old powersupply out, and slide a new
one in.

Have fun.

Rob

In other words, they're more retarded that I thought, because:

1. their products need software drivers to work at all
2. good drivers and docs = less cranky customers pestering tech support, 
and maybe even increased sales
3. one nice *nix tarball feeds every single Linux, BSD, and Unix. Nice 
package maintainers roll them into handy binary packages for those who 
prefer such
4. But each winduhs - 9x, NT, ME, 2000, and XP- needs its own binary 
driver. Which often must be modified because the latest Service Pack 
hoses it. Plus we all know how upgrading to the next winduhs means 
either waving bye to many of your peripherals, or spending wads of 
money on new hardware. But that's OK, somehow
5. Linux developers are valiantly reverse-engineering and writing 
drivers anyway. But supporting this free labor pool with specs and 
product is, somehow, Wrong.

A little hobby of mine is every so often I make the rounds of various 
hardware companies, and ask them about Linux support. Why don't they 
have any. Do they have any future plans to offer it. The 
Linux-unfriendly companies, without exception, respond in one of two 
ways: they ignore me totally, or they claim "when customers ask for it, 
we'll look at it." Which everyone here knows is complete bunk. 

So, according to the responses in this thread so far, the main reasons 
for the lack of Linux hardware support are incompetence and confusion. 
This is what we trust our computing infrastructure to? People who can't 
say duh without stuttering? People who can't tie their own shoelaces? 
Or have an independent thought, or make an independent decision?

I'll stick with my collusion-with-m$ theory. I'm not discounting 
incompetence and confusion, but it's hard to believe that's the primary 
reason. Why would any businessperson in their right mind purposely 
ignore significant new markets? It makes no sense.

On Fri, 12 Dec 2003, Bill Spears bspears-at-easystreet.com |PDX Linux| wrote:

> I thought we weren't supposed to take power supplies apart!  Isn't the
> fan an integral part of the power supply.  A case is a lot cheaper than
> a house fire (:-).  How safe is this process of replacing a power supply
> fan?

I would say if you have to ask-- don't.  There are capacitors inside that
can give you a nasty jolt even with the cord unplugged.  Shorting them
will arc and can cause burns, blindness, and unnecessary pants-wetting.
;-)

For $30-50 you can purchase a new power supply for your existing case,
which is generally a fairly easy thing to replace.  Alternatively, as you
already mentioned, you could get a new case, but moving all the computer
guts to a new case is pretty time-consuming.

  -- Steve

from a used case, a good quality power supply with

more than the cheapest case, but to me the near-silence is worth it.

From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Fri Dec 12 09:23:02 2003
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Fri Dec 12 09:23:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Fedora or Red Hat (or OSX)
In-Reply-To: <200312120908.43535.carla@bratgrrl.com>
References: <E1AUjIX-0005UT-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
	 <200312120908.43535.carla@bratgrrl.com>
Message-ID: <1071251633.5485.23.camel@dell.linux.box>

On Fri, 2003-12-12 at 09:08, Carla Schroder wrote:

> 1. their products need software drivers to work at all
> 2. good drivers and docs = less cranky customers pestering tech support, 
> and maybe even increased sales

IME, hardware makers, if they provide any technical support at all, make
it very difficult to locate and make it cost money in terms of long
distance phone calls...

> 3. one nice *nix tarball feeds every single Linux, BSD, and Unix. Nice 
> package maintainers roll them into handy binary packages for those who 
> prefer such

I'm not too up on cross-platform driver development, but I really don't
think you can write one nice little driver and expect it to compile
under Linux, FreeBSD, and Slowaurus.  If that were the case, FreeBSD
would have the same driver support Linux has, or very close to it... and
from what I understand, that just isn't the case.

> 4. But each winduhs - 9x, NT, ME, 2000, and XP- needs its own binary 
> driver. Which often must be modified because the latest Service Pack 
> hoses it. Plus we all know how upgrading to the next winduhs means 
> either waving bye to many of your peripherals, or spending wads of 
> money on new hardware. But that's OK, somehow

Just playing devil's advocate...

A few things... 9x and Me can share binary drivers.  2K and XP can share
binary drivers.  NT and 2K can share some binary drivers.

There are, I believe, more folks buying new hardware devices to run them
on Windows 98 than there are buying new hardware devices to run them
with any Unix workalike.  On a cost/benefit analysis, if you have
limited driver writing resources, it seems to make sense to me to build
one driver for 9x and one for XP (which will probably work with 2K). 
Right there you've covered what... 95% of the market?

That said, if they would just release a little bit more information
about their hardware products, there are a multitude of volunteers out
there who will take that and turn it into a real driver for Linux.

> 5. Linux developers are valiantly reverse-engineering and writing 
> drivers anyway. But supporting this free labor pool with specs and 
> product is, somehow, Wrong.

One interesting perspective on drivers I read a little while ago had to
do with Patents.  It may have been here, so this may all be a rerun. 
Patents are so crazy these days, everything is patented.  You cannot
design a piece of hardware today without inadvertently stepping on a
half dozen patents.  If they released the specs of the hardware so OSS
writers could design drivers for it, you would also be opening up enough
of the hardware to the public so your competitors could see where you
accidentally stepped on their patent and then... you get sued.

> A little hobby of mine is every so often I make the rounds of various 
> hardware companies, and ask them about Linux support. Why don't they 
> have any. Do they have any future plans to offer it. The 
> Linux-unfriendly companies, without exception, respond in one of two 
> ways: they ignore me totally, or they claim "when customers ask for it, 
> we'll look at it." Which everyone here knows is complete bunk. 
> 
> So, according to the responses in this thread so far, the main reasons 
> for the lack of Linux hardware support are incompetence and confusion.

From sandbox at pacifier.com  Fri Dec 12 09:56:02 2003
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Fri Dec 12 09:56:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Updating kernel on older system
In-Reply-To: <000001c3c0d2$b56005a0$6bf49d0a@CACheSoftware.com>
References: <000001c3c0d2$b56005a0$6bf49d0a@CACheSoftware.com>
Message-ID: <3FDA00F7.8040704@pacifier.com>

James Anchell wrote:
> My question is very basic.  I have a RedHat 6.2 system.  I would like to
> update the kernel, but a long time ago the automatic up2date feature stopped
> working.  I'm not sure why.  Therefore, I would like to update the kernel
> the old-fashioned way: retrieving a kernel via ftp and running an rpm
> command.  I did some searching on my own, but I'm not certain what the
> canonical site would be to obtain the kernel, or what the appropriate
> options to the rpm command should be.  Can someone please provide me with
> these details, and any other steps that may be necessary to carry out this
> update?

up2date probably stopped working because 6.2 updates were pulled from the 
servers.

I have these
kernel-2.2.19-6.2.7.i386.rpm
kernel-BOOT-2.2.19-6.2.7.i386.rpm
kernel-doc-2.2.19-6.2.7.i386.rpm
kernel-headers-2.2.19-6.2.7.i386.rpm
kernel-ibcs-2.2.19-6.2.7.i386.rpm
kernel-pcmcia-cs-2.2.19-6.2.7.i386.rpm
kernel-smp-2.2.19-6.2.7.i386.rpm
kernel-source-2.2.19-6.2.7.i386.rpm
kernel-utils-2.2.19-6.2.7.i386.rpm

Once you get your hands on the .rpms just do this as root,

# rpm -ivh kernel-2.2.19*

This will install the new kernel and associated flotsam along side your old 
one.  You now have two kernels to choose from at boot.

if you don't need any other of the packages, your done.  Can't remember if 
/etc/lilo.conf needs to be edited wiht RH 6.2 or not.  Take a look at it and 
  if necessary add a new stanza (duplicate the existing one and just change 
the kernel version.)  Run /sbin/lilo then reboot

Select your new kernel at the prompt and makes sure everything works as well 
as it did under the old kernel.  When you're happy with the new kernel, you 
can remove the old one

# rpm -q kernel

(you'll get a list of kernel packages installed)

# rpm -e kernel-2.the.old.one


--
Kyle Accardi








From barryb at proaxis.com  Fri Dec 12 10:18:01 2003
From: barryb at proaxis.com (Bill Barry)
Date: Fri Dec 12 10:18:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Updating kernel on older system
In-Reply-To: <000001c3c0d2$b56005a0$6bf49d0a@CACheSoftware.com>
References: <1071220453.1217.112.camel@kat.zotnet.com> <000001c3c0d2$b56005a0$6bf49d0a@CACheSoftware.com>
Message-ID: <20031212181702.GA20026@edge>

On Fri, Dec 12, 2003 at 09:09:30AM -0800, James Anchell wrote:
> My question is very basic.  I have a RedHat 6.2 system.  I would like to
> update the kernel, but a long time ago the automatic up2date feature stopped
> working.  I'm not sure why.  Therefore, I would like to update the kernel
> the old-fashioned way: retrieving a kernel via ftp and running an rpm
> command.  I did some searching on my own, but I'm not certain what the
> canonical site would be to obtain the kernel, or what the appropriate
> options to the rpm command should be.  Can someone please provide me with
> these details, and any other steps that may be necessary to carry out this
> update?
> 
> I know that I could just buy an new operating system, but this machine has a
> good deal of software on it that probably would not be compatible with a
> newer OS, and I've done extensive configuring of various services that I am
> reluctant to redo.  Thanks in advance for any assistance, James

You can find a 2.2.24 kernel for redhat 6.2 at rpmfind.net here
ftp://rpmfind.net/linux/redhat/updates/6.2/en/os/i386/kernel-2.2.24-6.2.3.i386.rpm

To install it, download it then use
rpm -hiv kernel-2.2.24-6.2.3.i386.rpm

It may complain that it depends on newer versions of other
packages which you will also have to download and install,
then go back and try installing the kernel again in
an iterative process until everythings sucessfully installs.

Bill Barry

From ehem at m5p.com  Fri Dec 12 14:00:03 2003
From: ehem at m5p.com (Elliott Mitchell)
Date: Fri Dec 12 14:00:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Fedora or Red Hat (or OSX)
In-Reply-To: <20031212172302.17561.74525.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <200312122158.hBCLwSwR093679@m5p.com>

> From: AthlonRob <AthlonRob at axpr.net>
> On Fri, 2003-12-12 at 09:08, Carla Schroder wrote:
> > 5. Linux developers are valiantly reverse-engineering and writing 
> > drivers anyway. But supporting this free labor pool with specs and 
> > product is, somehow, Wrong.
> 
> One interesting perspective on drivers I read a little while ago had to
> do with Patents.  It may have been here, so this may all be a rerun. 
> Patents are so crazy these days, everything is patented.  You cannot
> design a piece of hardware today without inadvertently stepping on a
> half dozen patents.  If they released the specs of the hardware so OSS
> writers could design drivers for it, you would also be opening up enough
> of the hardware to the public so your competitors could see where you
> accidentally stepped on their patent and then... you get sued.



In a message from Tim Roberts of XFree86 notoriety. Archived at:

http://www.mail-archive.com/devel at xfree86.org/msg02231.html

-----8<-----------------------------------------------------------8<-----
Unfortunately, "interesting" and "meaningful" are NOT among the criteria used
by the US Patent and Trademark Office in awarding patents.  The fact is most
chip companies DO hold patents on some peculiar aspect of their chips, and
they have to pretend to protect them in order to maintain their usefulness.

Most people don't realize how much the patent business has turned from being
an invention protector into one big Pokemon game.  Company A decides to
attack Company B.  They lay down three of their patents in the Pokemon arena
and say, "AHA!, you violate these patents, please pay me a million a year or
I'll sue."

Company B goes back to their Pokedex, chooses three likely candidates from
THEIR patent portfolio, and responsd "AHA!, you are violating OUR patents!
Sign this cross-licensing agreement or my Charizard's flame thrower attack
will turn you to ashes."

The two companies sign the agreement in order to avoid the court system, put
their patents back into their Pokeballs, and life goes on.  They have to have
patents in order to make their Pokemon card deck strong enough to survive
battles like that.

Of course, this is all anathema to the open source and free software
movements.

This e-mail also demonstrates that my children have spent WAY too much time
with Pokemon.
-----8<-----------------------------------------------------------8<-----

SCA-2. SCA-1 is practically non-existent, and many of them were HVD
anyways.

From sharbours at yahoo.com  Fri Dec 12 15:37:02 2003
From: sharbours at yahoo.com (Sean, Sharon and Kyle Harbour)
Date: Fri Dec 12 15:37:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] video conferencing
In-Reply-To: <FCEBIHDEIPOEEPHFOCFFCEGACLAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
Message-ID: <20031212233633.30729.qmail@web14422.mail.yahoo.com>

--- Billy Dimaculangan <bmdimaculangan at bhpi.com.ph> wrote:
> i already did that, i'm just missing the video. seems to be unbale
> to
> receive video

There is a significant checklist for troubleshooting H323
connections. For Netmeeting, I think the best you can do by default
is get the one behind the Linux firewall to place a call, but not
receive unsolicited incoming calls ( And at that, AFAICR you have to
open a large range of ports, because they are negotiated by the H323
clients semi-randomly). To make it work otherwise, there are some
H323 proxy modules you can install that will make two way work with
one box inside the firewall. If you want more, you need to install a
video gatekeeper on the firewall, of which there are several free
ones available.

Sean Harbour

From kyle at silverbeach.net  Fri Dec 12 18:04:02 2003
From: kyle at silverbeach.net (Kyle Hayes)
Date: Fri Dec 12 18:04:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Fedora or Red Hat (or OSX)
In-Reply-To: <200312120908.43535.carla@bratgrrl.com>
References: <E1AUjIX-0005UT-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org> <200312120908.43535.carla@bratgrrl.com>
Message-ID: <200312121804.00256.kyle@silverbeach.net>

On Friday 12 December 2003 09:08, Carla Schroder wrote:
> In other words, they're more retarded that I thought, because:
>
> 1. their products need software drivers to work at all
> 2. good drivers and docs = less cranky customers pestering tech support,
> and maybe even increased sales
> 3. one nice *nix tarball feeds every single Linux, BSD, and Unix. Nice
> package maintainers roll them into handy binary packages for those who
> prefer such
> 4. But each winduhs - 9x, NT, ME, 2000, and XP- needs its own binary
> driver. Which often must be modified because the latest Service Pack
> hoses it. Plus we all know how upgrading to the next winduhs means
> either waving bye to many of your peripherals, or spending wads of
> money on new hardware. But that's OK, somehow
> 5. Linux developers are valiantly reverse-engineering and writing
> drivers anyway. But supporting this free labor pool with specs and
> product is, somehow, Wrong.

I think it is a tad more complicated than that.

A lot of hardware needs some sort of driver to work properly (things like hard 
disks etc. may not).  The time cost of the software is part of the time cost 
of bringing the product to market.  Having worked for a while in a company 
that had real hardware products, I know that the software often delayed 
things dangerously.  It's hard to write the drivers when you don't have 
working hardware.  But, once the hardware is working the pressure is on to 
ship so that your product it out there before everyone else's. 

If your product is best, but it is one month later than a competitor's 
product, you might as well start dumping the existing hardware on eBay.  
You'll never get the end shelves in the stores, the front pages of the adds 
etc.  You're too late.

This time pressure leads to people buying all kinds of Windows driver kits 
that "do all the work for you" (tm), copy-and-paste coding etc.  Everything 
bad that you can do with code is done and done frequently to chase the goal 
of time to market.  It is ugly.

As to point 5, that seems reasonable until you realize that most hardware is 
made up of the same chipsets and other components off the shelf.  Take Wlan 
cards.  There are only a half-dozen chipsets that are widely used.  There are 
only a half-dozen CardBus chipsets (maybe not even that many).  There are 
only a few radio chips.  So, you've really only got a few different cards, 
but all from different manufacturers etc.  They all think they are protecting 
something by frobbing bits and moving ports around.  To them, the _only_ 
thing that they see as "intellectual capital" is the collection of specs.  
Nearly everything else is off the shelf.

A huge amount of hardware is basically put together from a relatively small 
number of parts.  If you want to build a modem, there's only a few chipsets 
that are decent and cheap.  This means that the vast majority of cards and 
finished products out there are really very little different from each other.  
Skimping on paint, thinner boards, cheaper surface mount resistors etc. is 
how those companies make their margins.  Companies will do anything to remove 
just one component.  Who cares if you have to invert all the bits and feed 
everything backwards at 1/3 the bus speed?  This is why there are different 
drivers.

It's a weird world, but if you dig enough, some of it becomes comprehensible. 
Not that I agree with the way hardware companies think or behave, but it is 
more comprehensible.  You have to remember that the margins on most hardware 
is so rediculously small that it is amazing that they can make it at all.  
There is _very_ little money spent on actual research at most places.

It doesn't help the Linux world and will not until Linux represents a 
significant percentage of sales.  I think that a couple of premium brands 
would have realized that they could charge a significant price difference for 
"works with Linux" products, but they haven't clued in yet.

Time for my nap.

Best,
Kyle

While it isn't RedHat, Fedora, or Debian... Slackware might be worth
considering, as well.

Slackware's philosophy is a bit different than that of RedHat/Fedora or
Debian.  It's a good rock solid distro, though.

If you check out the groups.google.com archive of
alt.os.linux.slackware, you'll see some stories folks have shared about
switching from RH to Slackware and the issues they've run in to, and how
they've solved them or decided Slackware wasn't for them.

If you want a bunch more info about it, I'd be happy to type some more..
but I think you can probably find enough on the web to decide if it is
worth investigating more.
